For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546433653000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'101016594', u'in_reply_to': u'124228843', u'id': u'124230681', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'infinatespace', u'text': u'The root of the problem is governments are driven by employment figures. They see jobs = good and show complete contempt at the thought of people not working. This mindset has led to "lets make lots of stuff", many inefficiencies, pointless contracts, engineered obsolescence, consumerism, subsidized fossil fuels, subsidized anything that has people pointlessly working etc.
being lean green and efficient means renewable energy, longer lasting products, no pointless building contracts, merged supply chains, pooled demand, recycled products, mass automation, shared services etc etc. All this would lead to the biggest Co2 savings one can think of but its scoffed at because of the huge unemployment that would ensue. green energy is far too efficient to employ the numbers that fossil fuel employ since fossil fuels have to be discovered, mined, transported, refined and much more.
The biggest antidote to Climate change is recession (less jobs), therefore the biggest driver is the opposite (economic activity i.e. jobs). Nothing of any significance will change until this conflict is addressed and employment is driven down via efficiencies, part time working, UBI, deflation, automation etc.
Personal changes will make very little difference if you still have to go to work and thus contribute to the problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546433508000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the huge unemployment that would ensue', u'effect': u'its scoffed at'}, {u'cause': u'all this', u'effect': u'the biggest co2 savings one can think of but its scoffed at because of the huge unemployment that would ensue'}], u'author_id': u'12185799', u'id': u'124230589', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'Yer, well, South Australia seems to be ahead of at least one aspect -https://treesforlife.org.au/', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546433505000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13322073', u'id': u'124230584', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lawrie Griffith', u'text': u'This is how I see it. (But I am always open to persuasion.) I have taken a rather analytical stance on this.
Well, I suspect what you say is because the environmental movement grew world wide from movements that sprang up to protect landscape, wildlife and areas of scenic significance from commercial exploitation. Sierra Club etc.So there is a natural synergy between them and labour movements committed to protecting rights of workers from commercial exploitation. Trade unions etc.In both cases it is collective action for collective benefit.
Then along come post-modernist theories of the identity of the individual where the ills of the world were blamed on social dynamics, (I have studied post-modernism formally). The focus shifted to became about the personal experience of the individual.Don't get me wrong. These theories have done a huge amount to remove discrimination based on identity. And we are the better for it.
But, a couple decades ago it went tribal and morfed into a new type of class war built around the tropes of theoretical models. And more recently, like all class warfare, it has been about the exercise of, and disputation of - power. Power between self identifying identityists and those they blame for the ills of society. By the very nature of its focus of the impact on the individual, it has splintered into more and more narrowly defined identities.
Neoliberalism focuses on the individual. It claims that in maximising the opportunities of the individual, society gains overall. Identityism makes the same claim. That in maximising the rights of the individual, society gains overall. Despite being at loggerheads, identityists and conservatives are both pursuing the cause of the rights of the individual.Neither are fighting for the collective rights of society. Both are battling for the power of groups within society.Both claim personal freedom is paramount above collective social laws where those laws inhibit the behaviour of individuals.
Now you don't have to be Albert Einstein to see how the aims of the identity movement can and do conflict with the collective aims of the environmental movement which seeks overarching principles and laws for the protection of the environment that inevitably limit the freedom of the individual. (Such as restricted access or commercial activity.)
Environmentalism seeks to limit the power of exploiters of nature.The collective good.Identityism seeks to limit the power of exploiters of minorities.The individual good.So it is not unexpected that they both end up on the left.
But, it is an uneasy alliance because of a fundamental dichotomy of purpose.
We are witnessing The Australian Greens Party ripping itself apart.And I believe that fundamental dichotomy of purpose is at the heart of its problems.
OK. I don't mind a debate. Its a very emotional issue. But anyone wishing to dispute my analysis please refrain from personalities if you can.Cheers.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432985000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the environmental movement grew world wide from movements that sprang up to protect landscape', u'effect': u'what you say is'}, {u'cause': u'a fundamental dichotomy of purpose', u'effect': u'but it is an uneasy alliance'}], u'author_id': u'13793892', u'in_reply_to': u'124224273', u'id': u'124230301', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'Um, the other tricky bit for "recycling" is trying to separate what they get from the bins. Most people don't care much - do not read 'labelling' - some plastics cannot be 'recycled'. One thing to note is that the "lids" on PET plastic bottles are different.Always take the 'screw tops" as well as the bit left behind OFF PET bottles.You will never really understand the cost of trying to separate these different plastics at the depot.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432958000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13322073', u'in_reply_to': u'124225065', u'id': u'124230289', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mountainrunnermum', u'text': u'BQSTART
Economics, What's the cost if we do nothing to slowdown Climate Change?
BQEND
Just looking at the IPCC SR1.5:
“Balancing of the costs and benefits of mitigation is challenging because estimating the value of climate change damages depends on multiple parameters whose appropriate values have been debated for decades (for example, the appropriate value of the discount rate) or that are very difficult to quantify (for example,the value of non-market impacts; the economic effects of losses in ecosystem services; and the potential for adaptation, which is dependent on the rate and timing of climate change and on the socioeconomic content).”
The best estimate of cumulative discounted damages due to 1.5C of warming by 2100 amounts to $54tn, the report says, rising to $69tn for 2C.
https://www.carbonbrief.org/in-depth-qa-ipccs-special-report-on-climate-change-at-one-point-five-c
And from the Stern Review, 2006:
Using the results from formal economic models, the Review estimates that if we don’t act, the overall costs and risks of climate change will be equivalent to losing at least 5% of global GDP each year, now and forever. If a wider range of risks and impacts is taken into account, the estimates of damage could rise to 20% of GDP or more. In contrast, the costs of action – reducing greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the worst impacts of climate change – can be limited to around 1% of global GDP each year. 
https://grist.files.wordpress.com/2006/11/summary_of_conclusions.pdf', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432878000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'estimating the value of climate change damages depends on multiple parameters whose appropriate values have been debated for decades value that are very difficult to quantify', u'effect': u'balancing of the costs and benefits of mitigation is challenging'}, {u'cause': u'1.5c of warming', u'effect': u'the best estimate of cumulative discounted damages'}], u'author_id': u'13049145', u'in_reply_to': u'124229143', u'id': u'124230241', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'David Jones', u'text': u'While on the one hand it's true that we need solid policies in order for the transition to work properly and within the time available, on the other hand it is not true that we should just sit and wait until the government eventually gets its act together if that ever happens.
Regardless of the fact that corporations have comparatively vast resources, individuals purchase much of their product. Lowering consumption of fossil fuel derived products on a large scale will damage the corporate profits of those giants, at some point they will be forced to change or be swallowed by the debt they will undoubtedly accrue in an effort to continue their operations. I have no doubt that the amount individuals can do as a collective is substantial even with the restrictions placed on our actions by the current fossil fuel driven infrastructure. Here are just a couple of actions that would be substantial:
1. Don't buy an SUV, buy a reasonably sized vehicle that will fulfil your general needs (make sure you understand what those are). Purchase a PHEV or EV.
2. Install water saving filters that reduce flow. 1.9l/minute seem plenty for the bathroom and 4l/minute is more than enough for the kitchen with modern techniques. For the shower, anything with 6l/minute should be enough as long as the quality is good. This here will lower your water related energy consumption by 3-10x depending on what equipment was used before and is very cheap to do. In my residence, I have calculated that we could collectively avoid 10000kWh or more of fossil fuel consumption with this change which is close to 3000kg of CO2 while also reducing our bills by about 10% on average. Assuming fossil fuels are consumed for heating water, it's the easiest and cheapest option to improve the situation and does not result in any comfort loss from my experience, in my case it has improved comfort.
There's obviously a lot more one could do but the above should be relatively easy to do, especially point 2.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432480000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'any comfort loss from my experience'}], u'author_id': u'17095222', u'in_reply_to': u'124228263', u'id': u'124230011', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'robertpinker', u'text': u'As one of the designers of extinction rebellion in the UK could I comment on two fundamental errors which the author of this article makes along with 30 years of failed environmentalist action. First you simply cannot mention we need to "save the world" as a passing comment and mention the E word - "existential" without at least expanding on what it means. It means in the first instance social collapse. This means millions of rapes, tens of millions slaughtered in wars, hundreds of millions of refugees, and the slow death of billions of people from starvation. Followed by extinction of the human species - this means everyone gone forever. You can say it in a number of ways and use other numbers but you need to start saying it - its going to be fucking hell and we are less than 10 years away maybe less.Second you have tell people the only thing people do which is effective when a government plans the genocide of its people - they rebel. Again this needs to be spelt out. It means thousands of people go the capital city and stay there day after day bringing the place to a stand still until the regime falls. This is not about the environment it is about national survival. It is about high politics - duty, betrayal and treason. Start treating it like what it is and change will happen. We have a window of a few years for nonviolent and democratic solutions to this. After that we will have slaughtered each other is a spasm of political hatred long before the seas rise above Sidney. 
Extinction Rebellion: Tell the truth and act as if that truth is real.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432121000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12879387', u'id': u'124229816', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'The tricky bit is that there is, as yet, not enough industries that CAN and DO, deal with recycled waste. There are some, converting plastics and rubber tyres into road surfaces - but not enough; some convert plastics into public seating, playgrounds, but not enough. Some convert 'paper' back into cardboard packaging - but not enough. Have you any idea how many trees (carbon collectors) are wasted as 'paper'?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546432006000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13322073', u'in_reply_to': u'124225065', u'id': u'124229744', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'And yes, rabbie, - stop believing that some sort of Middle Eastern. Mediterranean generated GOD will 'save us all". "Tis us, the average, ordinary PEOPLE, who have the power to solve this problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546431226000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13322073', u'in_reply_to': u'124225332', u'id': u'124229323', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'There is only one old party in Australia. The Liberal Party was formed just after World War Two. It's not very old at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546431080000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124220873', u'id': u'124229236', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'justdreamingguss', u'text': u'Economics, What's the cost if we do nothing to slowdown Climate Change?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546430936000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13984824', u'id': u'124229143', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'arbmahla', u'text': u'Public education about climate change is one thing that should and must be increased. Also, it is something that really upsets the fossil fuel corporations and the pro-pollution conservatives. They hate to have their lies exposed. They want everyone to calm down and to be seen as "the good guys". There should be more radio programs, more documentaries, more articles in magazines and newspapers. And most importantly, there should be a counter-offensive against denier propaganda exposing the government subsidies to the fossil fuel industry. Most people are not aware of how much of their tax dollars go to pay to support this industry.Fossil Fuel Subsidies', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546430763000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14723406', u'id': u'124229045', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'eyebrow', u'text': u'BQSTART
It is liberalism’s most dangerous lie that an individual’s action can solve problems of this scale.
BQEND
This is true, although political pressure can only be generated if enough individuals act in ways that indicate they care about the environment.
The only thing that will solve the problem of global warming is action on a planetary scale, which can only happen if governments change the rules of the game, to shift our economies away from fossil fuels and towards renewables.
But governments will only do that if they are constantly reminded that people care, and that has to be done by many individuals acting together.
So repairing, reusing and recycling are great, but it’s most important to make sure your local MP, congressman or whatever knows that you want them to act against global warming, and you will vote accordingly regardless.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546430659000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1317478', u'id': u'124228986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Glenister', u'text': u'Prove that the world's population will decline as you claim. A 2014 paper by demographers from several universities and the United Nations Population Division projected that the world's population would reach about 10.9 billion in 2100 and continue growing thereafter. A later prediction 2017 increased the estimate to 11.2 billion by 2100 with a 70% probability the world population will not stabilize this century. (Wikipedia, December 2018).', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546430493000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12612720', u'in_reply_to': u'124226383', u'id': u'124228897', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aussiejonn', u'text': u'Protest all you like, The LNP will not face up to the climate challenge.....& put an end date on the use of coal....As for Labor, not a lot of hope there ,sure they want to reduce emissions but at the same time,coal= jobs to some unions & they do not care about global warming..Labor is our best hops at the next election, but having a similer policy to the LNP is counter productive,no firm policy on the environment, & that includes phasing out coal will lose my vote, & probabaly many environmentalists, A Government that faces up to the challenge will score votes, The Planet is in serious trouble, it has been millions of years since the extremes of north & south are in free melt down,if nothing changes, and Antartica starts to make a bigger contribution it will not be MMs every 10 years but meters.Antartica & the north pole are two very different cases, Much of the ice on the southern extreme is land based.....As Emily Mulligan knows ,we must reduce greenhouse gases.....So far the Australian political system has its head in the sand (greens excluded)..NASA advised they are going to monitor the south extremes with a new satellite.....we need that information months soon become years & years decades.we are running out of time....', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546430392000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12059148', u'id': u'124228843', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'Um, apparently there are several names for "Government" of a Nation.One, obviously, is 'Capitalism' - where wealth devolves to the few."Socialism" -where wealth is mostly distributed among the peoples governed - with caveats. And "Communism" where wealth is distinctly kept within the "rulers" - or "autocrats" - the 'elite" - and the majority are 'peasants' - mere 'workers' for the use and pleasure of the the "Elites".

It just needs a government that is a little more encouraging and distinctly less crazy about coal.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546426575000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14681432', u'in_reply_to': u'124224059', u'id': u'124226896', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ejulia', u'text': u'The issue here is that people confuse "so something for the environment" with "do something to prevent climate change". There are lots of wonderful things we can do for the environment, recycling is one of them. yes it would be nice not to fill the planet with plastics or toxic chemicals but atmospheric carbon pollution is rather worse than that. It threatens our environment, probably irreversibly, to the extent that large areas of the globe, including many places with significant populations, will become uninhabitable, either below sea level or too hot.
There are far less actions that actually specifically do anything about climate change and that is actually by far the most serious threat. Things like the the price of electricity or even the entire business economy before that makes no sens at all. 
Even if you only count the cost in dollars and ignore the intangible factors, the cost makes any other economic fiddling just that, fiddling at the edges. Think of the cost every time a cyclone flattens coastal towns or fire a rages across the country. Think of the cost of massive crop failures and the resulting food shortages. Think about famine induced migration in the millions, and the wars that will probably cause. Any part of that represents an economic impact far greater than fiddling with the economy by waving a big stick at energy vendors.
Yes we can and should worry about recycling and so on so long as it does not distract us from getting with doing something about global warming. That means no new coal mines, stop Adani, stop issuing permits to explore for oil, stop letting global corporations open up gas drilling for export if it is going to release greenhouse gases.
It also means getting to the bottom of why the politicians let themselves be told what to do by those global corporations. It means throwing out politicians who openly admit to "representing the mining industry" in favour of those who will represent people.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546425861000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'14681432', u'id': u'124226561', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve Jones', u'text': u'EN014 Nuclear power, coal and incineration of waste will be phased out.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546425619000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11108528', u'in_reply_to': u'124226180', u'id': u'124226462', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SliceOfLemon', u'text': u'BQSTART

Clearly you have no idea what you're talking about.
China's official COP 21 policy is to do whatever it likes with emissions until 2030 and and at that point decide whether it does anything at all. The US, in the meantime, has
already reduced its emissions through the use of unconventional gas reserves.
Here's a quote from the International Energy Agency: "The biggest drop (in 2016) came from the United States, where carbon dioxide emissions fell 3%, or 160 million tonnes, while the economy grew by 1.6%. Emissions in the United States last year were at their lowest level since 1992, a period during which the economy grew by 80%." Facts are awkward things, huh?

BQSTART
In any case, renewable generation is now cheaper than coal, even existing coal generation. 
BQEND
If you make a statement like this without qualifying it with the circumstances under which the statement holds true then clearly you do not know what you are talking about. Of course renewables are cheaper - they have no fuel costs - but that's only at the marginal cost of production when they can be produced. However, it does not address the issue of generation when there is no sun/wind available or the fact that exisiting inverter technology cannot set the network frequency or the fact that renewables need massive storage facilities for firming to the same level of reliability and so on. These inconvenient facts also make renewables very expensive under many circumstances.
I suggest that when you have studied engineering and have some experience in the sector you can return with an informed opinion. The problem is a serious engineering challenge for which there are no simple answers. Your ill-informed slogans are unhelpful.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546425183000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15089024', u'in_reply_to': u'124222074', u'id': u'124226264', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vacantspace', u'text': u'People are funny. The UK's narrow-visioned PM doesn't even engage with climate change and most of her Tory party are no better.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546424069000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1347038', u'id': u'124225726', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FallenApple', u'text': u'"I think instead of protesting, you must form a political party with one aim - timely effective action on climate change. A one policy party."
The irony is that Brexit has ruined the Green Party for many who used to vote for them - including myself.
The Green Party is now "a one policy party" - a Stop Brexit party, like the Lib Dems.
All I hear from Caroline Lucas is calls to push aside the voice of the 17.4 million who voted to Leave the EU.
I do not see the EU as fundamentally a "save the planet" project or a substitute for a real international movement to do so.
But start up a new party that really does have "timely effective action on climate change" as its core policy, and you can count on my support.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546423931000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100522246', u'in_reply_to': u'124220661', u'id': u'124225649', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidJHursty', u'text': u'Another 'off beat' idea. If there is so much water 'run off' in Queensland - why not build a dam of some sort on the Tully River .. funnel/pipeline excess water into the headwaters of the Murray/Darling?Another odd idea. Was a 'lawnmower' in Adelaide a while back. Business killed off by water restrictions - but noticed that the roadside gum trees were dropping branches. And yep, one of my rich customers had put in 'bores' to keep his lawns green - but the problem with that was that the Adelaide underground 'water table' dropped - so the street trees had no choice but to drop branches.Did, actually, suggest to several local councils the notion of drilling 6 centimetre holes, 6 ft deep every 100 yards or so along the street gutters, and fill them with gravel - to replenish suburban roof rain run-off back into the groundwater ....But nobody listened.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546423773000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13322073', u'id': u'124225552', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rabbiedeoir', u'text': u'Only ten or fifteen years ago I was a climate change denier. Or rather, whilst recognising that the global climate was indeed changing, I denied the part that Man played in this phenomenon. However, with an interest in the preservation of wilderness regions, their ecologies, and the conservation of their wildlife (an interest that probably arose as a consequence of childhood memories of Kenya's wilderness and wildlife in the 1950s), I had always recognised the damaging effects of population growth, of pollution, and of natural resources exploitation. A conservative in cultural matters, I have nonetheless been reading the Guardian for at least twelve years, for its coverage of environmental and conservation issues. In the process, I have (within only the last two or three years), come to believe that Mankind's activities (particularly his activities related to servicing the demands of consumerism), are seriously impacting on our climate. And so I no longer rail against recycling, against the gradual phasing out of road vehicles powered by internal combustion, or against renewable energy. There is indeed little that I, individually, can do to save the Planet from our species. I can and do write about the threat Man poses to the Planet, and the demographic impact on western societies of climate change (with a number of such Blog entries appearing amidst entries on a wide range of other topics covered in my Blog); I can and do participate fully in the local recycling programme; I have in other ways all my life attempted to tread lightly upon our planet, above all in having never signed up to the consumerist delusion.If I can have become a believer, perhaps so can others who once, like myself, rejected the evidence for Man's impact on the climate. Or perhaps not . . . it took over a decade of reading the Guardian for me to undergo such a conversion, and those members of the public who support the Trumps and Bolsenaros of this world do not - and never will - read the Guardian, or other such publications.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546423359000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100124009', u'id': u'124225332', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'Knew I forgot something:4. Capital is actually wealth reserved to make more wealth. e.g. tools, education, technology, peace between nations.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546423139000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124224971', u'id': u'124225219', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FURIONSTORMRAGE', u'text': u'We always recycle carefully and put our recyclable stuff in the correct bin at home but then I go to work and all kinds of rubbish goes into one skip which costs our bosses a fortune to be taken away and dumped into landfill. Excellent Prologue by Fred Harrison: Who's Afraid of Henry George?
For sincere and willing truth-seekers, this short list, ^^free online^^ , cannot fail to illuminate. Namaste.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422779000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124224971', u'id': u'124225020', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'Thank you for this important message. It is beyond urgent, as you say.
BQSTART
School children going on strike demanding climate action provide a shining example of disruptive, urgent, agenda-setting activism. They acted like their lives depend on it – we all should.
BQENDWe really should. And as adults we are responsible for the system which has done this to us. And as responsible adults we
must understand the intimate details of the system, to isolate precisely which bits are at fault, and actually fix the flaws, rather than merely paper over them between wars.
It is within your power if it is within the bounds of your intent.
1. As the basis for economy, the Earth is all we have. All wealth must come from it, and ultimately be returned, from your next breath, to a wind farm to a vortex sword in WoW. Digital wealth is still dependent on the physical; requiring land, people and energy.
2. Land(aka nature), Wealth(what you want/need) and Money(sharing mechanism) are three entirely different categories of "thing", as your baby could undoubtedly attest. Capitalism says that they are all forms of capital. This is the source of the distortion, the heist of the millennium, and the huge thorn in Earths paw.
3. Wages are created by intelligently trained and employed people producing needed goods and services and available in the increased value of work-products, after work is done. The enormous production surplus achieved through division of labour, technology and other productivity multipliers underpin the value of the currency, always worth what you can buy with it.
Capitalism says wages are drawn from capital. In a barely-efficient world the only limit to production is availability of working citizens. Unemployment is not only unjust, it is also inefficient and completely unnecessary, not a natural human state at all.
So where did capitalism come from and why has it destroyed the Earth?
When the above creed was first written down by an unknown journalist in 1879 in then-remote San Francisco, Henry George, in the legendary Progress and Poverty. He sparked a global movement, including catalysing formation of Australian Labour. George was opposed to Marx's uncompromising revolution, preferring a social evolutionary approach, combining the best of individualism and collectivism based on the natural economy of the Earth and human desire/need.
While Marx was left to rearrange his manuscripts and even foment revolution on the outskirts of Europe, Henry George's thesis of a single tax on commercial land value to singularly fund civilisation gravely threatened established global power elites.
George had set out to discover the true cause of recessions, and why the worst poverty always seemed to accompany the most progress. Succeeding spectacularly, Progress and Poverty promised salvation in this life, not the next, and remains the only published work in history to outsell the Bible, globally, in a single year. Which it did for twenty consecutive years.
From Progress and Poverty chapter 17: "The Problem Explained":
BQSTART
Three things unite in production: land, labor, and capital. Three parties divide the output: landowner, laborer, and capitalist. If the laborer and capitalist get no more as production increases, it is a necessary inference that the landowner takes the gain. 
The facts agree with this inference. Neither wages nor interest keep step with material progress. Yet rising rents and land values invariably accompany advancement. Indeed, they are the mark of progress! Increasing rent explains why wages and interest do not increase. The same cause that gives more to the land owner also denies it to the laborer and capitalist. 
..In short, the value of land depends entirely on the power that ownership gives to appropriate the wealth created by labor. Land value always increases at the expense of labor. The reason greater productive power does not increase wages is because it increases the value of land. Rent swallows up the whole gain.
 That is why poverty accompanies progress.
BQEND
So he was stopped. Since they could not refute his arguments, Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers literally bought entire economics departments to corrupt the language to steal the very value of civilisation itself; Oil magnate John. D. Rockefeller created the Chicago school of Poison, Railroad Tycoon Ely Stanford started Stanford university, Banker J.P. Morgan founded Columbia.
In the process of so doing, they emasculated the discipline of economics, stripped dignity from labour and set in motion a planet-wrecking doctrine. Neo-Classical economics aka neoliberalism aka capitalism was born, for the benefit of rent-takers and to the catastrophic detriment of the working-citizen and the living world upon which s/he depends.
References:', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422693000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it increases the value of land', u'effect': u'the reason greater productive power does not increase wages is'}], u'author_id': u'16294933', u'id': u'124224971', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hhmmm', u'text': u'I've been vegetarian since 1979 and haven't flown since 1984.....and look how well things are turning out!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422494000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2770693', u'id': u'124224859', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FallenApple', u'text': u'“It is liberalism’s most dangerous lie that an individual’s action can solve problems of this scale.”
Never knock the little person’s attempts to make a difference with individual life choices to try and limit the damage we do collectively to our planet.
It is only when we start thinking about the little things – such as the food we should buy (how does its production affect the planet?) and the products we buy (do we need to throw-away and replace endlessly?) – that the bigger issues come into focus too.
The people who make the small changes to their lives are likely to be the ones who start pushing for bigger changes by how they vote and which policies they support.
And, in reality, even the policies of government are not going to save our planet from the damage caused by an ever-expanding human population.
Probably the only way (short of nature intervening in some way that decimates the human population that creates the problems) of reducing negative human impact on the planet is by population reduction – and it may just be those individual people that choose to have fewer, or no, children who make the real difference.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422176000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'an ever expanding human population', u'effect': u'the damage'}], u'author_id': u'100522246', u'id': u'124224707', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'And_justice_for_all', u'text': u'Bahahahaha', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422153000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100153683', u'in_reply_to': u'124224140', u'id': u'124224690', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'propertypete79', u'text': u'Yesterday's advert was for a collection of the latest consumer tat you can buy to aid....running.All made in China and bought through Amazon no doubt.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546422087000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16030204', u'id': u'124224652', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Thorlar1', u'text': u'Yes we are labouring under a massive (deliberately created) delusion if we think that what we do as individuals can save the world. But therein lies the genius of NEO-liberalism: the deliberate severing and debasing of social bonds that is the basis of any significant collective action. 
BQSTART
Realistically, the prognosis at the moment is that we won’t manage to steer the ship around in time.
BQEND
Damn right, given that the current fossil fuel industry owners of the ship still expect to dock in New York in spite of just entering the iceberg field. And far from changing course, they continue to order their puppet governments around the world (captain and crew) to increase speed. 
Seriously we don't really understand the degree to which our political systems are in hock to big business and the fossil fuel industry in particular. Thinking that using a few less plastic bags and takeaway coffee cups will save the world is silly but that's nothing to how naive we are to imagine that anything is going to change without a global political revolution in which banking, finance, industry and business are all brought firmly to heal quick smart.
A vote for a conservative, climate-denying, pro-business government in the crucial years remaining to us dooms us all. In other words we will have to have Corbyn, Shorten, Sanders, whatever remains of the Left in Europe and anyone but Putin (all the Russian progressives are in jail or dead) in power at the same time if we are going to have a chance of making this work.
The pro-business conservatives of the world are killing us.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546421809000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14178396', u'id': u'124224499', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rabbiedeoir', u'text': u'From my Blog entry of 27 June 2018 :-"I do not see one in a thousand of us changing his attitudes, or the way he lives his life. Nor do I see our present major political parties denouncing consumerism for what it is: a planetary blight. Climate change is being driven by the consumerism that Capitalists and their governments promote. As a consequence of the harm being done to our planetary home in order to feed the demands of consumerism, I foresee a miserable future for our young as they grow up, one of increasing dearth and want, of ever more frequent, violent conflict for possession or control of ever more scarce natural resources, such as arable land, and water. I foresee the pressure on our own western civilisation reaching breaking point, as entire nations land up on our shores, driven here by the advance of desert and drought in their lands. I foresee the cost of energy rising astronomically, and (so that the rich need suffer no hurt via tax increases), fewer and fewer of us will have access to state, or affordable, healthcare, or state funded old age retirements, or indeed, any sort of material security at all.I foresee tens, then hundreds of thousands of workers rendered forever unemployed, as capitalist corporations turn increasingly to automation to cut production overheads. Only the adoption by the government of a universal living income (ULI) can address the consequences of such an inevitable development. Consumerism has been deeply destructive of our spiritual or inner lives, robbing millions of people of their connection with their spiritual selves, and casting them adrift in an entirely materialist jungle where they fall easy prey to Capitalist predators." (My Blog shares my user name appearing on this site).
Perhaps the UK's Labour party will prove me wrong when I wrote above: "Nor do I see our present major political parties denouncing consumerism for what it is: a planetary blight."Labour's shadow Treasury Secretary, Clive Lewis, said that politicians must persuade consumers to make dramatic lifestyle changes if devastating climate change and mass extinctions are to be averted. From cutting back on red meat to taking fewer flights, the Norwich South MP said the public must face up to “real, stark choices” in the years ahead.“If you want your children and grandchildren to avoid food shortages, to avoid power shortages, to avoid biological degradation, biodiversity loss – if you actually want a planet that’s inhabitable – then we need to make some choices together, now, and some of them are about quite dramatic changes to how we live,” Clive Lewis (the UK's Labour party shadow Treasury Secretary) said in an interview with the Guardian.
I agree with Clive Lewis: “Leadership and punching above your weight doesn’t necessarily always have to mean gunboat diplomacy and bombing other countries into the stone age. It can actually mean leading by example, and helping other countries.”If Britain were to lead in radically transforming our consumer based economy, then other countries may within a few years follow.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546421761000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100124009', u'id': u'124224471', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlexanderGH', u'text': u'Some people would be nervous of uncontrolled immigration when sub-Saharan Africa and southern Europe become uninhabitable.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546421542000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4503360', u'in_reply_to': u'124222246', u'id': u'124224355', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlexanderGH', u'text': u'It doesn't help that environmentalism is associated with the left, when it should be seen as conservative stewardship.Our only environmental party puts a lot of people off with its focus on gender and migration.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546421404000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4503360', u'in_reply_to': u'124222536', u'id': u'124224273', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hemptheworld', u'text': u'Only around 90 or so fossil fuel corporations are producing 75% of alk carbon emissions .The public are getting played like a fiddle.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546421172000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18277923', u'id': u'124224158', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'drprl', u'text': u'BQSTART
And those votes need to be evenly spread across the country - no use having them all piled up in a few constituencies.

description: It is liberalism’s most dangerous lie that an individual’s action can solve problems of this scale
og_fields.og:description: It is liberalism’s most dangerous lie that an individual’s action can solve problems of this scale
og_fields.og:title: One person’s recycling won’t stop climate change in itself. We must act collectively | Emily Mulligan
text:
Climate change is happening now and it’s happening faster and much worse than predicted. It’s threatening to the world we know and everything in it. It’s already killing people. This is beyond doubt or argument.
We have just years to change course. If we manage it, we could save the world, at least the one we recognise. Realistically, the prognosis at the moment is that we won’t manage to steer the ship around in time.
So why have we, as people with everything to lose, not acted sooner?
We have a global climate agreement and we know what needs to happen. This is a problem we know how to solve. But we aren’t acting with anywhere close to the urgency fit for the situation. Renewable energy is cheaper than the bad stuff anyway. Australia is a rich country with the means and the smarts to take on big challenges, so why aren’t we doing it? What will it take to get people to respond in a fitting way?
It’s not surprising that in response to a problem this huge, this existential, people seek out something they can do, from using a keep cup to being fastidious with the recycling. It makes us feel better, it gives us something tangible to do, it stops us from despairing. But we need to admit that even if every plastic bottle and tin can ever produced was recycled, we’d still be on track for catastrophic climate change. No matter how many plastic straws are declined or ocean plastic turned into shoes, every indication points to our children never knowing coral reefs, the Arctic melting and the seas rising.
It is liberalism’s most dangerous lie that an individual’s action can solve problems of this scale.
So what should we be doing?
Stop Adani. Do not let that mine go ahead. My baby who has not figured out that a triangle block goes through the triangle hole could probably figure this one out. We need less pollution in order to keep the world’s ecosystems functional. Digging more new coal to burn is bad maths. We cannot let new coalmines happen. Join a local action group, meet your MP, flick some cash to the people working on this full-time, lock yourself to a bulldozer – this one is really important and there’s a movement set up ready for people to join in and get involved.
More important than any one person’s composting is government policy. Shortly after Australia signed the Paris agreement, Queensland relaxed its land-clearing laws, wiping out any reduction in our pollution that we had committed to in front of the world.
We have a coal-smooching, wilfully ignorant prime minister and a government refusing to take on any climate leadership because it doesn’t fit in with their ideology. Conservatives began the conservation movement, but this current crop of conservative politicians are trying to keep coal plants like Liddell open that even the coal companies want closed. 
Australia does not have an energy policy. This is not due to lack of knowledge or understanding. It’s due to lack of leadership and the influence of people who stand to make a buck now and will probably not be alive to see the worst of catastrophic climate change.
That’s not something you can reason with. They’re simply not up to the job.
So people need to act collectively. The first step is getting involved in this year’s election, when governments are most susceptible to influence. The most important thing we can do is try and influence government decisions. We urgently need to stem the flow of climate pollution into the atmosphere and absorb the pollution already out there on a scale that individuals can’t muster.
When we sort our waste in our homes or remember our reusable shopping bags it’s helpful, but in itself it is not up to the challenge of stopping climate change. If we are going to respond to the problem at the scale and urgency that reality demands, we need to do more. School children going on strike demanding climate action provide a shining example of disruptive, urgent, agenda-setting activism. They acted like their lives depend on it – we all should.
• Emily Mulligan is head of campaigns at GetUp

article_tags: [Canada, Justin Trudeau, World news, Americas, Climate change, Environment]
description: October’s parliamentary elections may hinge on the recent pipeline nationalisation and the government’s carbon tax plan
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: October’s parliamentary elections may hinge on the recent pipeline nationalisation and the government’s carbon tax plan
og_fields.og:title: Trudeau's environmental record on the line in Canada election year
text:
In his four years leading Canada, the Liberal prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has gone to great lengths – at home and abroad – to bolster his environmental credentials. Now, with a federal election looming, he is gambling his parliamentary majority and political future on them.
When Canadians cast their votes next October, they will do so amid standard electoral issues: jobs, the economy and foreign policy. But in a country largely dependent on resource extraction, a pair of politically fractious additions have risen to the top: carbon taxes and pipelines.
“The good news for the prime minister is that when you ask Canadians who they think would make the best prime minister, he still has a comfortable advantage over Conservative leader Andrew Scheer,” said Nik Nanos, a Canadian pollster. “The bad news is that leading up to the next federal election right now, it’s basically a coin toss between the Liberals and Conservatives.”
Canadians have shown an increasing concern for the environment, but in a country largely dependent on resource extraction, the results are often messy.
Earlier in the year, as part of its pan-Canadian climate change strategy, the federal government required all provinces have a minimum level of carbon pricing. For those that fail to do so, the government will implement its own carbon tax, set to begin in July 2019. Already, the levy has fired up Trudeau’s political opponents – at both the provincial and federal level.
But the prime minister had been forced to fend off barbs from critics – including the left-of-centre New Democratic party and Indigenous communities, that any environmental goodwill he might have earned through his carbon tax has been sullied by the support for – and subsequent nationalisation of – an oil pipeline. “The only true test of a climate change plan, after all, is whether carbon is going up or down,” said the NDP leader, Jagmeet Singh, in a statement about his frustrations with the Trans Mountain Pipeline, which runs from Alberta to the British Columbia coast.
The result for Trudeau is a tricky path forward as he heads off attacks that he has done too little on the environment – or too much.
“Trudeau has moved from having an environment that was friendly and pliant to one that is more combative and hostile,” said Nanos, pointing to a string of shifts to Conservative – or right-of-centre – provincial governments across the country since Trudeau was elected in 2015. Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, has repeatedly called carbon pricing “the worst tax ever” and at least five provinces have banded together to fight the tax in the courts, a battle legal experts believe they will lose.
Along with their provincial counterparts, the federal Conservatives have pledged to repeal any carbon taxes, with Scheer dismissing the policy as an “election gimmick”. This fight comes amid reports that Canada is not on pace to meet its 2030 climate goals.
“The opposition or the politicians will convince people that the carbon price is hurting them, even though that’s a lie,” said Mark Jaccard, professor of sustainable energy at Simon Fraser University.
Jaccard, who has also served as a policy analyst, has previously warned respective governments that carbon taxes – while effective at reducing emissions – are politically difficult to sell and often not as effective as other policy options. He points out that the biggest emissions reductions in Canada came from the Ontario government’s closure of coal plants. The recent plan to close all of Canada’s coal plants by 2029 will have a far greater impact than a carbon tax – yet the tax will probably remain at the centre of the discussion.
The tax could end up being particularly appealing from an electoral standpoint, said Nelson Wiseman, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto. All proceeds from the levy will be remitted back to households in the form of a cheque, the first of which will arrive in July – a date Wiseman suspects will be close enough to the election that people will take notice.
But Wiseman, who has studied the country’s elections for generations, cautions: “We’re still a long way off. And things can change on a dime in politics.”

article_tags: [The meat industry, Farming, Greenhouse gas emissions, Climate change, Environment, Food]
description: Exclusive: Green MP will tell Oxford Farming Conference UK must prioritise sustainability
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Exclusive: Green MP will tell Oxford Farming Conference UK must prioritise sustainability
og_fields.og:title: Caroline Lucas urges parliament to 'seriously consider' tax on meat
text:
Parliament must “seriously consider” levying a tax on meat to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help to render the farming industry carbon neutral, the Green party MP, Caroline Lucas, is urging.
She will say on Friday that a meat tax in the UK could be offset for more sustainable meat producers, such as organic livestock farmers, through more money for sustainable agriculture schemes.
Lucas will tell the Oxford Farming Conference, an annual gathering of farmers from across the UK, that the country must prioritise “more humane and human-scale methods of livestock farming, together with support for farmers to transition to less livestock”.
“If the world’s diet doesn’t change, we simply can’t avoid the worst effects of climate change,” Lucas will say, in a stark warning timed to coincide with the push for people to adopt a vegan diet for a month, the “Veganuary” movement.
In a call likely to be controversial, she will say: “Better manure management and careful selection of feed can both help reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but – at the risk of incurring the wrath of the energy secretary, who said recently that encouraging people to eat less meat would be the worst sort of nanny state ever – we need serious consideration of measures like a meat tax.”
She said that it would take “more than motivated consumers to bring about sustainability” in agriculture. Globally, livestock rearing is estimated to be responsible for about 15% of greenhouse gas emissions.
Lucas has tabled a parliamentary motion to require farming to be net zero in emissions as quickly as possible, which would involve ways to reduce fertiliser use and increase the amount of organic matter in the nation’s soils, both issues that Michael Gove, the environment secretary, also espouses.
She said: “We need to bring the whole food chain into the circle of responsibility, not leaving farmers to work on their own, together with clear signals that society will play its part in funding this transition through a new agriculture policy.”
But the notion of Veganuary has come under attack from some at the conference, with the National Sheep Association (NSA) claiming the movement, which encourages people to give up animal products for the month and consider permanent changes to their diet for health and environmental reasons, was part of a “campaign against livestock farming”.
Phil Stocker, chief executive of the NSA, defended British sheep farming as working to improve the environment rather than causing damage to it. “Our concern is that our unique, grass-based method of sheep production in Britain is hidden within more global and general statistics,” he said.
He contrasted the UK’s sheep farming, which includes many upland areas unsuitable for other forms of agriculture and is one of the least intensive forms of livestock farming, with the megafarms and feedlots that characterise beef, pork and poultry production in many parts of the world, chiefly the US but increasingly being brought to the UK.
“We are seeing criticisms from welfare campaigners, rewilders, climate change campaigners and health campaigners – but all these are connected and ignore the fact that UK sheep farming works very much in harmony with our environment, our landscapes and our human ecology, creating a countryside the majority of the public love and producing a food product that is healthy and nutritious within a balanced diet,” he said.
Stocker said he opposed a meat tax: “The right meat, consumed sensibly, should be incentivised and not taxed. Sheep production is not damaging to the environment or to health – sheep mainly eat grass and grass is part of a complex and natural cycling of carbon, with soil storing carbon in organic matter.
“Any meat tax would be likely to affect all meat production and consumption – and there are many different forms of meat production. A meat tax would end up putting further pressure on primary producers – in the case of sheep this would impact on the profitability of many small family farms, yet these are highly desirable and deliver a host of economic, social and environmental goods.”
Earlier Gove told the conference that advances in synthetic biology meant that in the future we would be able to create traditional farming products such as meat, milk or eggs in laboratories, adding that “the potential for Britain to lead in this revolution is huge”.
But asked whether the UK should be looking into increasing its production of “fake meat”, the National Farmers Union president, Minette Batters, said: “When you have one of the very few areas in the world where you have the right climate for producing food, that surely is what you should be doing.”
She added that “95% of what we eat is produced in soil, it’s nutrient dense and that is why it is such a valuable food. Why would you want to be stepping back from that?”

article_tags: [Art and design, Exhibitions, JMW Turner, Photography, Climate change, Environment, UK news, John Ruskin]
description: New images by Emma Stibbon of locations used by Turner and Ruskin highlight the toll taken on Alpine landscape
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: New images by Emma Stibbon of locations used by Turner and Ruskin highlight the toll taken on Alpine landscape
og_fields.og:title: Climate change ravages Turner’s majestic glaciers
text:
A Royal Academician has followed in the footsteps of JMW Turner and John Ruskin to capture in photographs the breathtaking sites in the French Alps that 19th-century artists caught so strikingly. The resulting images reveal a stark depiction of how climate change has taken its toll on the glaciated landscape.
For a forthcoming exhibition on Ruskin and Turner, Emma Stibbon was commissioned to go to Chamonix and record the glaciers around Mont Blanc where, in the early 1800s, Turner painted sublime watercolours that inspired Ruskin to embark on his Alpine tours decades later, photographing and drawing awe-inspiring glaciers such as the Mer de Glace.
In June, the same month in which Ruskin produced his daguerreotypes (early photographs) of the Mer de Glace more than 160 years ago, Stibbon found his viewpoint for her own images, using another early photographic process, cyanotype. While Turner and Ruskin observed the drama of a sea of ice almost at the level they stood, Stibbon looked down into an exposed deep valley with “a dark moraine-covered floor, almost completely devoid of ice”. She saID: “It’s unrecognisable.”
Her commission forms part of the Ruskin, Turner & the Storm Cloud, exhibition opening at the York Art Gallery in March and Abbot Hall, Kendal, in July. It is part of a worldwide programme of exhibitions, conferences and publications to mark the 200th birthday of Ruskin, a writer, artist and social reformer whose achievements are sometimes eclipsed by scandals, including his ill-fated, unconsummated marriage to Effie Gray and a libel action brought by painter James McNeill Whistler. “When we think of the Alps,” said Stibbon, “we think of iconic white peaks. By the end of this century, there probably won’t be any snow.”
She added that Ruskin was ahead of his time in realising “the Industrial Revolution was affecting air quality and that air pollution was linked to the use of coal. He could see that glaciers move and I think he suspected that there was some [ice] recession, which would have been starting around that period in the 1850s.”
Suzanne Fagence Cooper, research curator at York Art Gallery and author of a new book, To See Clearly: Why Ruskin Matters, said Stibbon’s images show the glacier retreat “very clearly”, and capture a “sense of real loss”.
While Ruskin events extend to Japan and America, in the UK there is a cinema screening, from 22 February, of Effie Gray – the 2014 film written by Emma Thompson – and the exhibition, John Ruskin: The Power of Seeing, from 26 January at Two Temple Place, London. It features more than 190 exhibits revealing how Ruskin’s influence is still felt.
Robert Hewison, author of the recently published Ruskin and His Contemporaries, said: “Ruskin was, by the end of his life, treated as a kind of prophet – although not in his own country – for predicting both economic and ecological deterioration. Climate change appears to show that he was right.”

From security to economy, insurance to relocation, election fallout to party agenda, overreacting and under reacting, there is a lot to the equation.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773688000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12177770', u'id': u'124320428', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'hflashman', u'text': u'I agree with the poster above, it seems to be more tied into the current divide in American politics & the debates about guns & abortion- it taps into a lot of peoples' knee-jerk prejudices.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773673000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4259440', u'in_reply_to': u'124319761', u'id': u'124320410', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'The nonsense fallacy that we can't support the population in a sustainable way is a bubble that needs bursting.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773554000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18522661', u'in_reply_to': u'124316421', u'id': u'124320335', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART
Nuclear generation is only fairly clean if you only look at the power station. If you include the whole process, from mine to Windscale, then it is anything but clean. For example, they still have tanks full of highly radioactive waste to deal with.
BQEND
The Windscale piles were primitive reactors built and operated for the sole purpose of producing weapons grade plutonium. They had nothing to do with nuclear power. The first pile was operational in 1950. That's almost 70 years ago. What's relevant is nuclear power today.
As for the Sellafield pools, they are also very much legacy engineering and technology that will never be used again. The spent fuel pools associated with light water power reactors are absolutely nothing like the Sellafield pools. The radioactive materials are locked away in the fuel rods NOT dissolved in the water or lying in a radioactive sludge on the bottom. You could safely dip your legs into the water in SFPs on swim on the surface. The water is clean. 
Having said that, even in a legacy engineering context, the waste in the Sellafield pools is isolated from the environment in complete contrast to gas combustion that just dumps the waste into the atmosphere. The Sellafield pools obviously must be dealt with, and there are engineering challenges, but they are not actually harming humans or the broader environment. Even Generation I nuclear power was much better than fossil fuels.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773501000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'124318799', u'id': u'124320304', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'That's because minsters are silly and influenced by lobby groups. I know we have massive recycling way of lives in regards to our own refuse, catalytic convertors, emissions tests, massive increases in solar and other renewables and yet, we also have had a massive increase in charities and researchers telling us we are all baddies in the U.K. when the facts prove we are not', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773273000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100501142', u'in_reply_to': u'124317508', u'id': u'124320156', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PeterPanther', u'text': u'So the real solution would be more housing in the city where you work ( the more there is , the cheaper it will be) Or bringing your work to where you live.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773254000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4236634', u'in_reply_to': u'124316140', u'id': u'124320138', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'william', u'text': u'BQSTART
Will we still be able to travel so much?
BQEND
Just as much, just not as far or so quickly
BQSTART
Will we still be able to buy such a variety of things?
BQEND
Probably not, but we may have a lot variety provided we eat things when they are in season near where we live. 
BQSTART
Will we still be able to heat our homes?
BQEND
In the interests of the environment and your wallet, putting on a jumper or a warmer pair of socks is always preferable to turning up the heating a notch.
BQSTART
Will our consumer economy/society still work, if so how?
BQEND
Yes, without Question, more products will be produced locally and this will provide more employment locally. It's a virtuous cycle.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773246000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'243884', u'in_reply_to': u'124315717', u'id': u'124320134', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mmurray57', u'text': u'In Australia what makes it difficult for the government to replace our ageing fleet of coal electrical generators with more of the same is the horrible free market. Nobody wants to invest in coal anymore. The market can see the future even when our politicians are mad.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773245000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2692943', u'in_reply_to': u'124318793', u'id': u'124320132', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dave6723', u'text': u'BQSTART
Clearly there are arguments on both sides
BQEND
Clearly there aren't. there is evidence on one side, and unsubstantiated rhetoric on the other.

BQSTART
but surely it is better not to take a chance on a runaway greenhouse effect
BQEND
We can stop a long way short of a runaway greenhouse and still wreck civilisation and kill millions.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773197000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18522661', u'in_reply_to': u'124316703', u'id': u'124320095', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bassireland', u'text': u'BQSTART
Clearly there are arguments on both sides ...
BQEND
This is a false equivalence: there are not equal or even approximately equal evidence-based arguments « on both sides ». Indeed there aren’t even « both sides »: this is not a debating society. There is a huge body of scientific knowledge, based on very solid foundations in some areas - the role of CO2 and other greenhouse gases, the global impact of higher temperatures for example - and less certain in others - how quickly Antarctic ice sheets may destabilise and melt. Portraying it as an endless soccer match in which each « side » scores debating points through gross oversimplification is part of the problem.
BQSTART
... but surely it is better not to take a chance on a runaway greenhouse effect if the possibility is there. In any event, fossil fuels are finite, so the shift will need to be made at some time, so why not sooner rather than later, and clean the air at the same time
BQEND
Agreed. But please don’t fall for the debating society mis-characterisation.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546773078000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2849622', u'in_reply_to': u'124316703', u'id': u'124320008', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'paulmarkj', u'text': u'Science doesn't work like that.

But then you see how ICE sales are dropping all over the UK, Europe and the US (although big auto there tells us that people are just buying more SUV/pickups instead of sedans).Diesel has lost a lot of it's shine, governments are committing to only EV sales by 2030/40. So it's quite possible that a large % of potential buyers are thinking to hang on until EV becomes more affordable.
This may come as a surprise, but the study projects a cross-over of ICE sales, EV sales and oil production in around 5 years time! Still a lot of ICE sales but the graph was clearly dropping. When you consider that ICE consumes a large % of oil production, it makes sense that oil will drop to.

Money is more a problem than a solution here. Maybe we need to think differently on how to "finance" sustainability. 
The grip of money over politics is exactly what needs to change.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1546771228000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14400611', u'in_reply_to': u'124316223', u'id': u'124318793', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'morrisseysmiff', u'text': u'Sorry. Here is more
It is no coincidence, suggests Klein, that several environmental organisations have also championed climate policies that are the least burdensome to the energy industry, including generously designed carbon markets and the use of natural gas as a bridge to a cleaner energy system.
