No government implementing it would be re-elected.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548702146000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15736907', u'in_reply_to': u'125169037', u'id': u'125190816', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'lovedoves', u'text': u'Einstein said We cannot solve our problems with the same thinking we used when we created them.the idea that capitlaism is so successful when in 50 or so post war years it has brought the world to the edge of destruction- what kind of success is that? myopic, short lived. capitlaism wont get us out of this mess, we need new ways of thinking', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548702090000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10481206', u'in_reply_to': u'125188831', u'id': u'125190760', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'honeytree', u'text': u'Confused now. I was responding to a remark about climate change circa 1800 years ago and how I'd have thought our "understanding" of that change can only be speculation without much in the way of detail (like temperatures, for example). 
Now you've introduced 1750 (I think you mean the year 1750 as a pre-industrial starting point?) Our understanding of climate in 1750 is likely to be much better than 200 AD. 
Our best understanding of the changes that industrialisation has brought certainly matters (not least to demonstrate that current climate change is man-made and therefore potentially fixable). Our understanding of climate change circa 200 AD less so, I'd have thought.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548702074000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15217954', u'in_reply_to': u'125190196', u'id': u'125190747', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'joneslj', u'text': u'If we want to survive, we must look at the costs that aren't on the balance sheets. The natural world recycles almost everything. The rest gets turned into limestone and oil. The oil came from a massive extinction event, so it probably doesn't count. Anything we don't recycle or reuse in someway is an environment cost . We live under the delusion that it's business as usual and that we can live without the environment. GMO's and even farmer's selective breeding is evolution for profit. The more we go down that road, the more we will have to go down that road to survive. For example we better start Genetically modifying plankton to help it adapt to climate change, or genetically modify our species to breath less oxygen, as it's been reported that plankton is dying. The human race as we know it will probably disappear. Personally, I'm for a recycled economy that takes as little as possible from the natural world. That and too get our population down to a billion people in a civilized voluntary manner. Now, how do we make that profitable?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701777000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3958771', u'id': u'125190504', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PerAudra', u'text': u'A lot of us, myself included, share your frustration with the current state of our political parties. You could of course join one and try to change things.
An alternative would be to join a group of like minded people and work for change. The thing I like about such groups is that they come in many different styles and sizes. Some are very big. Some could hardly be smaller. Personally, I like working with a small group but that is just my own preference. 
Here are few groups to consider. There are lots of others.
https://www.foe.co.uk/ 
https://www.greenpeace.org.uk/
https://joyinenough.org/ 
https://makewealthhistory.org/
http://arocha.org.uk/.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701638000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16618710', u'in_reply_to': u'125165111', u'id': u'125190391', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MaxDrei', u'text': u'When people realise it is caused by humans, you write. Even then, there is nothing to be done. A great many people would already accept that humans are to blame but then they shrug their shoulders and aver that it is futile to suppose that anything effective can be done now, to reduce the rate of climate change, stop it or reverse it. 
The corporations are reacting rationally to this reality, by going with the flow, and making the best of it.
Arwa, don't forget the "military industrial complex". There are huge pots of money to be pocketed by the complex when the E-W sea passage north of Russia becomes navigable. Bring it on, they cry. They are working on it already.
How about the "little people"? What can they do? One might think that the only sensible course is to buy shares in those companies who have the best business plans to make money out of human-induced climate change. It's every man for himself, these days, and no lifeboats on Plant Earth's ship of fools.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701577000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'humans', u'effect': u'it'}], u'author_id': u'2495368', u'in_reply_to': u'125161877', u'id': u'125190343', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'michaelmichael', u'text': u'unfortunately that's not how it works. Corporations will always seek the quick return option and most of the time these choices will be bad ones for the climate and our survival. What the author also does not seem to have grasped is that the conventional economy will tank and in its place will come a very nasty form of capitalism indeed', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11130177', u'in_reply_to': u'125186742', u'id': u'125190254', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'BQSTART
To be honest what happened climactically 1800 years ago is of little interest. Climate change is happening now and we need to address it.
BQEND
The rhetoric is based upon pre-industrial temperature defined by the IPCC as 1750. The problem is that the changes from GHG are not instantaneous and the 200 year +/- on the current equilibrium temperature could well be as much as 4C above where we estimate.
What matters is stopping emissions immediately but without the past record some people start to think 500ppm CO2 or even 560ppm CO2 is not insane to deliberately allow. 
politically the 1800 figure matters greatly but will never be truly resolved.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701396000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'125187779', u'id': u'125190196', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'honeytree', u'text': u'BQSTART
Economics adjusted to correctly value ecosystems (because they are fundamental to our survival in the long term) could work, but time is now very short for this sort of radical change.
BQEND
That kind of "adjustment" cannot be imposed from outside. Capitalism needs our survival, it needs markets, it needs people to exploit. It will value ecosystems (and governments don't seem to that much) when it becomes apparent that their maintenance is vital to protect markets/profits.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701282000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15217954', u'in_reply_to': u'125189542', u'id': u'125190104', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Regarding hurricanes and global warming.
For every foot of global mean sea level rise the shoreline moves on average 300 feet inland. It's much worse in places like South Florida and Bangladesh.
The extra foot of sea level rise on the East Coast caused Hurricane Sandy to flood an extra 25 square miles.
And that was just one factor in Sandy's flooding. The warmer ocean waters meant that Sandy retained more strength crossing the N Atlantic, so its storm surge was higher.
Changes to the jet stream likely due to Arctic ice decline caused Sandy to follow an unusual and unusually damaging track which was straight into land which made the storm surge higher.
And more rain fell from a moister atmosphere.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701245000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the extra foot of sea level rise on the east coast', u'effect': u'hurricane sandy to flood an extra 25 square miles'}, {u'cause': u'changes to the jet stream likely due to arctic ice decline', u'effect': u'sandy to follow an unusual and unusually damaging track which was straight into land which made the storm surge higher'}, {u'cause': u'arctic ice decline', u'effect': u'changes to the jet stream'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'125188484', u'id': u'125190070', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Logicomix', u'text': u'Sorry, let me rephrase - it appears you perceive my question as challenging your perspective, whereas I am 'literally' asking why you appear to think that Direct Democracy in our future is a given.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548867005000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4327078', u'in_reply_to': u'125185416', u'id': u'125299579', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'It represents employment but not really private sector business. If you are having to retrofit 25 million homes you don't do it using companies set up to do perhaps 1000 homes and make a profit. 
Similarly with energy the current pro rata cost for the UK under government plans would be approx. 8x higher than a direct purchase would cost. This then reaches perhaps £10tn which there might not be the funds for.
There are many economic advantages to the necessary action but most of this will be indirect as opposed for business', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701199000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10230223', u'in_reply_to': u'125189106', u'id': u'125190037', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BaddHamster', u'text': u'Trade with the land people? Never! I shall train an army of cats to ride seagulls and take what I want.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701132000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4548062', u'in_reply_to': u'125189698', u'id': u'125189984', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'461795', u'text': u'BQSTART
You tell me how people are supposed to 'adapt' to an increase in famine and starvation
BQEND
Foreign aid? Food programmes? Better governance? Economic liberalisation? Tariff-free trade? Amend any restrictive laws discouraging or preventing internal migration? Maybe even greater redistribution of wealth, if you're that way inclined?
You lot really do give up very easily. It's almost as if you want bad things to happen, just to validate your own doom-laden fantasies and needy sense of chronocentrism.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548859749000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100784632', u'in_reply_to': u'125220184', u'id': u'125293121', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'In the heatwave of 1976, the UK was virtually the only place experiencing unusual temperatures.
In 2018, similar conditions happened in a great many places.
Another example - extreme rainfall events are increasing globally.
Heavy rainfall events, setting new records, have been increasing in the past thirty years.
All weather events now take place within a set of earth systems that are different to those of, say, 100 years ago. 
Climate change has produced a new framework for weather.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548701070000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125188484', u'id': u'125189944', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'madmusician', u'text': u'It's very hard managing companies by regulation. Political regulation is a blunt tool, with lots of unintended consequences. What is needed is a national discussion about what ideas there are for decarbonising our energy production and use, and then a strong government policy to make it happen. In the end, if we are to generate more and more electricity to run electric cars, the only long-term non-polluting source of energy we have is the sun. And the nearest place to here that is REALLY sunny is N Africa. Large-scale solar power generated in N Africa would cost less than the electricity from a nuclear power station. And don't tell me it would be politically difficult, when we get our gas from the istans, via the Ukraine, from fields that have less than 30 years life left, and oil from equally politically "difficult" countries. It has been shown that 3% of the Sahara desert would collect enough sunlight to generate ALL the power being used in Europe at present - electricity, transport, industry - the lot. And no new or dangerous technology would be needed to produce the electricity. It is possible, and indeed desireable, and we'd be happier (or at least just as happy) but you are quite right that we don't really know how it would work.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700763000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'125183487', u'id': u'125189684', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'vacantspace', u'text': u'Population growth together with growing expectations of a better (consuming) life is, as you say, the problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548787336000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18075998', u'in_reply_to': u'125200534', u'id': u'125238673', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xwookey', u'text': u'Capitalism _could_ be not-evil, but current neo-classical economics simply ignores ecosystems as an externality, or at best values them as an equivalent amount of money, so it's OK to build over the last ever site of some creature because the house you put there has higher monetary value. This is a false equivalence, and is leading us to disaster. Economics adjusted to correctly value ecosystems (because they are fundamental to our survival in the long term) could work, but time is now very short for this sort of radical change.
It's more than just checks and balances - the natural world needs a proper value like labour and capital, and one that is not simply exchangeable for some other value, because that fails to preserve things that are essential.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700595000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the house you put there has higher monetary value', u'effect': u"it 's ok to build over the last ever site of some creature"}, {u'cause': u'that fails to preserve things that are essential', u'effect': u'that is not simply exchangeable for some other value'}], u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'125185619', u'id': u'125189542', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matthew2012', u'text': u'BQSTART

Just for clarity you were the OP in this thread. 
For starters, you can adapt your journey to a museum if the train is cancelled but not if the museum is burnt down. 
In this case, your modern way of life and the economic precepts which these large corporations are founded just simply cannot exist in the conditions that are forecast from the minimum consequences of the climate change of the ppm where we are headed.
It is too big an issue to go into in detail and there are even extinction level event scenarios to cover but instead I will stick to the basics of where we are at now in the short-term:
Ocean dead zones:https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/44677/aquatic-dead-zones
These are growing and thing people only really discuss as relates past mass extinctions.
Ocean ecosystem collapse:
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jul/07/australias-vast-kelp-forests-devastated-by-marine-heatwave-study-reveals
https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jun/21/coral-bleaching-event-now-biggest-in-history-and-about-to-get-worse
While the knock on effects to humans in cities is slow, it nonetheless represents a clear stressor upon all land ecosystems and things like cod once estimated the most abundant marine biomass by animal could risk vanishing.
From 400ppm we'd expect an eventual 20m sea level rise:
and the Geological record is grim:
BQSTART
"Atmospheric CO2 is currently just below 400 parts per million (ppm) on average. It last reached similar levels during the Pliocene (5.3-2.6 million years ago). At that time, temperatures rose to levels 2-3°C warmer than today, and sea level rose by up to 20m in places. Sea level takes a few hundred years to reach equilibrium in response to changes in atmospheric CO2 and temperature, which may explain why sea level has not yet risen to the same levels seen in the Pliocene. "
BQEND

https://www.geolsoc.org.uk/~/media/shared/documents/policy/Climate%20Change%20Statement%20Addendum%202013%20Final.pdf
and

BQSTART
"Recent estimates suggest CO2 levels reached as much as 415 parts per million (ppm) during the Pliocene. With that came global average temperatures that eventually reached 3 or 4 degrees C (5.4-7.2 degrees F) higher than today’s and as much as 10 degrees C (18 degrees F) warmer at the poles. Sea level ranged between five and 40 meters (16 to 131 feet) higher than today."
BQEND

https://scripps.ucsd.edu/programs/keelingcurve/2013/12/03/what-does-400-ppm-look-like/
This doesn't mean only places less than 20m above sea level are affected. Much of this will be form of flooding and soil degredation. Coupled with drought you'll see impacts on crop supply. 
For the amazon:"Future fire activity will also depend on anthropogenic factors especially related to land use change. For the Amazon it is estimated that at present 58% of the area is too humid to allow deforestation fires but climate change might reduce this area to 37% by 2050 (Le Page et al., 2010). Golding and Betts (2008) estimated that future Amazon forest vulnerability to fire may depend non-linearly on combined climate change and deforestation."
We have seen 30C above average anomalies in the Arctic:https://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/arctic-temperatures-warmth-1.3910765
We have been talking at between 1C and 1.5C anomaly here and some of the projections are above 10C and this is not a normal distribution of risk:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Frequency_distribution_of_climate_sensitivity,_based_on_model_simulations_(NASA).png

Whatever they are I can pretty much guarantee that money has "improved" them unrecognisably from their early origins.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700334000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15217954', u'in_reply_to': u'125188325', u'id': u'125189328', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'There's quite a lot known about volcanic effects on climate.
The end-Permian mass extinction is associated with lots of CO2 being formed by burning fossil fuel.
It was volcanic action that burned coal then, in Siberia.
There are a number of papers on that such as:
"Initial pulse of Siberian Traps sills as the trigger of the end-Permian mass extinction" - Burgess et al, 2017
There's also
"Catastrophic dispersion of coal fly ash into oceans during the latest Permian extinction" - Grasby et al, 2011.
It's not a precedent we want to emulate.
There's an interesting paper on the potential effects of future volcanic eruptions:
"Potential volcanic impacts on future climate variability" - Bethke et al, 2017
This research shows that strong volcanic eruptions would produce short periods of cooling; these would generally be followed by periods of accelerated warming, as the effects of the volcanic emissions subside, and the effects of CO2 emissions catch up.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700311000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125188859', u'id': u'125189309', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'I bet Russia would gladly invite tens of millions from Africa to move into Siberia ......', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548782024000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125214144', u'id': u'125234343', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'"Honda reckons its generators may empower its consumers when the world’s infrastructure crumbles."

I won't argue that noone thinks like that. In fact I once heard a senior exec of a famous multinational criticise his own staff for being too humanitarian in helping out after the Japan tsunami. But your overall point that corporates will be happier in a scarcity environment is wrong. Most companies sell to the mass market and so they don't want scarcity or a collapsing economy. They don't want climate disaster and would much prefer a stable trading environment. That makes them broadly change-resistant, and especially if they are in dinosaur sectors. If some are looking ahead to how they might make profits in a changed world that is actually better than denialism. For example, retrofitting nearly every house in the UK represents a huge amount of business and employment (never mind the rest of the world), and there are hundreds of others. The trick is directing this activity into things that actually help and not the hundreds of pointless high-carbon things people currently do which are just making the problem worse (journalists and youtubers cross-crossing the planet to film things, politicians and academics doing the same to talk to each other, epic amounts of even more pointless holidaying in far-flung places, band tours, all sorts of gratuitous consumerism in short-lived tat, and so on).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700087000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4307215', u'in_reply_to': u'125185257', u'id': u'125189106', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aethelfrith', u'text': u'Didnt finish ......meant to say 
Now Katla is a huge volcano compared to Eyjafjallajökull.....
Katla (Icelandic pronunciation: [ˈkʰahtla] (About this soundlisten)) is a large volcano in southern Iceland. It is very active; twenty eruptions have been documented between 930 and 1918, at intervals of 20–90 years. It has not erupted violently for 101 years, although there may have been small eruptions that did not break the ice cover, including ones in 1955,[1] 1999,[2] and 2011.[3]
Prior eruptions have had a Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEI) of between 4 and 6 on a scale of 0 to 8. In comparison, the Eyjafjallajökull 2010 eruption had a VEI-4. The bigger VEI-6 eruptions are comparable to Mount Pinatubo's 1991 eruption.
Katla is one of the largest volcanic sources of carbon-dioxide (CO2) on Earth, accounting for up to 4% of total global volcanic carbon-dioxide emissions.
When Katla blows , it will change things pretty much immediately.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548700018000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12705323', u'in_reply_to': u'125188859', u'id': u'125189045', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SenseBeautiful', u'text': u'No there isn't and hasn't been any safe method of nuclear waste disposal.All methods have failed so far because there is no such thing as a closed system.That's science for you.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548777125000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'there is no such thing as a closed system', u'effect': u'all methods have failed so far'}], u'author_id': u'101184959', u'in_reply_to': u'125228322', u'id': u'125229781', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SenseBeautiful', u'text': u'my definition? It's a difficult question.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548746321000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3447366', u'in_reply_to': u'125194201', u'id': u'125204395', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Usignolo', u'text': u'But by admitting it needs checks and balances you also admit that markets aren't the way to organise things. "As of 15 April, the eruption was not large enough to have an effect on global temperatures like that of Mount Pinatubo and other major past volcanic eruptions.[88][89] One previous related sequence of eruptions of this volcano, beginning in 1821 is recorded as having lasted for over two years, but no single set of major eruptions is known to have lasted more than 'several days'. Should the eruption continue for a sufficient length of time at its current intensity, the potential remains for a temporary global cooling effect. By analogy, the Laki eruption has been linked with extreme weather events from severe hailstorms in Great Britain to the Mississippi River freezing at New Orleans.[90][91] Sulfate aerosols that reach the stratosphere catalyse the production of chlorine monoxide (ClO), which destroys ozone (O3). In the upper troposphere, the same aerosols become nuclei for cirrus clouds, which increase the Earth's albedo, thus altering its radiation balance.[92] Several eruptions during the past century have caused a decline in the average temperature at the Earth's surface of up to half a degree Celsius for periods of one to three years"

Increasing CO2 concentration from about 280 ppm to around 410 ppm in a couple of centuries is a huge change and is the dominant factor right now.
CO2 was last over 400 ppm in the Pliocene, several million years ago.
Global average temperatures then eventually reached 3 or 4 degrees C (5.4-7.2 degrees F) higher than today’s and as much as 10 degrees C (18 degrees F) warmer at the poles.
Sea level ranged between five and 40 metres (16 to 131 feet) higher than today.
Earth systems take time to respond to forcings.
Sea level can't suddenly rise on that scale, because it takes time for enough heat to be accumulated to melt enough ice.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548742632000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it takes time for enough heat to be accumulated to melt enough ice', u'effect': u"sea level ca n't suddenly rise on that scale"}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'125198946', u'id': u'125203773', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ValResnick', u'text': u'And Cuba and Romania and North Korea...?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548714422000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101241871', u'in_reply_to': u'125168370', u'id': u'125198274', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Usignolo', u'text': u'What, you mean sort of "let them drink brine" ?', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548699782000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3447366', u'in_reply_to': u'125186230', u'id': u'125188841', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glasshalffull2', u'text': u'Oh good grief, what a myopic article and displaying a real lack of understanding - I want companies to make money from climate change - that's why capitalism is so successful. Typical that it would be a guardian pick though.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548699533000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"just they 're not popular in our anachronistic political system", u'effect': u"does n't mean that the arguments are not compelling"}], u'author_id': u'14435386', u'in_reply_to': u'125165111', u'id': u'125188628', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KarlosP', u'text': u'I completely agree it would be better if 'the rich' set an example, whether you mean the top 1%, 0.1%, 0.01% or whatever. But this is a global problem, and it can only be solved globally - the whole world. And it's not really about 'rich' - generally speaking, the richer you are, the greater your carbon footprint, true, but we need to target carbon, not income or wealth. 
Some conspicuous spending is highly costly in carbon terms, some isn't; likewise an economy flight isn't seen as a luxury, but is hugely costly in carbon terms. Aviation is an interesting example: 11 billion gallons of jet fuel were consumed by US airlines last year, but private and corporate jets registered in the US consumed just 1 million gallons. Now of course per person private flying is hugely more costly in carbon terms, but it accounts for one ten thousandth of fuel consumed, so it really makes no difference - the planet doesn't care about 1 million, it cares about 11 billion.
So, irrespective of what 'the rich' do, however you define them, we should all make a difference. If we say the rich have to set an example before we'll act, we're basically saying we're allowing ourselves to be controlled by the actions of an elite group that we have to follow and we can't think for ourselves. And lots of 'the rich' may be reining in their carbon footprints, but are we saying that so long as we see a few (say 1,500 out of a population of 8 billion) flying private jets that we should carry on driving our 3 litre 2 ton cars to the shops instead of riding a bike?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548768868000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100140705', u'in_reply_to': u'125215265', u'id': u'125222287', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OverHillAndDale', u'text': u'What an elaborate evasion tactic!

Using satellite measurements, this analysis directly quantifies how much the Arctic as viewed from space has darkened in response to the recent sea ice retreat. We find that this decline has caused 6.4 ± 0.9 W/m2 of radiative heating since 1979, considerably larger than expectations from models and recent less direct estimates. Averaged globally, this albedo change is equivalent to 25% of the direct forcing from CO2 during the past 30 y.
BQEND
As the other half of the surface area of Arctic sea ice largely goes away over the next several decades that already powerful amplifying feedback will increase substantially.

The orbital cycles operating on timescales of tens to hundreds of thousands of years were very weak climate forcings which nonetheless caused ancient climate oscillations to be huge due to amplifying feedbacks of ice melt and release of CO2 and methane from warming polar regions.

Moreover, the business world is littered with potentially beneficial innovations whose patents have been bought and shelved by companies whose sales would have been damaged by the innovation.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548765348000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'emergencies'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'more sales of their product'}], u'author_id': u'12231106', u'in_reply_to': u'125164457', u'id': u'125218641', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DoctorWibble', u'text': u'The question was set in a much longer environmental impact survey. It asked what the respondents felt might be the "risks and opportunities faced by their business as a result of climate change".
The people dumped with the job of filling out things like this are, you know, human and often quite junior. They are unlikely to leave the section blank much less offer the honest answer "I dunno, we haven't thought about that." So they do what we all would do. And what any senior manager likely advised them to do if asked. Make something up that sounds plausible.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548765293000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16498253', u'id': u'125218580', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'I know the article is tongue in cheek, and this subject could use some humor. But what it really needs is exposure. Please Guardian, I feel your coverage lately on this subject has been slipping.
And this is really the most important challenge you are covering because we've already seen conflicts and migration linked to drought with the little bit of warming to date in places like Africa.
In 2018 the Guardian reported that farmers around the Bay of Bengal were driven by drought to fish the Bay and now fisheries there are collapsing and the migration from a population of hundreds of millions is beginning.
When climatic zones and rains cross borders now there will be people with guns on the other side who may not like those being forced to move. I believe India and perhaps one more country are now building walls to contain the population of Bangladesh which resides on the sinking Ganges River Delta. 
And half a billion people live on sinking river deltas while the protective deltas are eroding, sea level is rising, and maximum storm strength may be increasing.
We have to keep our greatest challenge front and center.

description: A new report reveals how Apple, among others, is already exploring the business possibilities that will come from the environmental crisis. Something to be cheerful about as the ice melts …
og_fields.og:description: A new report reveals how Apple, among others, is already exploring the business possibilities that will come from the environmental crisis. Something to be cheerful about as the ice melts …
og_fields.og:title: Looking on the bright side of climate change, think of all the money corporations can make | Arwa Mahdawi
text:
You know what I love about capitalism? Its optimism. Even in the direst of circumstances, it is always able to find a silver lining.
Take climate change, for example. After weird weather and ominous warnings of more to come, many of us are freaking out about an environmental apocalypse. Indeed, a new poll shows record numbers of Americans are worried about climate change and, after last year’s heatwave, concerns about the issue have soared in Britain.
Now, it seems that big companies are equally worried about global warming, but they are thinking about the future with cool heads. Rather than being consumed by doom and gloom, or considering the idea that we should curb consumerism, corporations have realised climate change is an exciting business opportunity. You can see evidence of this in recent disclosures to CDP, a UK-based environmental reporting NGO that surveys companies on the “risks and opportunities” they face because of changing weather patterns. The 2018 disclosures, reported by Bloomberg last week, provide a fascinating insight into how some of the world’s largest corporations are, as Bloomberg puts it in a headline, “Getting Ready to Monetize Climate Change”.
Let’s start with the pharmaceutical industry, which is particularly well placed to profit from our dystopian future. As Merck notes in its disclosure to CDP, climate change may lead to “expanded markets for products for tropical and weather-related diseases including water-borne illness”. AbbVie sees similar opportunities, saying that its “immunology product line could see an increase in sales” as a result of more extreme conditions. And Eli Lilly, another large pharmaceutical company, cites research showing climate change may increase the risk of diabetes by “curtailing physical activity, disrupting traditional food supplies, and increasing food insecurity”. While that is sad and all, the upside for Eli Lilly is a potential increase in demand for its diabetes products.
It’s not just big pharma that sees dollar symbols in disaster. Honda reckons its generators may empower its consumers when the world’s infrastructure crumbles. The company notes that “the Katrina disaster was followed by a 27% increase in unit sales of [Honda] generators”. Meanwhile, the Home Depot is optimistic that, at the very least, it will sell more ceiling fans “should temperatures increase over time”.
The tech industry, as one would expect, is taking an innovative view of how an apocalypse may affect the bottom line. Apple thinks that “as people begin to experience severe weather events with greater frequency” they will become increasingly glued to their mobile phones. It notes that, as well as helping you check in with your loved ones, your iPhone can “serve as a flashlight”. Which takes the idea of seeing the bright side of a bad situation to a whole new level.
Apple also says that, if disaster strikes, you can charge your mobile device using “hand cranks”. Few people do that at the moment, but don’t be surprised if you see iCranks, Armageddon-proof iPhone chargers, hitting a store near you soon. All in all, Apple says that if it is “successful in creating products attractive to people whose purchasing habits are changing due to concerns about climate change” it could raise annual net sales by $2.3bn (£1.75bn). That’s something to be cheerful about as the ice melts, eh?
Anyway, while there are plenty more examples of corporate climate-change optimism, let’s skip to the moral of this story, which is that, when it comes to global warming, we should all be acting more like multinationals. Rather than worrying about the planet being destroyed, why not ask yourself how you can best monetise the rest of your time on Earth? Invest in big pharma. Get a hand crank. And don’t lose sleep over deforestation – after all, money doesn’t grow on trees.

headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Store to sell pasta and granola bars made from ground buffalo worm and cricket flour
og_fields.og:title: Insects worm their way into Selfridges food hall in ‘bug bars’
text:
Pasta, protein bars and granola bars made from insect flour are to go on sale in Selfridges to highlight alternative proteins for inclusion in mainstream diets.
Amid growing awareness of the environmental impact of livestock farming – and the benefits of reducing meat consumption – the British department store is the latest retailer to tap into the rising recognition of the benefits of eating insects on both nutritional and environmental grounds.
Basil fusilli pasta and raspberry and pumpkin seed granola – made from flour from ground buffalo worms – will go on sale in Selfridges’ food halls this week, along with dark chocolate and fig protein bars made with cricket flour.
The products have been developed by the specialist French brand Jimini’s, which sells through Spanish and German supermarkets and is aiming to expand its presence in the UK. The new products are exclusive to Selfridges.
Environmental experts have long recommended insects as a sustainable food source that could help end world hunger and reduce the damaging impact of meat production. Insects are also nutritious, containing essential proteins, fats, minerals and amino acids.
A regular portion of buckwheat pasta usually contains about 10g of protein, whereas Jimini’s insect fusilli contains 18g. Jimini’s cereal bars contain 20% protein and granola 14% – both products are blended with a selection of fruit and nuts for variety of texture. The products will be promoted in Selfridges initially in themed, pop-up “bug bars” but may remain on sale permanently.
Edward Goodman, the food buying director of Selfridges, said: “We are sure our epicurious customers will be surprised and delighted discovering the new range in store.”
In the UK, food choices are becoming increasingly important in the debate about how to counter climate change, reflected in the rise of “flexitarianism” whereby a largely vegetable-based diet is supplemented occasionally with meat.
In November, Sainsbury’s became the first major UK grocer to stock edible crickets – selling the roasted insects as snacks in small bags from the UK brand Eat Grub in 250 of its stores.
“Having sold over 10,000 packs of Eat Grub crickets in less than three months, we’re continuing to see Sainsbury’s customers explore edible insects as a new sustainable protein source,” said Katherine O’Sullivan, Sainsbury’s buying manager. “We’re always looking to provide our customers with new and exciting products such as these.”
The global edible insect market is forecast to exceed $520m (£395m) by 2023, according to recent research. The UN Food and Agriculture Organization said at least 2 billion people regularly consume insects and they could help meet the food needs of the world’s growing population.
More than 1,000 insect species are eaten around the world but they hardly feature in the diets of many rich nations. In the UK, crickets and other insects have so far been predominantly limited to quirky pop-ups or sales through online outlets and feature on a few restaurant menus.

description: Letters: Farmers should be incentivised to switch to nature-friendly farming techniques, writes Graeme Willis of the Campaign to Protect Rural England. Meanwhile Melvyn Rust says people should be persuaded to have slightly fewer children
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Farmers should be incentivised to switch to nature-friendly farming techniques, writes Graeme Willis of the Campaign to Protect Rural England. Meanwhile Melvyn Rust says people should be persuaded to have slightly fewer children
og_fields.og:title: The need for better soil, and fewer people | Letters
text:
Your article (Can we feed the world if we ditch intensive farming?, The Briefing, Journal, 28 January) highlights the hugely detrimental impact that industrial farming is having on the quality of our soils . The Campaign to Protect Rural England’s recent report on this very issue echoed many of these concerns, highlighting that soil degradation costs at least £1.2bn a year in England and Wales alone. Soil must be seen not only as a fundamental for delivering productive farming and a healthy countryside, but also critical to tackling climate change – or mitigating its worst effects. Its importance should not be understated.
There are solutions, however. By scaling up and incentivising farmers to switch to nature-friendly farming techniques, such as conservation agriculture and agroforestry, we will create a productive farming industry that works with nature and enables farmers to reduce their costs, while still producing the food and services that we need. Rebuilding biological life in soils is vital to enabling this life-giving asset to function as it should. Our soil will once again effectively lock in carbon, store and filter water, support ecosystems and restore the health of the natural environment.Graeme WillisSenior rural policy campaigner at the Campaign to Protect Rural England 
• On page 3 of the Journal I read “the modern western diet needs a complete overhaul if we are to avoid potential ecological catastrophe” (Eat less meat – and redraw the entire global food system, 28 January). And on page 10: “Can we feed the world if we ditch intensive farming?”
Both of these concerns are predicated on a global population in excess of 10 billion people by 2050. Might it not be easier to persuade people to have slightly fewer children than it would be to move the western world on to a diet of nuts and berries? Of course it would also help to reduce our CO2 emissions and our carbon footprint.Melvyn RustSt Albans, Hertfordshire

description: A technique developed by a Jesuit priest is producing bumper crops – and reducing emissions of a grain responsible for 1.5% of greenhouse gases
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: A technique developed by a Jesuit priest is producing bumper crops – and reducing emissions of a grain responsible for 1.5% of greenhouse gases
og_fields.og:title: The miracle method for sustainable rice – and bigger harvests  | John Vidal
text:
The fragrant jasmine rice growing on the left side of Kreaougkra Junpeng’s five-acre field stands nearly five feet tall.
Each plant has 15 or more tillers, or stalks, and the grains hang heavy from them. The Thai farmer says this will be his best-ever harvest in 30 years and he will reap it four weeks earlier than usual.
It is very different on the other side of the field. Here, Junpeng planted his rice in closely spaced clumps of 20 or more seedlings in shallow water just as he, his father and millions of other small farmers across south-east Asia have always done. He used the same seeds but the conventionally grown plants are wind-battered and thin, and clearly have fewer, smaller grains.
Junpeng is part of a pilot project to see if it’s possible to grow more rice with less water and fewer greenhouse gases. The dramatic difference between his two crops points a way to help the world’s 145 million small rice farmers, and could also greatly reduce global warming emissions from agriculture.
The project, backed by the German and Thai governments and by some of the world’s largest rice traders and food companies, has seen 3,000 other farmers in this corner of Thailand’s “rice basket” near the Cambodian border trained to grow sustainable rice according to the principles of a revolutionary agronomical system discovered by accident in Madagascar in the 1980s.
Jesuit priest Henri de Lalanié working in the highlands observed that by planting far fewer seeds than usual, using organic matter as a fertiliser and keeping the rice plants alternately wet and dry rather than flooded, resulted in yields that were increased by between 20 and 200%, while water use was halved. Giving plants more oxygen, minimising the competition between them and strictly controlling the water they receive is thought to make them stronger and more resilient to flood and drought.
When it was first employed outside Madagascar in 2000, the system of rice intensification (SRI) was dismissed  by a handful of scientists who questioned the legitimacy of the reported increased yields. But since then, it has evolved and been developed by peasant farmers working in many different climates around the world.
Academic criticism has since all but disappeared and the SRI system of farming has been validated in hundreds of scientific papers and adopted by up to 20 million farmers in 61 countries, according to the SRI information centre in Cornell University.
“The results consistently cite yield increases, decreased use of seed, water and chemicals, and increased income,” says Norman Uphoff, professor of global agriculture at Cornell.
Vietnamese, Cambodian, Nepalese, Filipino, Indian and African farmers have all reported large increases. In 2011, a young Indian farmer broke the world record for rice production, harvesting 22 tonnes from a single hectare (2.47 acres).
“SRI is very positive in west Africa. It uses fewer seed and fertilisers and needs less water. Farmers saved up to 80% of the cost of seed and got increased yields and incomes. They see the advantages and they change. People are teaching each other now,” says Professor Bancy Mati, director of the water research centre at Jomo Kenyatta University in Nairobi, Kenya.
The Thai farmers who took part in the Ubon Ratchathani trial say they are delighted. Says Khampha Bunchansee from Noan Dang village: “It was very easy to learn. I will use the extra money to invest in a tractor. If I can do it, anyone can. Everyone can come and learn.”
“I applied more fertiliser on my conventional crop but it produced lots more leaf but not more grain,” says Wanna Sriwila, also from Noan Dang. “Now I bring other farmers to see what can be done. Seeing is believing.”
But what is now exciting some of the world’s largest food corporations and governments is that growing rice along SRI principles also greatly reduces emissions of the powerful greenhouse gas methane, which escapes when rice, or any other crop, lies waterlogged for weeks at a time.
Methane is roughly 30 times more powerful than CO2 as a greenhouse gas, and rice emits as much as 1.5% of the world’s total greenhouse gas emissions. With the human population in south-east Asia expected to grow by around 100m people in the next 20 years, emissions from rice growing could increase 30% or more.
The urgency to act for the global good, self-interest in maintaining production and the possibility of accessing money to reduce farm emissions has now led heavy rice-using food companies like Mars and Kellogg’s, and the agri-business colossus Olam, to set up the Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP).
This coalition of companies, NGOs and governments sets the world’s first voluntary sustainability standards for rice growing. It adopts the basic SRI principle of planting seedlings further apart, and keeping them moist rather than flooded, but adds targets and measurements to provide consistency.
“Rice is both a victim and a cause of climate change,” says Sunny Verghese, CEO of Singapore-based Olam’s, which grows its own rice on 25,000 acres in Nigeria, owns mills and processing plants across south-east Asia and ships nearly 20% of the world’s globally traded rice.
“South-east Asian rice farmers are among the world’s most vulnerable to climate change impacts such as rising sea levels, salinity, temperature rise and droughts. Yields can decrease as much as 10% for each 1C temperature increase, threatening food security for billions of people.
“With another two billion people we cannot carry on the way we are. We must go beyond what is currently being done and achieve far more at greater scale. We must re-imagine the whole food supply chain if the world is to become carbon neutral by 2050,” he says.
“SRI should influence everyone’s thinking. In Nigeria we saw a 70% increase in yields, albeit from a low base. SRI is revolutionary. It is a genuine change in thinking. It is difficult for scientists to understand that an amateur [like Lalanié] should have a solution. We want to partner with SRI, to scale up in Africa.
“But reducing emissions from rice cannot be a trade-off that hurts farmers and communities who depend on it for their income and sustenance. We have to measure the true cost of food and dismantle the subsidy system.”
Working with German development agency GIZ and south-east Asian governments, Olam now plan to roll out SRP rice to 100,000 farmers in Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam and India within five years, increasing yields and incomes, and reducing methane emissions by 50%.
Governments and global bodies must act too, says tropical agronomist Erika Styger, director of climate-resilient farming systems at Cornell University who led a three-year World Bank study of 50,000 farmers using SRI methods in 13 west African countries. This saw a 56% rise in yields in irrigated areas, an 86% increase in rain-fed areas and an average 41% increase in income.
“The SRI revolution is happening. People are changing their practices and you can see SRI in the field in many places now. There is no reason why SRI should not become normal agronomic practice,” says Styger.
“But there is no long term funding. If we want to make it mainstream it needs to get to a critical mass. We are left with breadcrumbs, with only short-term project finding,” she says.
“The food system is broken. Olam on its own cannot fix it, we can only change it. We can’t do it overnight but there is a new way of collaborating. Companies must change and reduce their resource intensity. The whole food sector must change,” says Verghese.
“What is needed now is large retailers to brand SRP. It’s the way we can reduce emissions, use less water and grow more. Win. Win. Win.”

In response to ComfortablyPlumb "And I suspect that the reason why many hot countries like the UAE are deploying nuclear that is usually confined to cold ones (as well as solar etc)". 
BQSTART
The UAE (United Arab Emirates) is a country of 9.5 million people in area of 84,000 square km (compared with 5 million Queenslanders in a state of 1,850,000 square km) at a similar latitude to Southern Queensland. For obvious reasons fresh water hydro is not an option but there is some mountainous country in the north-east not far from the Arabian Gulf.
BQEND
BQENDI really don't understand why you feel compelled to 'write out' what I've said as if it's explanation or correction.
I think it's safe to assume that we both know what UAE stands for - and the subject we are discussing.
We both have the internet, there's no need and no point to be scored that way.
UAE is an example of cost and environment - I'm not saying that every nut and bolt should be copied.
BQSTART
The UAE has the fifth largest natural gas reserves in the world so dispatchable electricity from gas turbines is an option. Despite an absence of coal reserves in the UAE, Dubai's coal fired Hassyan Project currently under construction will supply 3,600 MW of generating capacity most likely using coal imported from nearby Iran.
BQENDThe subject, should you choose to accept it, is cutting emissions.
The question isn't 'how not to have nuclear' the question is 'how to substantially cut emissions'
BQSTART
The UAE has 11,500 MW of gas turbine generation capacity at a six locations throughout the country.

BQENDWouldn't it be easier to answer the question ... just once?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549131639000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125385270', u'id': u'125406736', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'cheard', u'text': u'Resilient building design and execution - a problem with buildings is their longevity - they are one of the longest lived artefacts that humans manufacture. The benefits of a good resilient design are spread over several generations but in the case of privately owned buildings the upfront costs are borne by the present generation. In long-lived public infrastructure (roads, bridges etc.) debt financing paid over its useful lifetime is a way of assuring that future generations that benefit from such goods pay their part. The incentives to build for future generations of users in commercial or residential building need to be addressed to spread the costs over time. When carrying out net present value estimations for such investments the question of what discount rate to use and how these should vary over time needs much more work: a start was provided by Giglio et al ["VERY LONG-RUN DISCOUNT RATES" https://www.nber.org/papers/w20133.pdf]. Of course one way to go is to impose stricter building envelope energy standards at least for new buildings - for retrofitting existing buildings that would be a hot potato given that even suggesting an acceleration to renewable carbon-free power is politically difficult.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549127916000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14973352', u'id': u'125405621', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'onthefence', u'text': u'BQSTART

Well, quite. A renewables grid locks in gas.
A wind+solar+gas calculation based on UK wind statistics (e.g. Table 6 here) shows that if you have enough gas capacity to meet 100% of UK consumption over a year, then — even with additional solar — 20% of generation ends up being gas as backup for wind lulls. That gives you an aggregate carbon intensity of 113g CO₂/kWh for the electricity system as a whole.
The UK emissions target is 50g CO₂/kWh. 
Using gas as backup for wind lulls won't decarbonise electricity. That's a well-known and uncontentious point. The UAE (United Arab Emirates) is a country of 9.5 million people in area of 84,000 square km (compared with 5 million Queenslanders in a state of 1,850,000 square km) at a similar latitude to Southern Queensland. For obvious reasons fresh water hydro is not an option but there is some mountainous country in the north-east not far from the Arabian Gulf.
The UAE has the fifth largest natural gas reserves in the world so dispatchable electricity from gas turbines is an option. Despite an absence of coal reserves in the UAE, Dubai's coal fired Hassyan Project currently under construction will supply 3,600 MW of generating capacity most likely using coal imported from nearby Iran.
The Barakah nuclear power plant currently under construction 50 km west of Ruwais is still under construction and the production of electricity from its first reactors is now not expected to commence until next year. If all four nuclear reactors become operational the proposed Barakah Power Station will provide 5,600 MW of power.
The UAE has 11,500 MW of gas turbine generation capacity at a six locations throughout the country.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549111234000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125396382', u'id': u'125401842', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nowheretorun', u'text': u'Did you read that study or just the abstract? Did you read the follow up study? 
Within those percentages are papers that are related to climate change but are not discussing the causes - for example they might be talking about Arctic melt rates or other technical analysis, but those particular papers are not talking about causes. The absence of a direct mention is not a negative, it just wasn't relevant to the particular content of the paper so causality was not addressed. Also, in the first paper, they are looking over a large period of the climate science development period when there was a lot more genuine uncertainty about the causes early on and these papers were also included.
They are simply being accurate honest scientists and being clear that in the review of the total number of papers only 33.6% actually directly expressed an opinion about causality and of those 97% endorsed AGW.
The second follow up paper directly addresses the problem of taking a paper that expresses no position on causes as being negative or non-committal as in itself being a flawed view and explains why that is so.
You seem to have a POV which I don't think any amount of evidence is going to change. I do not doubt your sincerity, nor your apparent intelligence, but I think you don't seem to understand how scientific consensus is developed nor do you seem to understand the nature of the meta-analysis presented in these papers.
I wasn't going to respond as it did not seem worthwhile, but I just did not want to let your last analysis go unanswered lest someone else only read the abstract and was misled by the conclusions you seem to draw.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549111216000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16973644', u'in_reply_to': u'125395899', u'id': u'125401834', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'BQSTART

One at a time.
Frequency controls "such as the small 100 MW Teasla" battery bank "in SA" has successfully dealt with frequency fluctuations caused by problems outside South Australia including problems with aging coal fired power stations in Victoria.
"Snowy River 2.0" is a planned 2,000 MW capacity readily dispatchable stored hydro scheme.
"HVDC links to shunt power from state to state from where it is to where it isn't" don't play a large role in linking state grid to state grid with the exception of one from the Victorian Riverland to the South Australian Riverland, but HVAC (high voltage alternating current) links do, though most of those were built using federal funding during the Hawke/Keating years and are likely due for an upgrade. Power is shunted during heatwaves such as recently occurred from Queensland to New South Wales and from South Australia to Victoria and from Tasmania to Victoria when the largely coal based generating capacity of New South Wales and Victoria could not meet demand.
"Then there's the grid costs of getting power from frequently remote wind and solar farms" to consumers.
Where are wind and solar farms more remote from consumers than coal fired power stations? Solar panels on my roof are definitely not remote from their consumers 3 metres below or at most 50 metres down the street. Solar farms on the Darling Downs are no more remote from the 3.4 million consumers in South East Queensland than the Tarong Power outside Nanango. Solar farms and wind farms in North and Far North Queensland are closer to the 300,000 consumers north of Mackay than the Stanwell power station in Rockhampton.
Also there are economies of small scale and reduced transmission distance inherent in wind and solar for areas with small spread out populations.
Note that South Australia with a population of 1.7 million is the equivalent in terms of number of consumers to greater Brisbane north of the river.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549106959000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'problems outside south australia including problems with aging coal', u'effect': u'frequency fluctuations'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125396190', u'id': u'125400308', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'Yep, domestic (in fact all demand side) batts are brilliant. They’ve been a key to our industrialisation and development.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549097357000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14432870', u'in_reply_to': u'125392524', u'id': u'125395595', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'Hiya, just to warn you, this is not a new issue, all of the points have been made many times before on UK based articles.
For those of us that support RE (not nuclear campaigners) we can clearly see that demand side storage, even in homes, benefits the national grids through offset, after all, if a powerstation (even a small domestic PV system) is added to 'the grid' then it's supply will impact the grid.
If a homeowner doesn't ask for a kW of power, or their neighbours don't need it because the 'small powerstation' is exporting next door, then the national grid doesn't get asked for that kW.
Once you put maths tricks, or deliberate anti-RE and anti-storage spin aside, you see that domestic storage benefits all. And the big benefit is that the CAPEX is borne by the household, not the grid for the batts.
I note that in Aus, households with storage can join schemes that negotiate on their behalf to provide additional supply to the grids during peak periods by having 1,000's of households export from their batts. Not only do the households get paid peak prices for that leccy, but all of Aus benefits as the increased supply helps to reduce peak prices.
I seem to recall a news article from a year or so back, where households were receiving about A$1/kWh for export because the grid price was peaking around $1,400/MWh at that time.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549091641000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the powerstation is exporting next door', u'effect': u"their neighbours do n't need it"}, {u'cause': u'the grid price was peaking around $ 1,400/mwh at that time', u'effect': u'where households were receiving about a$ 1/kwh for export'}], u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'125387212', u'id': u'125394442', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'goliver4', u'text': u'Was wondering if Australia have any Mined-out Solution Mines? "Not one developed nation has a plan for renewables only. Why do you think that is?" 
No imagination combined with vested interests
BQENDYou are probably right, and of course these 'not 100% RE options' are government plans, whereas many, many studies show that RE + storage costs would be cheaper as prices tumble.
The fun part now is that as fast as some folk argue against RE + storage on cost grounds, we see RE + storage being deployed at cheap and ever cheaper prices, so it looks like intraday RE + storage is sorted.
Then we need to consider longer term storage, such as CAES, LAES, PHS etc, but let's not forget bio-methane as that has a low cost of storage, and can be used to demand follow when burnt as gas generation if necessary. That is reaching efficiencies of ~80% now, so a great way to store Aussie sunshine.
Power-to-gas with high efficiency
So, we can expect something like 50% of PV gen to be consumed at time of generation, perhaps 25% consumed via high efficiency intraday battery storage, so about 25% consumed as gas generation from bio-methane at 40% efficiency (80% x 50% gas efficiency).
The fun bit here though is even at 40% efficiency the PV (via gas generation) is still far cheaper than nuclear, with the UK paying out A$180/MWh with the planned new nuclear at HPC, whilst Aus can expect sub A$40/MWh for PV generation, which even at 40% efficiency (on that part) is still only A$100/MWh.
Or a weighted average of A$180/MWh nuclear v's A$57.50/MWh* for PV.
* 50% at A$40, 25% at A$50 (80% efficiency) & 25% at A$100 (40% efficiency).', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549090916000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11150889', u'in_reply_to': u'125390471', u'id': u'125394380', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"Whilst I 'think' Australia is a country best set for a renewables 'only' platform, I suspect the cost of making the grid capable of handling that on the necessary scale will stifle the role out of utility scale renewables."
Currently in Australia the cost of maintaining and expanding the transmission and distribution grid contributes 54% of the retail cost of electricity. That cost has little to do with the cost of adapting the grid to accommodate the installation of renewables but much to do with changing patterns of demand peaks and troughs including the uptake of domestic airconditioning. Large 80% increases in network costs have occurred in the last decade or so independent of any cost of adapting the network to renewable sources of electricity. 
One source of renewable energy, rooftop solar, has reduced the need to increase network transmission capacity as it uses little to none of the network at times of peak demand due to airconditioner use. Rooftop solar capacity in Queensland is currently equivalent in output to one of our large black coal fired power stations. Large utility scale concentrations of photovoltaic panels such as are being rolled out in Queensland and large scale wind farms such as as being built in southern Australia and North Queensland require no more additional grid upgrade than a coal, gas or nuclear plant of similar capacity.
Australia is a major exporter of uranium with the world's largest uranium mine in South Australia. A inquiry into the nuclear industry options possible for that state found that, at least for the next two decades, a nuclear power plant to supply power to the 1.7 million South Australians was uneconomic. There has been no similar inquiry into the economics of nuclear power for Victoria (population 6.4 million), New South Wales (population 7.4 million) or Queensland (population 5 million). The cost of producing electricity from nuclear power stations even in countries with large concentrated populations is greater than the renewable and gas alternatives in Australia. Unlike gas turbines and hydro nuclear and coal fired plants have problems with quick dispatchability.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549090550000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'airconditioner use', u'effect': u'peak demand'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'125389031', u'id': u'125394347', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'okay, just wanted to make the distinction.Thanks.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549039620000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125377728', u'id': u'125381334', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'And it has to happen quickly starting now, not Dec 31, 2049.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549038083000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'125342667', u'id': u'125380349', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mazter', u'text': u'BQSTART
In the UK Hitachi was bid at £75/MWh the same as the 2023 price for near shore offshore wind. Deep water will cost considerably more.
BQENDAs usual you misrepresent the facts.
The Hitachi bid was not £75/MWh, it was £75/MWh plus £5bn of direct investment in the build costs by the UK government.
£75/MWh over 35yrs, against an expected £50/MWh wholesale price is an additional subsidy of £25/MWh, or approx £23bn, so a total subsidy/contribution cost of £28bn.
Whereas the 2022/23 off-shore wind price is only £57.50/MWh, and only for 15yrs, so comes to about £5bn in total subsidies if we match generation for generation. £5bn v's £28bn in subsidies, despite off-shore wind being relatively new, and only having had support for a decade, whereas nuclear is 'old' and has received vast subsidies in the UK (and worldwide) for about 60yrs.
The higher price of £75/MWh is actually for the 2021/22 pot that was issued at the same time. But you know that, and choose instead to quote the higher price.

Their solar output has parity with aircon demand and their wide open plains offer extremely cheap land on which to plant solar and wind farms with far lower seasonal variability than with a country like the UK.So where is it?
The problem is that Australia's grid requires massive expansion and strengthening to make that work - yet the public refuse to pay for it whilst at the same time asking their politicians where the renewable generation is.
Nuclear has the advantage that it is a direct replacement for coal because it uses the existing grid infrastructure.
So if Australia decides (as it seems to have done) that spending hundreds of billions updating their grid to accommodate renewables is too much, then they could use renewables to limit demand and have their baseload (literally: the minimum demand requirement) met with some nuclear.
Australia already has industrial/commercial nuclear, it just doesn't use it for power.
The change from coal will not be free, but then there's no rule that says that addressing AGW is free.
We know that failing to address AGW will cost far far more, and right now Australia is bottom of all OECD nations in addressing AGW - they need to stop complaining about change, poull their fingers out and make their minds up.https://www.climate-change-performance-index.org/country/australia-2019', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1549017529000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it uses the existing grid infrastructure', u'effect': u'that it is a direct replacement for coal'}], u'author_id': u'14842422', u'in_reply_to': u'125365587', u'id': u'125368686', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'BQSTART

Energy Source Mortality Rate (deaths/trillionkWhr)
Coal – global average 170,000 (50% global electricity)
Coal – China 280,000 (75% China’s electricity)
Coal – U.S. 15,000 (44% U.S. electricity)
Oil 36,000 (36% of energy, 8% of electricity)
Natural Gas 4,000 (20% global electricity)
Biofuel/Biomass 24,000 (21% global energy)
Solar (rooftop) 440 (< 1% global electricity)
Wind 150 (1% global electricity)
Hydro – global average 1,400 (15% global electricity)
Nuclear – global average 90 (17% global electricity w/Chernobyl &Fukushiima)
**The dozen or so U.S. deaths in nuclear have all been in the weapons complex or are modelled from general LNT effects. 
The two failures have been in GenII plants with old designs - All new builds must be Generation III and higher, with passive redundant safety systems, and all must be able to withstand the worst case disaster, no matter how unlikely.
As to the data, they come from Professor James Conca who is, according to his bio, a member of " Sierra Club, Greenpeace, the NRDC, the Environmental Defense Fund and many others, as well as professional societies including the America Nuclear Society, the American Chemical Society and the American Association of Petroleum Geologists."

Nuclear is just too expensive. It cannot compete with renewables on any measure
BQENDIt's wrong to think of it as a competition.
Coal is a base load provider.Nuclear is a baseload provider.Intermittent supplies are not.Intermittent supplies with storage get some of the way there but still require gas backup.
So if Nuclear is a direct replacement for coal and gas (with no expensive [often non existent] extras then nuclear kills coal and gas/ - wind and solar do not.
So if anything if we got rid of nuclear then it would be a huge boost to coal and gas.
Par exemplar, the German phase out of nuclear was a huge boon to the coal sector who far from closing down, opened new coal plants and new lignite coal strip mines through forests and villages to balance the removal of nuclear.
So it isn't nuclear /vs/ renewables, it is nuclear PLUS renewables in a mix.
The UK is completely off coal by 2022/5 using a mix of RE+nuclear and no marked increase in cost.Germany is opening new coal power stations and have some of the most expensive electricity.
Australia is 70% coal.
