So I am hoping the same to you that I have experienced so you will learn to shut your mouth before making such nasty comments again.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548961421000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the mudslide in santa barbara', u'effect': u'when you referred to the response i had to the death of my very good friend and travel partner for the past three decades as tears'}], u'author_id': u'14173421', u'in_reply_to': u'125321925', u'id': u'125354075', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bangor1', u'text': u'The Wooden Boat Centre is a boat builder, not a marina per se, and that is what concerns me, all the tools, jigs, plans and so on.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548937127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14038383', u'in_reply_to': u'125326641', u'id': u'125335542', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PDGFD1', u'text': u'I'm not familiar with buttongrass plain ecology, but I can tell you the there is a great deal of evidence to suggest that 'firestick farming' (for example) turned forests into 'savannah' in northern Australia.What goes on on Cape York, for example, is quite concerning from a botanical point of view.
Just saying, all human intervention has it's 'downsides' and assuming that relatively frequent cold burns, even 'patchwork' ones, is an 'answer' to catastrophic wildfires is probably optimistic, if not simplistic. Plants need to exceed reproductive maturity in order to replenish soil-born seed banks - which are vital, as I'm sure you also know.
I worry when I hear people who just want more and more 'burning off' as a panacea to 'protect' property start quoting indigenous practices - particularly reactionaries who have agendas that don't include botanical diversity . Forests are more than the trees, and even trees who have 'resprouting' as their regeneration after fire strategy can be depleted beyond their ability. Especially in a climate constrained ecosystem.

No rain on the horizon just yet and we need proper rain (at least two inches) to even start filling dams We got 115mm in 8 hours back in May. That'll do it!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548893729000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125315760', u'id': u'125316260', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Liz Charpleix', u'text': u'Really? No wildlife died from either being directly burnt to death or suffocated by smoke? From stress myopathy after the fact? From being burnt on paws or wings, preventing them from moving off the fire ground? From untreated injuries which left them to die slowly, out of human sight?I find that hard to believe.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548893609000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11369375', u'in_reply_to': u'125315991', u'id': u'125316205', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Liz Charpleix', u'text': u'S/he hasn't drunk enough to pee properly. It's dribbling down here right now, just enough to stop the firies getting on with it, not enough to put any fires out.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548893155000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11369375', u'in_reply_to': u'125313641', u'id': u'125316004', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bangor1', u'text': u'In the Como fire to my knowledge only humans were lost, Pets and other animals were too smart.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548893135000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14038383', u'in_reply_to': u'125267774', u'id': u'125315991', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bangor1', u'text': u'5400km should have been 400km.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548892981000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14038383', u'in_reply_to': u'125267060', u'id': u'125315919', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gregory Shearman', u'text': u'Yeah, GeorgeHuxley, it's the fault of us little guys and nothing to do with the fossil fuel corporations "donating" to government to make sure they can still sell their poisonous and climate warming product.
Sheesh, we protest, we buy solar panels etc to lower our energy bills and yet we STILL get blamed.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548892795000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14899696', u'in_reply_to': u'125302242', u'id': u'125315835', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MorvaHindrance', u'text': u'I have one of those compost tumblers which is why I get the Ferrero Rocher effect. I don't have gum trees near the house to gather leaves from but the occasional small branch gets blown onto the lawn so I use them for firelighters. We are supposed to get two wet days next week so hopefully we can fill our tanks. You might even get more than a puddle in your new dam.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548892603000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16761029', u'in_reply_to': u'125315199', u'id': u'125315760', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'If we all wish together this will get heavier
http://www.bom.gov.au/products/IDR762.loop.shtml
Sadly wishes (and prayers) ...', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548892454000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'id': u'125315690', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bangor1', u'text': u'I heard this morning that Franklin on the Huon River is under threat. Its mainly apple orchards but it also has the Wooden Boat Centre, Australia's last vestige of a dying art. I really hope it survives.
At the same time, another fire is threatening Waddamana on the Central Plateau and home of the first public hydro generating plant in Australia, Waddamana Power Station, now decommissioned and home of an excellent museum.
And what activity on climate change do we get from the COALition and Shouty, their ineffective leader? Nothing, SFA, Nada, Zip. Its criminal and this mob should be held to account.
I really hope you get through this horror, Doggie; and I hope Tasmania rapidly recovers. Our thoughts are with you.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548891419000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14038383', u'id': u'125315242', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'You need to get your compost hotter by the sound of it. Tea bags (also great compost) just disappear
Fire lighters?? That's what all the dry stuff especially under gum trees is for. When there are fires around it reminds you it's a good time to collect a few boxes rather than have any embers falling into it …
Green? Not so much and it will take a good deal more than 14mm to even begin to fill the new dam (not even a puddle this morning I checked!) or top up the others but I will be mightily relieved when they are spilling again', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548891317000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125314899', u'id': u'125315199', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MorvaHindrance', u'text': u'Bog rolls full of used tissues make great firelighters. Used teabags soaked in metho work well too. My compost ends up like ferrero rocher with a teabag covered in sheep shit covered in composted green stuff, then rolled in a crisp coating of egg shells.
Our 2mm of rain did nothing, but if you got 14mm it should look greener already.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548890682000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16761029', u'in_reply_to': u'125313927', u'id': u'125314899', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Aldous0rwell', u'text': u'They help in the same way that expressing empathy and care, concern and compassion help. It helps build people who have been wounded, injured, traumatized know there is support for them, however small. It helps unlike the mockery of someone who, upon learning about another grieving over death and loss, sneers at them, like ReformedSoma chose to.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548890452000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14173421', u'in_reply_to': u'125311563', u'id': u'125314792', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ReformedSoma', u'text': u'Thanks Verlie. Good advice.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548890064000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100736998', u'in_reply_to': u'125310629', u'id': u'125314602', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LeeBay', u'text': u'I hope you will be able to evacuate your animals as well...I hate the thought of all the defenseless animals being killed or injured in the fires. Our thoughts are with everybody facing bushfires.', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548889835000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17992762', u'id': u'125314486', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jick123', u'text': u'The Engie owned Hazelwood coal fired power station fire.
"This isn't good ... we really shouldn't be breathing this."
That was the assessment of visiting Tasmanian Environment Protection Authority expert John Innis on Tuesday, as he prepared for a media interview next to the Morwell Centenary Rose Garden.
Mr Innis' laptop was at that moment reading in excess of 400 mg/m3.
Having already relocated once from near the Morwell bowls club, the group decided to shift again to an area in Morwell’s north, where the air was noticeably clearer to allow the media interview to proceed.
"We've often been seeing 800 micrograms per cubic metre here - that's some of the highest readings we've ever seen from an ongoing incident," Mr Innis said.
He said a reading of 1500 micrograms had been recorded over the weekend.
A three-day tyre depot fire in Tasmania was the only time Mr Innis could recall PM 2.5 readings at this level.
A monitoring trip out to Glengarry on Monday (20 kilometres from the Hazelwood fire) recorded 150 mg/m3 - a revelation Mr Innis said was "quite surprising".
While PM 2.5 monitoring commenced in Morwell on 12 February, three days after the Hazelwood fire started, hourly readings have only began making their way to the EPA's public website since Monday afternoon.
That's 13 days later!
http://www.latrobevalleyexpress.com.au/story/2115399/hold-your-breath/?cs=1462
Remember how the government in Japan refused to inform residents of the radiation readings! It would never happen here though!', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548889789000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100805943', u'id': u'125314465', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jick123', u'text': u'Morwell's Hazlewood coal fired power station now deceased has been mooted by the Coalition to be turned into a plastic burning facility to cope with mounting tonnes of recyclable waste not going to China. It is right in town and when Engie owned it the fire whose smoke covered the La Trobe was deadly.
Engie is the owner of the Pelican Point power station in SA responsible for not backing up the power supply when the transmission poles were knocked out by a storm. 
Why did energy regulators deliberately turn out the lights in South Australia?
...the amount of gas generation available on Wednesday was about 20% less than the nominally available capacity. 
Had the full capacity been available, the blackouts would have easily been avoided. 
It is this fact that has particularly angered the South Australian government, which is once again facing political derision for failing to keep the lights on.
The largest single part of the unavailable capacity is 240 megawatts – roughly 8% of the state’s total gas generation – at Pelican Point power station. 
Pelican Point is the highest-efficiency, lowest-emission thermal power station in South Australia. 
But nearly two years ago its owner, the French multinational Engie (which also owns the Hazelwood coal station in Victoria), announced that the rising cost of gas had made it too expensive to run at full capacity. 
Since then Pelican Point has operated only intermittently, and never at more than half of its nameplate capacity.
Gas that might notionally have been used to supply electricity for South Australians is instead being shipped to customers in Asia.
https://theconversation.com/why-did-energy-regulators-deliberately-turn-out-the-lights-in-south-australia-72729', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548889693000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100805943', u'id': u'125314409', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'Not sure how the two are connected but I agree that the building in parks - especially where totally unnecessary (3 Capes all within a day walk of plenty of accommodation outside the park) is out of control', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548889029000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125311841', u'id': u'125314025', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'We got 14 or Maria did which certainly could have been better directed
Compost those bog rolls!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548888862000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125312107', u'id': u'125313927', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zz9pluralzalpha', u'text': u'Thoughts and hopes are with you all down there, and a big thankyou to the volunteers out there busting their guts for the community and environment.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548888755000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14670527', u'id': u'125313881', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'doG has an interesting soh
We ended up getting a thunderstorm last night Maria got 14mm - not sure we got all of that but while welcome was of course entirely in the wrong place for those that needed it much more than we did', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548888342000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125276093', u'id': u'125313641', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ReaderinHobart', u'text': u'It is amazing how much smoke a burning forest can create. It is also amazing what the firefighters know about fire, and can predict. It is a real science. It is also great that their first priority is still human life. Let’s hope this never changes.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548888096000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14051475', u'id': u'125313504', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jick123', u'text': u'Very true, and not diminishing the impacts of the fires smoke on health let alone the devastation to lives and the heartache ensuing, but the impacts of this smoke is the same in winter on those who have the misfortune to be inhaling woodsmoke from wood fires. Once thought innocuous, it is in fact deadly.
Ash Wednesday was my nightmare and I really feel for all those including the wildlife caught in this conflagration.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548887745000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100805943', u'in_reply_to': u'125311941', u'id': u'125313276', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BlueMageAlpha', u'text': u'BQSTART
Educate yourself on what to do and dont fuck about when the firies order you to move
BQEND
That last part especially. Too many folks think they can stay and defend, not realising all they're doing is not just endangering their own lives, but the lives of the firies who will be put in increased danger when they attempt to rescue.
People (family especially) >>> property. Property can be rebuilt. People can't.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548887548000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17572525', u'in_reply_to': u'125312506', u'id': u'125313119', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'wardadkiwi', u'text': u'Fought bushfires in the Army in the 80s,even as part of a disciplined well trained cohesive unit its scary as fuck.Watching gum trees explode before the flames even hit them is horrifying,fascinating and awesome.Educate yourself on what to do and dont fuck about when the firies order you to move .', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548886661000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4725614', u'id': u'125312506', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'Yes it was never just Geeveston but that's still where you think it is if that makes sense
If you ever saw The Kettering Incident otoh most of us spent more time trying to identify the multitude of locations (none of them Kettering from memory!) than the weirdy story line.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548886649000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'125290571', u'id': u'125312497', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MorvaHindrance', u'text': u'We had a dry lightning storm last night and then 2mm of rain a couple of hours later when the cold front came. It is now 15C and I lit the fire this morning to get rid of the build up of empty toilet rolls and stuff that had accumulated in the stove since last year. There is a new fire in the north-west that may have been started by lightning. The fires near me have been downgraded but the ones further south around First Dog's place are worse now. The wind is picking up and carrying embers for miles.
I want to thank all the interstate volunteers who have come to help us save our ancient landscapes and historic towns. Tasmania will never forget your willingness to help us at this time.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548886133000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16761029', u'id': u'125312107', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Verlie', u'text': u'When I was doing environmental studies some years ago, I recall us being told that the UK could suffer a polar vortex, giving them weather like the northern Scandinavian countries. Mother Nature has a lot of surprises in store for those who ignore her.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548886065000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13484758', u'in_reply_to': u'125310812', u'id': u'125312063', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Verlie', u'text': u'Reports from Tasmania have mentioned that many asthmatics are reaching for their puffers. Even those living in cities and large towns will be suffering impacts from the smoke.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885863000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13484758', u'in_reply_to': u'125311115', u'id': u'125311941', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArborealDeathWombat', u'text': u'I still don't know what the comment means. Maybe the smoke is clogging up my neural pathways.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885748000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100478787', u'in_reply_to': u'125307932', u'id': u'125311871', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Verlie', u'text': u'The Tassie fires underscore the need to keep tourist accommodation out of wilderness areas and national parks. Building luxury cabins in remote areas is madness. Politicians and developers, please note.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885696000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13484758', u'id': u'125311841', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mogbrown', u'text': u'These actions will help to reverse the conditions that have led to the current fires and floods. Stay safe, doggie and all those in beautiful Tassie.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885536000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the current fires and floods'}], u'author_id': u'100164601', u'in_reply_to': u'125311729', u'id': u'125311766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArborealDeathWombat', u'text': u'Government? Morrison, Abbott, Abetz, Joyce, Frydenberg..? Who are they?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885504000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100478787', u'in_reply_to': u'125280023', u'id': u'125311756', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mogbrown', u'text': u'Couldn't agree more. We need a government that will facilitate the entry of electric vehicles, establish charging stations, help people who can't afford it to put photovoltaics on their roofs and install storage batteries and set-up community power-sharing hubs. The technology is available; all that's needed is political will.Make this a key issue in the next election.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885431000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100164601', u'in_reply_to': u'125311067', u'id': u'125311729', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Oatland', u'text': u'Hey FDOTM and the rest of Tassie, Thinking about you all and hoping for the best for everyone and everything there. Best wishes', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885274000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13176528', u'id': u'125311656', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Frumpyoldbag', u'text': u'Having lived in the Sutherland Shire since I was little I have seen many bushfires and they still strike terror into my heart, the worst was the 94/95 fires where friends were forced to sneak behind police lines to rescue their elderly mothers and I thought I may not have a house after an inaccurate news report (I was up the coast). Friends or their family members have lost houses; the landmarks of my childhood were gone in one fiery evening leaving jagged burnt outlines that stood as grim reminder for months not to mention the dreadful silence that hung over the community for months in the fire’s aftermath. Thankfully in all this my parent’s home remained safe as well as my house. Last April we again had to face our fears again but were spared. My friends and I now share the reaction of a tightening in our gut each time we even smell smoke. I bless the RFS.
So Doggie I sincerely sympathise with your situation and truly hope you and yours stay safe and untouched by the fiery beast that stalks our nation.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885173000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13622061', u'id': u'125311614', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ian Black', u'text': u'On the upside you're getting to see how well rural Tasmanians do the community support thing.And to prove that we're also tops for weirdness today's forecast includes snow falling above 1000m.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885074000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11482416', u'id': u'125311577', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArborealDeathWombat', u'text': u'Please explain exactly what practical assistance prayers supply. 'Cause if your god existed and listened to people, this wouldn't be happening in the first place.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548885027000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100478787', u'in_reply_to': u'125302121', u'id': u'125311563', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ArborealDeathWombat', u'text': u'My first fire was '67. Even as a 9yr old, I was helping when the fires were threatening our community, as part of the bucket and gunnysack brigade. 
No, experiencing that -and too many elsewhere since - doesn't make this any less frightening.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548884903000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100478787', u'in_reply_to': u'125310216', u'id': u'125311514', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]

article_tags: [Josh Frydenberg, Coalition, Australia news, Australian politics, Liberal party, Climate change, Climate change, Environment]
description: Treasurer says climate change is real and Scott Morrison’s government takes emissions reduction ‘very seriously’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Treasurer says climate change is real and Scott Morrison’s government takes emissions reduction ‘very seriously’
og_fields.og:title: Josh Frydenberg defends Coalition's climate record as he faces challenge in Kooyong
text:
Josh Frydenberg has defended the Coalition’s record on climate change and says he will work hard to earn the trust of his constituents in the face of a challenge from long-time Liberal and now independent Oliver Yates.
Yates, a former Macquarie banker and head of the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, confirmed on Wednesday he would run in Kooyong at the coming federal election, declaring Frydenberg deserved to be challenged because of a lack of action on the environment.
Yates told Guardian Australia that Frydenberg, now treasurer, “had plenty of opportunity to stand up in relation to the environment when he was minister, or even now, as a more influential person, but he’s failed to discharge his duty in relation to environmental responsibility”.
Frydenberg told reporters climate change was “real” and he defended the government’s policy record.
“The Coalition takes very seriously our international and domestic responsibilities and obligations to reduce emissions,” he said.
In rebutting Yates’ arguments, Frydenberg did not mention the policy he tried to implement as environment and energy minister, the national energy guarantee, which was scuttled when party conservatives moved against Malcolm Turnbull’s leadership last year.
But he said he was “proud of the work we’ve done to support the renewable energy target” – a mechanism Tony Abbott as prime minister attempted to wind back, and conservatives within the government still oppose.
Frydenberg said the government continued to fund abatement through the emissions reduction fund, which the Coalition declined to top up in last year’s budget, although the government has signalled more recently that the fund, a vestige of the Direct Action policy, will get a cash injection ahead of the federal election, and its remit could be broadened to look after threatened species and their habitats.
He also referenced ongoing work on energy efficiency and said the government would deliver “the world’s biggest pumped hydro scheme” in an expansion of Snowy Hydro. The government is yet to confirm whether it will back an expansion adding 2,000MW of new generation capacity, which was approved by the Snowy Hydro board in mid-December.
Frydenberg says the Coalition has presided over a reduction in per capita emissions, but emissions have been rising since the Abbott government repealed the carbon price legislated by the Gillard government.
The latest government projections show that Australia will miss its 2030 emissions reduction targets, despite Scott Morrison’s regular assertion that the country is on track to meet its obligations “in a canter”.
The report, released in late December, says emissions in 2030 are projected to climb 4% above 2020 levels, driven by higher levels of liquefied natural gas production, growth in agriculture, increased transport activity and a drop in the amount of carbon reduction from activities such as reforestation in the land use sector.
It projects emissions from all sectors, except for electricity, waste and land use, will grow by 2030.
A new report from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development has found that Australia is not on track to meet its 2030 emissions targets under the Paris agreement and needs to bring its environment policies into line with the “scale of the challenge” the country is facing.
Yates joins other high-profile independents facing off against Liberals in the coming contest, with a number, including barrister and former Olympic skier Zali Steggall, who will take on Abbott in Warringah, citing inaction on climate change as a central motivation.
There is also continuing speculation that Julia Banks, a Liberal who quit the government for the crossbench late last year, will run against the health minister, Greg Hunt, in the Victorian seat of Flinders.
Yates will face an uphill battle to unseat Frydenberg in Kooyong, a prized Liberal seat held by party leaders including Robert Menzies. The treasurer and deputy Liberal leader tends his local turf assiduously, and won the seat in 2016 with a primary vote of 58%, which was a positive swing of 2% on the previous federal contest.

article_tags: [Scottish politics, Politics, Scotland, UK news, Climate change, Environment, Edinburgh, Environmental activism, Extinction Rebellion]
description: Climate campaigners stage one-hour peaceful sit-in protest in debating chamber
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Climate campaigners stage one-hour peaceful sit-in protest in debating chamber
og_fields.og:title: Extinction Rebellion activists occupy Scottish parliament
text:
Around 40 climate activists have staged a peaceful occupation of the Scottish parliament’s debating chamber, urging MSPs to introduce much tougher climate targets.
Campaigners with the recently formed direct action group Extinction Rebellion posed as tourists on a visit to Holyrood before staging an hour-long sit-in in the chamber.
There were no arrests. Police escorted the protesters from the building through a side entrance and they were greeted by cheers from other campaigners gathered outside the parliament.
Extinction Rebellion was launched last October with the backing of 100 academics and the former archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams. Friday’s occupation was the group’s first direct action in Scotland, after sit-down protests in Parliament Square, Westminster, and at climate talks in Poland.
Robert Alcock, a builder and eco-designer who took part in the sit-in, said the group wanted Holyrood to take up far more ambitious CO2 reduction policies geared towards cutting net emissions to zero by 2025, in line with analysis from the International Panel on Climate Change.
Extinction Rebellion wants Scotland to convene a citizens’ assembly to decide how to achieve that goal through consensus. It would be made up of 73 members of the public drawn from Holyrood’s 73 single-member constituencies, and have the power to revise the parliament’s climate bills.
The Scottish government insists the country’s climate policies, enacted by Holyrood, are among the most ambitious and far-reaching in the world, and the most radical from any UK legislature.
Scotland’s first target to reduce CO2 emissions by 42% by 2020 has already been met, and the parties are now debating a fresh target to hit 90% by 2050 in a new climate bill.
Asked why Extinction Rebellion was targeting Holyrood rather than oil companies in Aberdeen or the oil refinery at Grangemouth west of Edinburgh, Alcock said: “This is a very symbolic place because it is representing the people of Scotland, and today is Burns Day, the day of Scotland’s national poet.
“While it is relatively progressive compared to other countries it comes nowhere near what is necessary to really address the gravity of the climate emergency.”
A Scottish parliament spokeswoman said: “Around 40 individuals on a free public tour refused to leave the chamber for approximately 60 minutes before leaving peacefully at 1.30pm.
“The public tour route takes in the debating chamber when parliament is not sitting. There was no impact on parliamentary business.”

ASHP units cannot realistically replace gas boilers. ASHP essentially provides constant low-level heat; and so it requires very good insulation and very good windows. It also means that pipes and ducts need to be installed; and windows need to remain closed.
BQEND

I agree with a lot of your points about hydrogen, especially how we should be using curtailed wind energy (and possibly solar) to electrolyse it. But we can also do a huge amount to replace oil and gas-fired boilers with ASHP or GSHP-based heating. Keep your ire for those who deny the science.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547458363000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13126382', u'in_reply_to': u'124591234', u'id': u'124603223', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'What can you expect from a Klapperschlange? He is blissfully unaware of recent studies of the links between extreme weather and global temperature rise. He is fixed on the more conservative statements from the earlier IPCC reports and has not noticed that the research has continued. The NOAA, NASA and the American Meteorological Association are all warning of the workings of climate change on local weather events. 
Here is a round-up of the recent research:
"A growing body of evidence demonstrates that climate change is already amplifying extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, droughts and floods, making them either more frequent or more intense. Awareness of this trend was among the factors leading to the Paris Agreement in 2015, with governments, businesses, the military and health professionals among the constituencies highlighting the growing impacts of extreme weather in the run-up to the summit.
A year ago, the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU) published an analysis detailing what scientists had discovered about the links between climate change and extreme weather in the two years since the Paris Agreement.1 Today, we update that analysis with a further year’s-worth of scientific papers. This strengthens further the case that climate change is driving an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, documented on every continent except Antarctica.
In last year’s analysis, we identified 59 papers published in 2016 and 2017 exploring a possible link between climate change and amplification of extreme weather events, of which 41 found a positive signal of climate change. The additional year has brought a further 43 papers, of which 32 found a positive link from climate change to the event’s likelihood or intensity. Of the new batch, only four found that climate change decreased the chances of a particular extreme event, and these all involved snow and/or cold temperatures." [The Seeker Jan 8. 2019]', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547457897000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the paris agreement'}], u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'124598860', u'id': u'124602897', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonShone', u'text': u'You may not be lazy at downloading data, but you certainly are unaware of the irony in your statement. The idea that a cif poster has got a better understanding of the situation than publishing climate scientists with peer reviewed work, scientists from nasa, the noaa and the many others who produce reports for the ipcc, is what lacks credibility.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547457873000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15198700', u'in_reply_to': u'124591524', u'id': u'124602883', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Some may want to restrict themselves to a discussion of heat in a particular place in a particular month but the article is clearly about wider weather patterns. These extreme weather events are not weather as usual but seasonal weather plus the intensifier of warming. To speak bluntly, climate change has acted as an amplifier turning up the voöume. 
To take an example a bit further away from the US, the current snow masses in the Northern Alps which are causing avalanches are not the usual winter snow fall but 8 meters in as many days followed by melting rains. To put it even more plainly, the winter there is too warm for skiing.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547457010000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'avalanches'}], u'author_id': u'3684556', u'id': u'124602364', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'"This thread is about summer heatwaves" you claim. I am talking about the article not some thread you are trying to pick apart from its fabric. Here is one of the claims the article makes about winter up and down the eastern seaboard:
"Strangely the team found that winter heat waves had experienced the greatest growth in size, leaving northern hemisphere seasons less defined than they used to be. Although winter heat waves tend not to be as hot as summer ones they do still strain health services and confuse ecosystems. "
As I have already pointed out above I feel the concept of a "winter heat wave" less than useful. Nonetheless the article does discuss winter weather. The DC area is as I also mentioned to you, in a rather odd position because of the watershed of the Potomac/Chesapeake system which can disrupt the movement of air currents. As far as I know from my experience and reading about the local weather there, DC has always had capricious weather. My brother used to call December "Sprimauter" in the sense that it would often be around 70° F and balmy at Christmas. 
How does this apply to the forcings associated with global warming. As a recent study has pointed out, more heat from radiative forcings has lead to warmer oceans and they in turn are affecting local weather systems. Thus global warming intensifies weather extremes, and studies of sea temperatures and their correlation to weather systems have proved this. 
You may want to restrict yourself to discussing heat in a particular place in a particular month but the article is clearly about wider weather patterns.

NASA, NOAA, the scientists who wrote the Fourth National Assessment and the IPCC special 1.5C report have a credibility problem, not Klapper!', u'recommendation_count': u'16', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547446731000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'124591524', u'id': u'124598860', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'LEDs are great.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547446543000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'124593983', u'id': u'124598832', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quietreason', u'text': u'And thus our friend drags us back towards the territory of deniers of the possibility of natural selection who love to claim that it's "only a theory", blind to "theory" as used in science - a logically consistent and coherent explanation of what is happening in that area, which has successfully passed all tests and challenges (so far).
Calling science or scientists "consecrated" is here a cheap insult, otherwise a sign of irrational credulity or cultism, but either way betraying it author's lack of grasp of the scientific method. Reading on "the scientific method" (Wikipedia might help) could save werdzwerth from exposing his unawareness of the fact that, in science if nowhere else, the words used have precise meanings. Thus what science calls a scientific theory is not just a guess but is the acknowledgement that an hypothesis has survived huge amounts of checking, testing, challenging and re-checking by countless others of all abilities and experience. Thus werdzwerth is free, and most welcome however amateur, to provide evidence or argument to rationally defeat any current scientific theory, but not to denigrate a scientific theory by nonsensically suggesting that it, or other theories, have been easily disproved. Few scientific theories have been as rigorously and repeatedly tested as those of Einstein on Relativity, but a century of intense testing has yet to find fault. And the testing will never end for as long as there is science.
Please, werdzwerth, understand that to claim that science is malleable, or that scientists play the game for personal gain, gets one nowhere. As in any pursuit there are frauds; one thinks of the brutal Trofim Lysenko, but he and many others have been exposed by the unstinting efforts (some at great personal risk) of others in those fields. Sometimes it has taken many decades, or longer, for the validity of certain hypotheses (eg Alfred Wegener on plate tectonics) to be validated and accepted by science, but great hypotheses demand great proofs. And still there are the idiots, as now when, despite the increasing accessibility of real science, we have this smug rash of precious anti-vaccination campaigners wilfully endangering not just their own kids but whole communities and, in particular, those individuals whose condition of immunosuppression prevents them from being vaccinated. We see now the deadly consequences in the current growth in measles cases, complications and deaths - thanks to the eager followers of one bent charlatan.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547444957000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14769888', u'in_reply_to': u'124597610', u'id': u'124598590', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Apart from some public speaking and teaching I don't have much experience of performance. My politician daughter was good at science in lower high school but opted for extension drama rather than a science subject in upper school. She told me in a mixture of 16 year old defiance and sheepishness but knowing she already had political ambitions I cynically replied that drama may be of more use in politics. There was some truth in my cynicism. She subsequently completed a Masters in Environmental Law occasionally ringing me for information. As tourists visiting mass graves sites in Ireland where some of my partners we did indulge in a spot of crying. As I drove with my Aranda friend across western Queensland on a cold winter's night, she went quiet as we passed each massacre site. Catalonia must have similar places.
I must confess that at 31 degrees on another humid but dry Brisbane summers days I'm sitting in front of the screen I'm typing on and the one showing Shane Mc Gowan and a cast of thousands singing "I put a spell on you."
My voluntary work in revegetating the local creeks involves some contact with a few variously disabled young men. I don't think that their severe autism, physical disabilities and deafness are a consequence of genetics. Eugenics and the elimination of the disabled and their supposed genes were a feature of European fascism last century.
My daughter's been Tourism Minister for the past 4 years. The Great Barrier Reef is the major natural feature that attracts overseas tourists to Queensland. As a biologist and a geologist I can't begin to describe its wonder and beauty. Queenslanders have looked after it for 50,000 years but now in recent years it has suffered extensive mass coral bleaching as a result of global warming.
Australian domestic real estate prices are among the highest in the world partly as a result of tax cuts for real estate investors but also as a result of skilled and business immigration. China's recent declaration of intent to make Taiwan part of China in the long run will only increase the value of my mother-in-laws property.
Old democracies should not become complacent but instead learn from new democracies about improvement. This is as much the case now as it was in the 19th and early 20th centuries when the antipodes pioneered democratic reforms such as female suffrage. Democracy can be lost as it was in fascist Spain and Queensland from 1950 to 1990 but it can also return. Keep improving it.
30 degrees C in January and February is a relief from temperatures in excess of 34 degrees which can also occur at this time of year and which now occur more often. So far since Christmas we've been lucky. Last year was a different story.
There are many tourists here too but we've yet to get to Barcelona levels. When I was a kid Brisbane CBD after noon on a Saturday was deserted.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547443593000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124580719', u'id': u'124598385', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"I like reading about amateurs and non-trained people who have shown consecrated scientists to be speaking pure fiction."
The term "consecrated" means, in relation to land or a church being declared sacred or bread and wine in Christian liturgy being declared to represent the body and blood of Christ. It's not a term used to refer to people whether they are scientists or not. You are confusing religion and science.
As already discussed all scientists are at heart professionals. The pay's not that good. A scientist is anyone who has undergone the appropriate training which whether in a formal postgraduate setting or more informally involves considerable self initiation. You have spoken of untrained people showing scientists to be speaking pure fiction. Please provide some concrete examples.
"Paleontologists were very prone to making amazing theories based on virtually no evidence only to be shown up."
Note that an hypothesis based on virtually no evidence is not a theory.
Paleontology developed in concert with geology as a means of equating the stratigraphy of sedimentary rocks. This occurred before the theory of biological evolution by natural selection explained the morphological changes seen through geological time.
My first paid work in paleontology involved Permian invertebrate foissils used to correlate the comparative ages of sedimentary rocks in Australia, China, Nepal and Thailand. Such correlations sare of prectical use to the coal, oil and gas industries.
My later work involved vertebrate fossils in the Queensland Cretaceous which eventually led to an understanding of the effect of climate change in Antarctica on biogeography of large sauropods and led on to tracking changes in small mammal populations with Pleistocene climate change.
I ask you once again to provide a concrete example of a paleontological "theory", most likely an hypothesis based on virtually no evidence.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547438454000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'an understanding of the effect of climate change in antarctica', u'effect': u'tracking changes in small mammal populations with pleistocene climate change'}, {u'cause': u'an understanding of the effect of climate change in antarctica', u'effect': u'an understanding of the effect of climate change in antarctica'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124580719', u'id': u'124597610', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'"They are not her views, " Strewth that is amazing. I only comment on areas where I have some knowledge and climate science is one of those as it is both informed by and informs the sedimentology, geomorphology, paleontology, epidemiology, ecology, genetics, evolution and paleontology that underpinned the areas I worked in and some aspects of politics and rock music in which my family are/have been involved.
I occasionally come across terms in my scientific reading which I'm not familiar with but usually find I can come to understand their meaning with some on-line searching. When I taught lower high school many years ago I remember a Spanish speaking student who commented that the scientific term for one genus of owls that I was talking about was the general Spanish word for owl. Central Park isn't a bad first choice since I'm thinking it's a station that hasn't been moved and might be somewhat insulated from the Urban Heat Island effect, plus the data record is very long. 
What I found looking at the daily TMAX variable downloaded from KNMI Data Explorer is that while there is a trend of increasing number of days exceeding average daily maximum temperature by 2 StdDevs since 1869 on an annual basis, if you look at only trends since 1940, there is actually 5 months with decreasing trends in the number of days per month exceeding 2stdDev TMAX. Those months are June, July, August, September and October.

If the major changes had happened a few decades ago, it would have been easier.

All the main UK political parties signed an agreement that coal cannot be used to produce electricity in the UK after a cut off date - 2030.
This means no change of policy if there is a change of government, and the generators have clarity.
In reality, it looks like it will be done by 2025.
A number of countries are setting cut-off dates for registering new petrol or diesel vehicles.
As a result, I suspect that by around 2030 no car maker will be putting old engine technologies in new models.
Cut-off dates worked for removing lead from petrol, and for dealing with CFCs that strip the ozone layer.
For fossil fuels we need different cut-off dates, dealing with the easier fuels and uses first.
Plenty of jobs can be created by making homes more energy efficient - fitting insulation alone is a big job creator, plus installing solar and heat pumps.
Some of these jobs are skilled, others less skilled.
UK housing is in need of a big upgrade - people are paying to heat the streets, because their homes need to be insulated.
Already UK energy generation has reduced because of better efficiency of equipment, including the use of low-energy lighting.
Using compact fluorescents to replace the incandescents around 20 years ago did reduce my overall electricity use by 10%.
Then I upgraded all my lighting with LEDs in 2016, including strip lights.
Much better.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547401673000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'their homes need to be insulated', u'effect': u'a big upgrade people are paying to heat the streets'}, {u'cause': u'better efficiency of equipment including the use of low energy lighting', u'effect': u'already uk energy generation has reduced'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'124563323', u'id': u'124585457', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'PS if you are really interested in DC area weather you should go to the Washington Post's Capital Weather Gang pages. Does your scientific knowledge go as far as setting up millions of profitable people-centred, environmentally-friendly, non-material, minimum-energy-consuming jobs to replace millions of climate-changing superfluous consumer goods ones as a way to evolve the economy away from the existing alarming one?
BQENDThe existence of any living entity tends to change the environment to some degree. As a prime example: our atmosphere once had a suffocating concentration of CO2 with almost zero oxygen but ~2.3 billion years ago underwent a massive change to oxygen-rich in the Great Oxidation Event (GOE) It appears that the GOE was triggered some 0.4 billion years earlier by the evolution of multicellular cyanobacteria - still with us today. It seems the greenhouse effect of that earlier CO2-rich atmosphere had kept the earth warm at a time when the early sun was far cooler than it is now.
That we exist today would still affect the atmosphere, earth and oceans even if we made nothing and lived by eating plants and occasional bare-handed sheep strangling, because any living thin consumes and emits. The GOE was a cataclysmic event at its time, but even that was a gradual process (it took 0.4bn years) compared with today's man-driven rates of CO2 and climate change.
Until the early C19th our effect on atmospheric CO2 was barely noticeable, swamped as it was by natural CO2-consuming processes. Even so, we were leaving various mineral footprints through our exploitation of metallurgy (lead poisoning being just one recurring issue, and having left a legible record in soil and bones since the Roman era and before, right up to today - e.g. Flint, Michigan). So a livable society without excessive CO2 emissions is possible.
What is different today is our insatiable demand for "energy" which we most readily generate from the combustion of carbon-rich natural materials found now in fossil form as coal, oil, natural gas. Before 1800 most of our combustible fuel came from felling trees which, if re-planted, recovered the CO2 emitted by our combustion of the predecessors. Today, however, we're emitting CO2 at about twice the rate at which all available natural processes can remove it (and the significant proportion of this as oceanic absorption does not exactly "remove" CO2, just holds it for later emission).
Now suppose we learn to halve, or much better than halve, our profligate CO2 emissions? That need not betoken the end of commerce, industry, travel. Indeed, we would certainly need the first 2 of these in good nick in order to achieve such a reduction, 'though far less travel of goods and people would certainly help balance the equation.
So let's have more local manufacture and agriculture; more truly community-based care; less conspicuous consumption; better-quality and longer-lasting products; more efficient and lighter vehicular transport. And let's bring back real work and skills for our young people, or those many for whom compulsorily extended school feels like a sentence of confinement, saving them from sterile addiction to smart-phones and social media and giving them real pride in achievement. Yet also encourage arts, literature and learning for learning's sake.
Do that, and we really could have a worthwhile, low-carbon economy which might, just might, have the means and brains to survive the coming climatic crisis.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547397267000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14769888', u'in_reply_to': u'124557894', u'id': u'124584168', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'correction "I think what [you] mean is . . . I observe and analyse but my bent is unannounced quite spontaneous artistic intervention in the public space to possibly create a change and a connectioin between strangers, which is very often expressed in original sequences of words. A couple of days ago my message was, "why do millions flee from public contact to their private screens?" I then overheard a young couple talking about this inside an underground carriage for several minutes. On Friday it was "why don´t tourists cry their eyes out?" and a few interesting conversations with complete strangers ensued.
Seeing the youths with severe learning difficulties where my wife works and knowing that the people who live in certain places have a reputation for oddness, I wonder how extensive and to what extent there are in-breeding and other genetic defects amongst us (and not just royal lines). 
Guilt transference is awful. As I kid my chronic sadness was taken advantage of by a sincere Christian and at one point I was directing myself to becoming a missionary and it has been a long process of liberation. I am happy I never ever took my kids to a church.
I am glad you have a positive tourism. Here, despite severe cuts in public spending which has inevitably caused unnecessary deaths, before the right wing government was replaced last year by a left-wing one it suddenly found 2,000,000,00 euros to build a new terminal at the airport to increase its capacity from 45 to 70 million, and within weeks, the rent of our flat, like everywhere here, suddenly shot up 30%! This mass tourism is a new form of territorial conquest and it is successful here not just because of the climate and the modernist architecture but because the important people here love their second residences in the country more than their flats here and working for tourism enables them to enjoy them even more. The expulsion of neighbours from other neighbourhoods does not bother them a bit. 
Any chance of a 69 year old such as myself starting his life all over again in your unique wonderful democracy? I am very tired of the "democracies" I have lived in in Europe. But not in Brisbane; 30º C is too much for me. I am not bothered by money and possessions and enjoy what has become a very rare thing, conversation with intelligent people. I think what mean is that average temperatures are warming world wide and this is particularly noticeable in the higher latitudes. Another popular phrase for this is global warming. 
According to a recent study which looked at the measurements taken by ARGOS buoys We are witnessing a continuing warming in the oceans. This is even more pronounced than the warming on land. It also has devastating effects on outlet glaciers which melt into the sea drawing down the glaciers behind them. Much of southern Greenland is now free of glaciers and the ice loss from the ice shield on northern Greenland is contributing to the rise in sea levels. A similar process is also happening to the outlet glaciers and ice shelves of Antarctica. We are due for some heavy increases in sea level in the coming decades.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547385709000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'124570417', u'id': u'124579603', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'werdzwerth', u'text': u'Some rich, powerful and stupid people such as the current US president share your ignorance Some rich, powerful and stupid people such as the current US president share your ignorance.
You wrote that in your first comment. Once again, the irony in my initial comments did not appear as irony to the reader. I am sorry about that.
I am a very active person as a vocational social artist who also has to work to finance this vocation, which is very absorbing due to the rampant consumerism and other changes here. I don´t have the time to pursue all the sciences that I need to up be to date with. I have to rely on good communicators to lighten my load. Here people are bombarded with subtle sophisticated consumer and other vested interest messages like never ever before, which as I age and lose physical energy, makes this vocational task more demanding.
My performing means I have interest in psychology, psychiatry, sociology, anthropology, contemporary anthropoloigy, economcs,genetics, communications, mass media, politics, technological changes, the industry of mass tourism, the history of people rather than of monarchs, and how to turn whatever into whatever type of short performance wherever I will be, and a very long so on, not forgetting observing the behaviour of people and the public places we are in.
 Teaching retired people English from scratch makes for a lot of other demands on me. I even don´t much like the jargon of linguists of English as they use classical terms and other terms that don´t feel right or are not very useful for my students. I use terms like "samesound" and "samespelling", which do not require me to think "now what does this term mean?" Why invent new terms of retricted use if in our everyday language we have terms that already exist and mean the same or if we can use everyday words to coin new terms that are inastantly understandable? 
My interests go beyond the environment, to seeking how to replace soul-destroying factory jobs and wasteful consumerism with very satisfying jobs for people that enrich us as humans. One of my recent messages was the question "why don´t we make "being good" a well-paid job?"
Now, tongue in cheek, I think environmentalists should seriously, perhaps full-time, study money and non-money-based economies so as to release hundreds of millions of humans from the profitable drudgery that is causing a lot of problems for the environment as well as these humans so that they could lead worthwhile lives from Monday morning onwards! 
Again, thank you.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547385492000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the rampant consumerism and other changes here', u'effect': u'very absorbing'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'a lot of problems for the environment as well as these humans'}], u'author_id': u'12826250', u'in_reply_to': u'124576496', u'id': u'124579459', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'He has a valid point and that is that are are still alot of sceptics out there. Cliate experts need to be more careful.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547384815000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'124567767', u'id': u'124579080', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Science changes by the experimental collection of evidence. The physics of subatomic particles and astronomy are good cases in point as are the fields of plate tectonics, evolution, biogeography and climate science. Anyone who learns the science of an area of investigation and collects and analyses experimental data is a scientist whether they are what you describe as an amateur or not. My colleague who has continued by vertebrate palaeontology work of 35 years ago published his first scientific paper as a schoolboy. He was what you would call an amateur. Science is not a highly paid career. We are all enthusiastic amateurs.
My fully initiated Aranda friend was an anthropologist married to a Catalan bloke who sadly died with the very start of this millennium. She sent his ashes back to Catolonia as is her peoples custom. Human evolution and physical anthropology has revealed an interesting an varied hominid bush. I still spend time in the trees near my place. As a geologist I was involved in the training of Chinese geologists whose stratigraphic work underpinned the Chinese industrial revolution in coming decades.
As a biologists I make little distinction between the tissue of plants, animals and fungi. As an atheist I'm not prone to guilt transference from Christians.
My daughter's party is the world's oldest Labor Party formed in the Queensland town of Barcaldine under the Tree of Knowledge in 1892 during the shearers' strike.
The decision to close car factories in Australia was made by the multinational companies that owned them as they relocated to the Asian mainland closer to rapidly expanding markets for their products. Providing jobs for retrenched workers in such cases involves cooperation between the companies, communities and governments concerned. Government has a role as does education.
My cities streets and educational institutions are full of tourists and overseas students but they represent a major industry which helps pays for those streets, educational institutions and hospitals. The locals don't miss out and many of the visitors become locals as my partner's father did. I more easily recognise Chinese languages these days than European ones. My Aranda friends daughter learnt Catalan over a few months when living with her father's family. For the last 200 years Australia has had many migrants who speak many different languages including my sadly departed Catalan friend and my friend of over 50 years who Shanghaiese ancestors came over with the mid-19th century gold rushes.
I am better at distinguishing', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547384728000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124571108', u'id': u'124579026', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'werdzwerth', u'text': u'Frankly, I have had a bad time here since my initial posting, and what worries me far more than the threat of climate change is our lack of intelligent, from all angles, response, as if just reading the science and voting for a green party is enough.
 I wish we 7,000,000,000 humans had the sense to, at least somewhere, decide that specific jobs will generate a money supply to pay the salaries and costs of this job plus an added profit to be invested in creating more such profitable jobs. This has got nothing to do with climate change directly but with how we use this wonderful tool called democracy, rather more a concept than a fact in reality (glorified plutocracies or partycracies), to set up a bespoke economy that humanises us through the work we do and which is in harmony with the environment as much as possible. Surely there are a few of us who are capable of going beyond this wish to actually turn it into a reality?
A look at our history shows we humans have had an awful time at the hands of other humans and how much damage has accumulated within us, that we don´t know of, which could be identified and dealt with because we have decided that this work will be also a part of the money supply, or some other workable arrangement? 
What with technological advances threatening to leave even climate change scientists out of work some day soon, there is an even greater need to create "green" jobs that only we humans can do. 
I am saying this part with my tongue in my cheek, so don´t get me wrong; rather than me reading up the climate change science, it perhaps would be more useful if these scientists, along with everyone else, became experts in money-based and non-money-based economies so as to devise the economy or economies I have been writing about!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547381786000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we have decided that this work will be also a part of the money supply', u'effect': u'which could be identified and dealt with'}], u'author_id': u'12826250', u'in_reply_to': u'124573377', u'id': u'124577300', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'What have I done as the one person who has made you feel like a moron? I explained that we all start as lay people when it comes to learning what scientific language and methodology means.
I share your interest in the evolution of languages and commonly come across similar phonic and meaning clusters and phylogenies. My cousin taught English as a second (or fourth or fifth) language and helped set up schools in China way back when a trunk line phone call to China from Australia had to be booked days in advance. In our retirement she shares my obsession with the local rainforest. The science never ends.
Why is the language and methodology of climate science difficult for you to understand? If you can learn to understand the meaning of the language of one professional area why can't you learn the language and methodology of climate science?
My grandkids are learning to pronounce written English words using the phonics method you describe. Our skinny boy has a thing for sharks and other large carnivorous phot or fish.
The people depend on the economy and the economy depends on people. Both people and the economy depend on the environment. Reading the G here is a nightmare as it is!
I am interested in a mass replacement of emissions jobs by non-emissions jobs through a change, which could be dead simple, in the economy so that people-centred jobs that are environmentally-friendly but which currently are not done, either because they are not profitable or we are not aware that these jobs could and should exist, will be done because they are profitable. I am talking about socially engineering human evolution along these lines and this environmental crisis is an excellent moment to change the course of the future for ever.
I want to close factories and shopping centres that deal with contaminating superfluous consumerism because we have used our collective intelligence to adapt the economy so that work by people directly on other people will be done because it is profitable (because we decide this and back this decisiion by Law), these profits then being used to permit non material economic growth.
I am finding that environmentalists don´t know what I am talking about or that they are fatalist, "it is too late". 
If this situation is that serious all avenues should be pursued , and with urgency.
I would like our money supply to come from people doing such work, you know, caring for dependent people, simply being parents, perhaps a one day a week paid job for all called Democracy, and so on. If factories and shopping centres can be closed down because we have switched to working in a profitable people-centred economy, by how much could emissions be reduced because resources and energy are not being used up, and by how much could human happiness be increased because we are working directly with each other on each other for the intellectual, emotional, social, creative, etc, benefit of each other?
 For example, we become able to invent an infinite number of interesting games with just one pack of cards rather than going to a shop to buy our very own wonderful selection of table games in large boxes with large plastic trays and bits of metal and wood, and for which we need to buy an extra cupboard for them. Environmentalists are the ones trying hard to preserve a planet on which the conditions are as beneficial as possible for human life. An awful lot of what is going on right now - by burning fossil fuels for energy, for example - is the exact opposite.
You don't need to start reading scientific papers to get a reasonable understanding of the latest information. Read the Environment section of the Guardian. Subscribe to the daily email from Carbon Brief. Subscribe to the daily email from Unearthed. Subscribe to the weekly email from Climate Action. Each of these offers neat summaries of recent updates in a digestible fashion, with links to more details. If you want to read the scientific papers, some of them are paywalled, others are readily available.
It feels to me as if you know there is an issue to be dealt with but not why, and what needs to be done.
If you would like a tough read that is based on the science but somewhat more accessible, try the IPCC's recent 1.5 degree report for policymakers, published in October last year. I don't think so. More a general move away from blogs and refocussing on print media. Amazingly and indeed shamefully they didn't even bother to tell Dana and co! Dana wrote about it on Skeptical Science:
https://www.skepticalscience.com/guardian-blog-eulogy.html', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547375549000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10025860', u'in_reply_to': u'124556911', u'id': u'124573298', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'reinhardpolley', u'text': u'Oh dear, you're not fooling anyone with your whataboutery and strawman arguments.
