description: Fears rise for homeless and vulnerable people as communities brace for another week of relentless hot weather
og_fields.og:description: Fears rise for homeless and vulnerable people as communities brace for another week of relentless hot weather
og_fields.og:title: ‘It’s like hell here’: Australia bakes as record temperatures nudge 50C
text:
It was 48.9C last Tuesday in Port Augusta, South Australia, an old harbour city that now harvests solar power. Michelle Coles, the owner of the local cinema, took off her shoes at night to test the concrete before letting the dogs out. “People tend to stay at home,” she said. “They don’t walk around when it’s like this.”
It’s easy to see why: in the middle of the day it takes seconds to blister a dog’s paw or child’s foot. In Mildura, in northern Victoria, last week gardeners burned their hands when they picked up their tools, which had been left in the sun at 46C. Fish were dying in the rivers.
Almost every day last week a new heat record was broken in Australia. They spread out, unrelenting, across the country, with records broken for all kinds of reasons – as if the statistics were finding an infinite series of ways to say that it was hot.
The community of Noona – population 14 – reached the highest minimum ever recorded overnight in Australia – 35.9C was the coldest it got, at 7am on Friday. It was 45C by noon.
A record fell on Tuesday in Meekatharra in Western Australia – the highest minimum there ever recorded (33C). Another fell on Wednesday, 2,000 miles away, in Albury, New South Wales – their hottest day (45.6C).
It was 45C or higher for four consecutive days in Broken Hill – another record – and more than 40C for the same time period in Canberra, the nation’s capital. Nine records fell across NSW on Wednesday alone. Back in Port Augusta, Tuesday was the highest temperature since records began in 1962.
In the Niagara Cafe in Gundagai, whose claim to fame is that the former Australian prime minister John Curtin once popped in during the second world war, Tina Loukissas turned off the deep fryer, then the grill.
“It feels like you’ve walked into a sauna,” she said. “When it’s getting up to 43C or 44C, because you have all these machines going, the air conditioning isn’t coping very well.
“We’ve got tables outside that nobody has sat at for the last couple of days … You’d be crazy to sit outside on a day like today.”
In Mildura, Tolga Ozkuzucu, owner of Top Notch Gardens, had the misfortune to be working outdoors.
“It’s been like hell,” he said. “You have to try to leave your tools in the shade. If you don’t, it burns your fingers. There’s not much you can do.
“I try to start as early as I can. I’m not going to risk my body and health. People here are very understanding of that because they know how hot it is … nobody wants to be outside when it’s 46C.”
In South Australia, they declared a “code red” across Adelaide, the state capital. Homelessness services were working overtime and the Red Cross started calling round a list of 750 people who were deemed especially vulnerable.
At the Australian Open in Melbourne, only the sea breeze kept the temperature below 40C. At Adelaide’s Tour Down Under, a bike race, it was 41C.
On Monday last week the hottest spot in New South Wales was Menindee, a river town that feeds the country’s largest water system, the Murray-Darling basin. It was 45C. It climbed to 47C on Wednesday, and by Thursday the fish were gasping.
Australia’s native Murray cod can live for decades under normal conditions, growing all the while. The oldest are a metre long, with heavy white bellies that have to be held with both hands. Last week, hundreds died, choked of oxygen due to an algal bloom that fed and grew in the heat, and collapsed when temperatures dipped.
Blue-green algae flourishes in hot, slow-moving water. Then, when temperatures inevitably drop, the algae dies and becomes a food source for bacteria, who multiply and starve the river of oxygen. The fish rise to the surface.
The mass fish death has reignited a debate over water management in the region, where cotton farmers upstream have been accused of taking more water than they should.
The heat is not the root cause, the locals stress. But the five punishing days settling over the river have not made it better. Last Thursday the cod were up near the surface and struggling. On Friday, it was 45C again. In Menindee, the locals believe the fish kill will happen again, with temperatures in the 40s expected to continue into this week. The water will be running hot.
But away from the Darling, Michelle Coles from Port Augusta says she is used to the heat.
“I didn’t think it was that hot yesterday, if you want an honest answer,” she said last Wednesday, the day after the temperature hit 48.9C.
“Yesterday at the cinema, it was very quiet. People tend to stay home. We’re quite used to it. Once it’s over 40, it’s hot.
“We’re conditioned to it. Honestly, I’d much rather be in 48C heat in Port Augusta than in the city. You’ve got so much concrete and it’s closed in, but here it’s quite open.
“You just don’t stand out in the sun though. That would be stupid.”

This is because we are finding out that we can make changes with relatively minor inconvenience to most ordinary people if the right kind of policies are in place, the right kind of funding and so on. 
James Hansen makes a special note of this in his book. "I believe the biggest obstacle to solving global warming is the role of money in politics, the undue sway of special interests."
If we have a group of people at the top who are not engaging with the threat on any level then we all pay for the consequences - the wrong government is the worst situation because these people act as a roadblock for change. And we have the technology, we have the means to make the changes - but if everything is mismanaged then no-one can move forward. I think this is going to become more and more relevant - no matter what the outcomes are. Because by creating the space to make the changes necessary, then change will happen; and in many different ways. In effect, he doesn't believe the worst projections of future warming are possible. Its difficult to understand the methodology of how we could end up with more extreme temperature changes, mainly because the paleoclimate data has some interesting inconsistencies. Unfortunately; most of these have been ironed out at this stage. So in this way; if you want to know what the worst scenarios are; then you might want to wade through the political stuff in James Hansen's book. However; this is really a confirmation of what Tim Flannery outlines, and its again relating to feedback events - essentially the difference between carbon dioxide and methane. 
So if you want to get to the more extreme possibilities and think about that, then read James Hansen's book; Curt Stagers book and relate that to Tim Flannery's earlier book and then you have most of the details.
The important element which is still not clear is how fast this could happen. I think we should all agree, however, that the risks are very, very big; and considering the world has the money to shift to renewable energy, in many different forms - we should use this money now. Essentially, hydrogen is where we should be spending money right now; we need a wholesale shift from hydrocarbons to hydrogen - and the faster this happens the sooner we stop emissions.
I suppose the good news is that this is starting to happen. However, it is not just electricity - electricity alone won't save us.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548078005000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'mainly the paleoclimate data has some interesting inconsistencies', u'effect': u'how we could end up with more extreme temperature changes'}], u'author_id': u'101308278', u'in_reply_to': u'124924306', u'id': u'124925509', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lagado', u'text': u'"Lomborg has promoted the controversial idea of geo-engineering to address climate change. However the economics of climate change is really where we should start to understand more; because this is ultimately how it effects the average person.
Here is what I read:
A Blueprint for a Safer Planet: How to Manage Climate Change and Create a New Era of Progress and Prosperity - Nicolas SternThe Burning Question - Mike Berners-LeeThe Weather Makers: The History and Future Impact of Climate Change - Tim FlanneryTropic of Chaos: Climate Change and the New Geography of Violence - Christian ParentiIntroduction to Modern Climate Change - Mark DiesendorfWhose Crisis, Whose Future - Susan GeorgeStorms of My Grandchildren - James HansenSix Degrees - Mark Lynas Climate Shock: The Economic Consequences of a Hotter Planet - Gernot Wagner, Martin L. he is a political scientist.
BQEND
No he's not. He has never published a single academic paper in political science, or on any subject related to climate change.
Thousands of academics have, so there are literally thousands of academics more qualified on the subject than Lomborg.
So why are you bringing up a non-expert?
BQSTART
have you read about what was the final outcome of the Danish committee?
BQEND
Yes they repeatedly upheld their decision.
Lomborg, a non-expert in climate change economics and policy, bases his non-expert opinions on systematic misrepresentations of climate science, according to The Danish Committee for Scientific Dishonesty.
And they are hardly the only scientists who have reviewed Lomborg's representations of climate science and found them fraudulent (see link above).
So why are you bringing up a non-expert who tells lies about climate science?
BQSTART
What is interesting, is that his premise on where is money best spent is given hardly any interest.
BQEND
It is not interesting, because his premise cannot pass review by a single one of his peers. No fellow expert finds any of his theories compelling, which is why he presents them not to his peers but to laymen via his popular science books.
95% of his peers who actually do follow the proper scientific and academic process for scientific debate, disagree with him. All of these individuals are far more qualified on this issue, having actually studied in the field and had their theories pass scientific muster.
BQSTART
Is the academic environment biased against him?
BQEND
It is a moot point, he bypasses academia when publishing his ideas. He refuses to subject himself to the minimum standards of evidence and debate.
BQSTART
Saw that Australian university had to back out from a programme becuase of student disquiet.
BQEND
Of course, millions of dollars were being given to someone who has no expertise whatsoever in their claimed academic area by a government hostile to the science of climate change.
As I have pointed out ad-nauseum, there are literally thousands of academics far more qualified to run an academic institute dedicated to climate policy - e.g. people who have actually studied it and published on the matter.
As I pointed out above, Lomborg began life basing his musings about climate policy on denial of the Greenhouse Effect - you are talking about the crudest form of science denial. This alone should be enough to colour his musings for good.
So you have someone with no expertise whatsoever in climate science, policy or economics, who refuses to publish their views in scientific journals (as has been basic practice for several centuries), a person whom climate scientists, published literature reviews and independent ethics bodies claim systematically misrepresents climate science, and who is paid $750,000 per year by an unknown list of donors (more than any actual expert in the field) in the context of billions of dollars paid to misrepresent climate science by fossil fuel interests.
But, again, it really comes down to this: Lomborg has never studied climate science, policy or economics and he has never published an academic paper on climate science, policy or economics so... why are you bringing up a non-expert?

How much is it worth spending now to avoid the worst effects of climate change in the future. 
In my opinion it is worth spending a lot to avoid climate change (so, this is called a 'low' discount rate). But the problem today is that the options for just spending money and 'fixing' the problem are very limited; we are still waiting for any country to decarbonise successfully. 
Really; you could say that it is not a straight carbon tax, in my opinion. It is putting in place effective policies; and the main one (which every country will have to do) is to replace methane for heating and industry, with hydrogen. This is going to be a little bit complicated, no matter how we do it; and it will require cooperation between countries to see out successfully, if we are not to try to capitalise on each others efforts.
But this is the central component. This is and the use of hydrogen in transport; which is now well on its way with recent announcements from Hyundai, China and Japan. There will be a flood of cheap fuel cell cars and we should not wait until they arrive to build the infrastructure.
But I believe the damage will be severe, and we should spend money on what we genuinely need to do now because we may not have the money in the future to make the fundamental changes necessary. I also believe that this is a very good reason for the global economy to remain going strong just so that we we have the money to convert all these industrial plants and so on away from fossil fuels. If we are poor, then we will never be able to do this. So its that balance between maintaining a functional economy just until we have all industry, heating etc decarbonised and switched to hydrogen. 
Both CCS and electrolysis will be used in order to decarbonise our gas grids; but the low cost of renewable electricity (and electrolysers) and the use of hydrogen in transport (and fuel cells for heating etc) should necessitate generic use of hydrogen only. BQEND

BQEND

BQEND
His entire body of work has never been published in any form of academic journal. Why even bring him up?
Meanwhile, an actual peer-reviewed summary of his work concluded:
BQSTART
The Skeptical Environmentalist is not a reliable source of information and certainly not a work of science. Too often Lomborg does not seem to be looking for truth and validation but just wants to find support for a particular conviction. In his interactions with reviewers he frequently shows a mere interest to win a debate at any cost rather than to advance – his own and public – knowledge. Of course, given a lack of relevant education and research experience (and peer-reviewed publications) in natural, environmental and social sciences, Lomborg could not be expected to accomplish the formidable task of covering the wide range of themes addressed in his book... it is just a polemic.
BQEND', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548131708000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2484923', u'in_reply_to': u'124947151', u'id': u'124949986', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Regarding deep ocean ventilation there's another problem besides meltwater off of the ice sheets.
The surface waters of the ocean are warmer and hence less dense than the waters at depth. So it takes a lot of energy to turn the ocean over. This process takes around 1,000 years.
As the surface now warms faster than the depths it takes more energy to turn the ocean over, so it gets more strongly stratified.
Important nutrient-rich waters from the depths slow their journey to great fisheries like the anchoveta, and oxygen-rich surface waters slow their journey to the depths.
Bad things happen when the ocean turns anoxic. Like perhaps 3 mass extinctions.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548131105000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'124946304', u'id': u'124949880', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Davemcgruer', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

My memory ain't what it used to be.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548111814000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'124944380', u'id': u'124946304', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"Their work ultimately confirmed the theory that the earth's irregular orbital motions account for the bizarre climatic changes which bring on ice ages."
But what brings on the demise of ice ages - known as deglaciation - during which the Earth transitions from a glacial period or ice age to an interglacial period such as the one we have been in for the last 9,000 years?
The Earth's irregular combined orbital and axial motions can at times, as at present and for the next 50,000 and more, cause a steady decline in the insolation that occurs due to the angle at which sunlight strikes in summer at high latitudes in the Northern Hemisphere (Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation or NHHLSI). This declining insolation produces cooling of the climate at those high northern latitudes and results in incomplete melting of the previous winter's snow and hence gradual build up of snow which eventually results in widespread glaciation at those latitudes burying peatlands, increasing albedo or reflectance, reducing oxidation of those peatlands at the same time as peatlands spread south sequestering more carbon. Reduced albedo and increased Carbon sequestration lead to lower atmospheric CO2, typically a drop from around 280 ppm to around 200 ppm, reducing the Earth's greenhouse effect and causing global cooling.
The demise of the last ice age or glacial period which occurred between 19,000 and 9,000 years ago was initiated by a peak in Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation which caused a meltwater pulse into the North Atlantic from the North American and Eurasian continental glacial ice sheets. This stopped the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation, switching off the deep water currents that cool the Southern Ocean, resulting in oxidation of carbon rich oceanic oozes, causing an increase in atmospheric CO2 from 200 ppm to 280 ppm over the next 10,000 years and consequent global warming which caused the bulk of the melting and retreat of the vast glacial ice sheets which covered the high latitudes of North America and Eurasia.
Global warming due to an increase in atmospheric CO2 ended the ice ages or glacial periods after orbital and axial motions initiated the process.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': can you help?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548106899000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15275664', u'in_reply_to': u'124943656', u'id': u'124944318', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The political parties, which are opposed to both practical means of reducing CO2 emissions and research and development into new means, are also opposed to measures that help poorer people. The major cause of high fuel prices is declining supply of crude oil.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548106162000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124934171', u'id': u'124944019', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Brainingtree', u'text': u'"I understand he is a political scientist who works with economists" - my comment from above', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548106086000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15275664', u'in_reply_to': u'124943489', u'id': u'124943983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'It's far cheaper and quicker to get non-fossil energy to poorer people in poorer countries.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548105683000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'124934171', u'id': u'124943859', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"why cut fossil fuel?"

Why not cut its combustion?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548105152000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124934171', u'id': u'124943656', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Bjorn is not an economist.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548104692000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124924306', u'id': u'124943489', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'joshdking', u'text': u'Some excellent suggestions here.
Although not strictly climate mitigation economics, I thoroughly recommend Drawdown. It makes for excellent daily reading, since you can read one or two of the 100 solutions to global warming more or less in the time it takes to have a coffee and breakfast. 
I did notice your list includes much work by Nicholas Stern. This prompted me to comment and suggest that people briefly familiarise themselves with the significance of "discount rates" in the economics of climate mitigation. This is because it is still a source of major contention between mainstream economists. For example, William Nordhaus (economics Nobel laureate) disagrees with Stern's discount rate. 
And there are, of course, still many disagreements in the economics that desperately require consensus for policy to move forward.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548104199000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it is still a source of major contention between mainstream economists', u'effect': u'this is'}], u'author_id': u'16672722', u'in_reply_to': u'124923816', u'id': u'124943277', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'Thanks for the article. Have you seen anything?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548104015000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'124942191', u'id': u'124943205', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'thebowsie', u'text': u'BQSTART
Why no mention of Bjorn Lomborg?
BQEND
Why would Bjørn Lomborg deserve a mention?
"Lomborg is not a climate scientist or economist and has published little or no peer-reviewed research on environmental or climate policy. His extensive and extensively documented, errors and misrepresentations, which are aimed at a lay audience, "follow a general pattern" of minimizing the need to cut carbon emissions."
You cannot be an expert on climate science or policy if you do not publish peer-reviewed articles on the subject - this alone is enough to dismiss him out of hand. There are literally thousands of actual academics more qualified on the subject, 95% of whom disagree with him and have actual published records to back them up.
However more damningly and the reason why Lomborg should be dismissed not just as a non-expert but with derision and contempt is because his most prominent work is riddled with systematic errors and misrepresentations of the actual science, which considering the pattern of errors, are essentially lies he tells about climate science to justify his non peer-reviewed pronouncements.
If there were not untold billions of dark money being poured in climate science denial, Lomborg would not have a platform of any kind.
He should be treated like the for-rent carnival barker he is.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548103604000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'his most prominent work is riddled with systematic errors and misrepresentations of the actual science are essentially lies he tells about climate science to justify his non peer reviewed pronouncements', u'effect': u'however more damningly and the reason why lomborg should be dismissed not just as a non - expert but with derision and contempt is'}], u'author_id': u'2484923', u'in_reply_to': u'124924306', u'id': u'124943055', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rgilyead', u'text': u'For a thoroughly realistic extrapolation of the effects of climate change I recommend Chris Beckett’s America City (https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/nov/09/america-city-chris-beckett-review)Mix Trump with Facebook et al and this is what we will get', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548101968000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10493280', u'id': u'124942408', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jan/21/greenland-ice-melting-faster-than-scientists-previously-thought-study
Faster than expected is to be expected.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548101400000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'124941711', u'id': u'124942191', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'Yesterdays C02 ppm reading broke 412. The recent 413 reading may have been an outlier. Well, here's another one. It's a long way to April.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548100108000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'124937591', u'id': u'124941711', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'anon-113452a530181', u'text': u'Flannery, Mann and Goodell are all excellent choices.
Meanwhile, the crisis grinds on. As DWilliams notes below, a dearth of policy and political will lies at its core. We could be starting the energy transition now on a myriad fronts if governments (national, state, borough, city) functioned properly and worked in tandem. As it is, much sterling effort to curb climate change is sporadic and small; and many governments are in thrall to fossil fuels. A number of national economies are at least partly defined by them (Canada, US, China, India, Nigeria, the Gulf states, parts of Central Asia, Norway, etc etc). 
As with CFC eradication, the effort has to be global. But CFCs were deployed mainly in fridges, freezers and air conditioners. By contrast, petroleum products have seeped into society through transport, energy, manufacturing and beyond; and fossil-fuel companies are corrupt and intractable. Big Ag - a vast source of methane emissions through livestock production - is just as corrupt and intractable. Manufacturing of useless consumables, unnecessary shipping, landfill - there are scores of other emissions sources that will not halt because of a kind of fatal apathy: this is the way it's all set up now, they'll lose money, and all the rest of the business-as-usual litany.
All of that makes the transition to renewables - including, as Nicholas Stern has pointed out, hundreds of thousands of new jobs in innovation and industry - much more difficult than it should be. Governmental and industrial unwillingness and corruption also mean that societies don't have the subsidies they need to afford installing top-notch solar panels, re-engineering their homes for energy efficiency, or make other changes necessary to radically whittle emissions down. 
During WWII, people made the changes necessary (blackout windows, backyard shelters, stockpiling) to survive, and the government conducted a vast public-information campaign to ensure it. Faced with this enemy - us - too many want to pass the buck and too few are are unwilling to take governments to task over the needed large-scale shift. The world has made energy transitions before, although always to harmful sources. It's shocking, yet predictable - given the prevalence of those dual engines, greed and fear - that we cannot yet collectively seem to transition to benign ones.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548096894000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1759344', u'id': u'124939983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'glacier', u'text': u'It is extremely good - but only for those that are interested in proxies and less interested in forcings.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548096729000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'124935443', u'id': u'124939895', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'funyon', u'text': u'Being the Change: Live Well and Spark a Climate Revolution by NASA climate scientist Peter Kalmus. In addition to a clear explanation of the science, it talks about what one person can actually do.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548094976000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15956952', u'id': u'124938827', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The renowned glaciologist Richard Alley wrote an excellent book on climate change for the general public titled “The Two-Mile Time Machine: Ice Cores, Abrupt Climate Change, and Our Future”.
He also has a number of presentations on YouTube. He’s probably the best speaker on this subject that I’m aware of.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548093079000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'124937591', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'Lomborg's arguments continually change as the old ones become untenable, but the end result is always the same.
He used to claim global warming wasn't a serious problem.
Then it was a serious problem, but not as serious as others.
Then it was just as serious as others, but there were better ways to fix it than cutting fossil fuels.
Now the best way to fix it is to cut fossil fuels, but not until we've done more R&D.
As far as I know he isn't paid by the FF industry, but he sure does a good impersonation of someone who is.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548092128000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'124934171', u'id': u'124936870', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'Global warming is causing crop failure due to drought and heat. People who live in areas that are primarily depending on subsistence farming will either move or starve. Because we have a global economy, markets will be negatively affected. Capitalism and it's attendant fiat currencies live on a razor's edge. There must be growth. 
Humanity may be able to survive the increased heat but if insects die then the entire food chain that relies on eating insects dies as well. 
Given this scenario markets will fail. There will be many fewer jobs. There will be depression. One things for certain. You will get to know who your good neighbors are.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548091978000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'global warming', u'effect': u'crop failure due to drought and heat'}, {u'cause': u'drought and heat', u'effect': u'crop failure'}], u'author_id': u'13899889', u'id': u'124936758', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Karadjordjevic', u'text': u''Reconstructing Quaternary Environments' by Lowe and Walker is pretty good.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548090309000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101245085', u'id': u'124935443', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'partoftheproblem', u'text': u'I've just been re-reading the Greg Mandel trilogy by Peter F Hamilton, science fiction written early to mid 90's, it's interesting take on how climate change might alter the country. It's after climate change has had a major impact, post-warming they call it, with mass migration causes problem and some areas in the UK uninhabitable.
There's a federal Europe thrown in (with Euro-Francs) and the first book starts 10 years after the collapse of socialist government.
Might not be the best set of books to understand what's happening, but they are enjoyable and have a changed/struggling UK as a backdrop.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548089416000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'mass migration', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'16171854', u'id': u'124934656', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Steve Jones', u'text': u'Your post seems to say that there is a fixed amount of money and more money going into R&D means less for direct spending on reducing poverty.It reads kinda strange.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548089046000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11108528', u'in_reply_to': u'124934011', u'id': u'124934307', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Brainingtree', u'text': u'but that is not an argument but insinuation.
why cut fossil fuel?should poorer people pay more for fuel in the short term, or should we invest in R&D to develop cheap alternatives for the future?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548088901000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15275664', u'in_reply_to': u'124933623', u'id': u'124934171', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Brainingtree', u'text': u'from above:"i thought his main principle was how to spend money and that it should be on R&D of alternative energy." -', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548088740000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15275664', u'in_reply_to': u'124931416', u'id': u'124934011', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'scubadoc', u'text': u'Stick with Stan: it’s much more fun:
https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/mar/03/new-york-2140-by-kim-stanley-robinson-review', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548088481000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2000661', u'id': u'124933762', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Vlamingo', u'text': u'BQSTART

Pretty much everything Lomborg says on the subject ultimately comes back to the same thing: there's no need at present to cut fossil fuel use, and doing so would be bad.
As has often been pointed out, he invariably does precisely what the fossil fuel industry would want a PR person to do.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548088352000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15902664', u'in_reply_to': u'124924306', u'id': u'124933623', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: The novelist shares her favourite books to help us cope with how our world is changing – and inspire everyone to do something about it
og_fields.og:description: The novelist shares her favourite books to help us cope with how our world is changing – and inspire everyone to do something about it
og_fields.og:title: Annie Proulx on the best books to understand climate change
text:
Today we live with non-stop special events of fire, flood, mud slide, rising water, whirling hurricanes, toxic algae blooms, unprecedented droughts. That word “unprecedented” is coming to define our time. Most of us were short-changed by educations that ignored ecology. We need clear explanations of climate change, what it means and how to cope with it.
Tim Flannery, an Australian mammalogist, is a supple writer with a wide-ranging and questioning mind. His 2005 The Weather-Makers gave lucid and easily understandable explanations of climate change, both a history and a look into what might come next. It is still a basic starting point.
Climate scientist Michael Mann and Washington Post cartoonist Tom Toles collaborated on The Madhouse Effect. It is drawn straight from the frontline of the climate wars. In trenchant sentences the authors skate out, hockey sticks swinging, and scythe the legs from under the cabal of vested interests, venal payola scientists and shadowy political éminences grises. They name names and present a player list as well as the irrefutable tough news. 
The Water Will Come by Jeff Goodell is especially good at showing the daunting complexity of solutions to on-the-ground problems in places such as Miami Beach, Alaska, New York, Venice and remote islands whose residents have nowhere to go. Here are real-world headaches of flood insurance, transportation, nuclear reactors on eroding shorelines, the tendency to rebuild rather than rethink following disasters.
Amitav Ghosh’s The Great Derangement: Climate Change and the Unthinkable is literate and probing. He presents a critical discussion of the Paris Agreement vis-a-vis Pope Francis’s Laudato Si’. As for the “unthinkable” in his book’s title, it is left to the reader to decide which of several dreadful outcomes he means. I concluded one was truly unthinkable.
Charles Wohlforth’s The Whale and the Supercomputer: On the Northern Front of Climate Change looks at two different and sporadically intermeshed groups – science experts from distant universities and local whale-hunter people of the Arctic with millennia of ice experience. The cooperations and rivalries between local residents and academic scientists matters in the way we handle the hellishly complex changes bearing down. Both groups work towards understanding how best to survive.
Peter Brannen’s The Ends of the World is a witty review of Earth’s previous global species extinctions. His discussions with experts present the evidences in the ancient rocks showing that in the vast life collapses of the geologic past CO2 was a major operative and thus a patterned back-story to our present situation; climate change extinction is new to humans but not to the planet. It puts a lid on the hubristic belief that Earth exists solely for human use.
Poet-linguist Robert Bringhurst and classicist philosopher Jan Zwicky offer a meditative approach in their Learning to Die: Wisdom in the Age of Climate Crisis. Bringhurst’s essay The Mind of the Wild outlines the liminal relations between the natural world and humans. Here the wild is the bedrock of human ethical and moral values.
He suggests that to understand what is happening we should individually “practise thinking like an ecosystem ... ” by “spending a day in the wilds – alone with reality, keeping quiet and letting things unfold”. This exercise can clarify our thinking and open windows of perception. Zwicky’s essay A Ship from Delos guides us towards ways to live and know the situation of climate change. Her beautiful recasting of Socratic excellences – awareness, courage, self-control, justice, contemplation and compassion – can profoundly shape our inner selves.
• Barkskins by Annie Proulx is published by 4th Estate. To order a copy for £8.79 (RRP £9.99), go to guardianbookshop.com or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&p over £15, online orders only. Phone orders min. p&p of £1.99.

[{u'author': u'Eisenhower', u'text': u'We need both radical population control and sound environmental policies (alternative energies, the end of plastic, more taxes on cars and cruise ships, and most importantly an end to the industrial animal meat production).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548342336000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4079434', u'in_reply_to': u'124953731', u'id': u'125052307', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Eisenhower', u'text': u'I agree with you on the population level.
But it’s one of the reasons I vote with the left! I can’t support any party that works against birth control and abortion rights.
Not only do I find it immoral but it’s one of the biggest hurdle to sound environmental policies.
You can’t be pro life and an environmentalist. We haven't developed ways of applying our so called social values in the same way as our science works. We say we value egalitarianism and freedom [Barnaby this morning!]. Yet do we evaluate our legal, industrial, political, tax policies to align them to this? The only criteria we use really consistently is profit; the bottom line. There's been a failed attempt to extend it to include social and environmental criteria. I don't know that we even have a name for it. I called it a social conscience. Don't confuse weather with the climate.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548194677000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16662131', u'in_reply_to': u'124952179', u'id': u'124982941', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'I do agree with you, absolutely, and it's great to meet people like you pushing against the tide and asking people to think, because that's where "the system" evolved from in the first place. By no means take my suggestions the wrong way - you obviously are already thinking seriously about this stuff, and I'm looking for allies to talk with, not adversaries to spar with. Therein lies more madness...
The first obstacle to getting people to think about economics is to believe they have the right and the ability to do it. As users of our shared economic system, we should all be encouraged and enabled to do just that.
I like your metaphor about the mansion fire. No talk of prosecuting the landowner with the lighter-fluid and matches in his back pocket, either *chuckle* Very apt since land is what it's all about. Always was, always will be. Its domination, and now its destruction :(
Henry George was in a hurry too. While you may not be persuaded that land-rent can fund civilization than all the combined taxes today, you have to admit that a single step change to the taxation system could certainly be enacted by any country in any election, at any time.
Something to put in the toolbox, at the very least. Capitalism, Socialism and Communism isn't the whole ball game. No doctrine ever dominates completely, thank God, but if it's not in the mix it cannot even influence. I look forward to a good read.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548228611000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15962138', u'in_reply_to': u'124967083', u'id': u'124989059', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'Cheers Otpus1. Total heartfelt agreement. The momentum of "the system" probably will not be stopped, since we're already half-way down the cliff, telling ourselves the vertigo is just performance anxiety over [insert anxiety here].
So I don't think change can happen at the speed of light, only communication. After that, at least we've informed ourselves a) What the real situation is and why, and b) What are our collective options? 
Most people think they understand the basics of Capitalism, Socialism and Communism, and that's all there is. While perhaps we will choose between variants of these "known" economic configurations, we would be shortchanging ourselves by not investigating a 4th way.
It was developed as a "Middle Path" between Capitalism(Full private ownership of value-creation) and textbook Socialism(Full public ownership of value-creation). Called "Economic Democracy", it has been hailed as the ultimate reconciliation between individualism, collectivism, and environmentalism by no less than Albert Einstein, Winston Churchill, Leo Tolstoy, and Aldous Huxley.
It is described in a free online book, Henry Georges Progress and Poverty, which built upon Adam Smiths 1776 Wealth of Nations to try to explain the failures of Classical Economics which Smith had so lamented: Industrial and Commercial recession, and the problem of persistent poverty amidst almost unimaginable technical progress. The introduction could have been written in 2019:
BQSTART
Yet we must now face facts we cannot mistake. All over the world, we hear complaints of industrial depression: labor condemned to involuntary idleness; capital going to waste; fear and hardship haunting workers. All this dull, deadening pain, this keen, maddening anguish, is summed up in the familiar phrase "hard times." ~ Henry George, San Francisco 1879
BQEND
In a nutshell, by scrambling the definitions of Land(aka nature), Wealth(what you want/need) and Money(sharing/trading mechanism) by magically pronouncing them all to be interchangeable forms of Capital(wealth reserved to make more wealth), the linkage between the Earth and real value(usable wealth) is lost.
Capitalism says Land equals Wealth equalsMoney equals Capital, which means pretty much whatever whoever controls the Myrmidons of the rent-takers wants it to mean.
That is of course, until production cannot underwrite the enormous rents, brutally extracted at whatever the market will bear. Then the economy crashes, and the monopoly game starts again on a smaller board.
Economic Democracy rights this obfuscation, by assigning the correct relationship as:Land causes Wealth causes Money with _repeated_ application of Labor, true Capital and Trade.
Nominal owners of natural opportunities should pay for civilization, not those who do the work of building and maintaining it. Economic Democracy suggests a simple market-based mechanism to get the most out of the least land, while the benefits of land ownership accrue to everyone, not just inheritors. Everyone has incentive to make sure land doesn't degrade, and the power to enforce those desires.
If you're interested in further investigation, especially in why no one seems to know about this, or pretends they do and insists it is old hat even though they can't explain why, Here are a few rabbit holes I found fascinating. I've also written a lot in these comments if you have absolutely nothing else better to do. Questions and thoughts most welcome.
~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics, Dierdre Kent 2016.The Corruption - detailsWhat Money is: Seven Deadly Innocent Frauds of Economic Policy, Mosler 2010 P1.What Wealth is: Progress and Poverty, Henry George 1879, esp intro, ch3, 17.How we got to Now: The Corruption of Economics, Mason Gaffney 1994 p 29-44. Excellent Prologue by Fred Harrison: Who's Afraid of Henry George?
For sincere and willing truth-seekers, this short list cannot fail to deeply reward even a cursory treatment. Namaste.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548222946000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'wealth', u'effect': u'money'}, {u'cause': u'land', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124987625', u'id': u'124988256', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mshawdjflex', u'text': u'I work in the area of greenhouse reduction and sustainable building design and I remember the disappointment I felt when Australia's relatively week carbon price was introduced. This was particularly obvious when viewed through the lens of my own lifestyle. Pricing in environmental externalities would never cause me to stop using my landlord's electric storage domestic hot water unit, it wouldn't quickly decarbonise Victoria's high carbon brown coal electricity generators, nor would it encourage my landlord to install photovoltaic panels on the roof of his investment property for my benefit. The carbon price would also not encourage me to abandon my petrol vehicle for my 20 minute commute to and from work. The changes necessary would have been a) far better public transport services for journeys not starting/ending in Melbourne's C.B.D; or b) My employer's office landlord installing a workplace shower room so I could realistically cycle or jog to and from work. My occasional use of short-haul commercial plane flights for local tourism or work journeys could only have been decarbonised by a high speed inter-city rail network, once again not a carbon tax. None of the potentially dramatic carbon reductions to my current high carbon affluent Australian lifestyle would have been uncomfortable for me to adopt but with the neoliberal obsession with carbon pricing, it meant that none of the policy work was done to ensure that these 'market failures' were addressed.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548190539000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'pricing in environmental externalities', u'effect': u"me to stop using my landlord 's electric storage domestic hot water unit"}], u'author_id': u'12167977', u'id': u'124981558', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'countryranger', u'text': u'Yes that would be a very good idea & like the road accident, give it the full works with things like this is getting worse & no none is doing anything to stop it.
Govts. don't like bad exposure on TV & that's the problem we have, commercial TV are pro the Coalition & the ABC have been cowered into submission with massive cuts, so we don't get what is desperately needed.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548190501000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100633604', u'in_reply_to': u'124950237', u'id': u'124981547', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'evmvic', u'text': u'What we want to do and what we need to do are two very different things.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548219418000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100093587', u'in_reply_to': u'124986035', u'id': u'124987846', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobertBris', u'text': u'You are quite right. Sparrow's opposition to cap and trade schemes is completely irrational and even dangerous as the alternative he offers is economically inefficient and authoritarian.
Cap and trade schemes can be and will be gamed. However the purpose of lawmakers and regulators is to minimise gaming. Cap and trade schemes work, which is why they have been so vehemently opposed by conservatives and industry groups.
Sparrow is right that, without compensation, they are inherently regressive. However, shutting down power stations by government edict has the same regressive effect on prices and will be equally unpopular if there is no compensation. The solution is to arrange compensation through the social welfare and/or tax system.
Cap and trade is the way to go because it encourages innovative, lowest cost solutions to a shared program. Top down solutions are limited by the imaginations of a handful of politicians and their advisors.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548188576000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it encourages innovative solutions to a shared program', u'effect': u'to go'}], u'author_id': u'3915144', u'in_reply_to': u'124949501', u'id': u'124980931', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Exactly.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548185172000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'124952031', u'id': u'124979983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'optus1', u'text': u'Matt Quinn: Thanks for your reply.  I agree with you that "it's not enough to say greed". It's not......I think that way back when, it all started out with good and right intentions, the vision and hope of a better world for more people. Plus it started out with a whole lot of ignorance - i.e. lack of knowledge and understanding. Then at some point, the ignorance became less and less.
However, even though we were no longer ignorant, we kept up all the "business as usual" and acted as thought we were still ignorant. Made various attempts to cover it all up. Now, in the 21st century we simply cannot hide our ignorance or the consequences of our past actions - and our present ones, as well.But by now, we've all become addicted to "the system" and dependent on what it gives us and provides for us.
Who among us is willing, able and courageous enough to stand tall - and probably, alone - to be the hero or the fool and make the changes and take the actions which would be necessary to stop the economic vehicle in its tracks? (Which nation? Which leader or leaders? Which government?) And do it all at the "speed of light"? Hint: They are all entirely different categories of "thing".', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548215195000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124986192', u'id': u'124987275', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R_Ambrose_Raven', u'text': u'True, but let us recognise the irony.
Prime Minister Julia Gillard’s correctness in endorsing a carbon tax was resoundingly confirmed by China acting to do so. 
It was the view of twelve senior European and American economists and scientists that the carbon levy will “put Australia in the vanguard of the development of low-carbon technologies”. They obviously didn’t see any real action by the UK and EU, whatever promising targets might have been adopted. 
Rabid Right ideologues should have welcomed Gillard Labor’s carbon pricing, it being a classic price signal. Big Energy indicated at the COP21 Paris Environment summit, and since, that it accepts the need for decarbonisation. That it seeks a market-based mechanism to avoid regulation is only to be expected. 
Ironically, it worked. Pitt&Sherry’s energy analyst found that in its two years of life (2010-2013), emissions from electricity generation fell an exceptional 10.6%, while in next 21 months they’d climbed 5.6%, and have been increasing every quarter since. An abrupt change in the mix of electricity generation “away from hydro and back to brown and black coal as removal of the carbon price changed the relative costs”. What a surprise!
Further, the abbott Misgovernment’s behaviour assured us that saving energy was no longer that important. So does Turnbull, now. His National Energy Guarantee is literally just the (three) soothing words so beloved of prestidigitatious politicians. Under Gillard Labor we were leaders, now we are just followers, though with our stupid politicians regularly embarrassed by Chinese actions that trip them into the adjacent piles of manure.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548215170000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12554246', u'id': u'124987269', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pavanne', u'text': u'Our entire economic system is based on energy used, primarily from fossil fuels. If that was satire, you got me ;)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548214360000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124986480', u'id': u'124987147', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EasyFix', u'text': u'With mentions of Silent Spring, Club of Rome, Klein below - & my then '70s readings of Ehrlich, Commoner, Ecologist's Blueprint, Schumacher, Boulding, Scitovsky (yes, some economists who could think)...& countless others, I could write a tome, but tend to agree with lenny_van_ross below...given the time frames...as one of my then lecturers said to me way back in 1971.."it is already too late".
A couple of brief comments: God, the Cloud, the Market (the much mis-quoted 'invisible hand') all have religious undertones of some positive higher power that means we don't have to do stuff, we can just 'trust' someone/thing to look after our best interests. And we can still multiply & subdue the earth. Thank God I'm an atheist.
Economics has steadfastly refused to seriously take into its orbit many of the critiques - from quality of life measures, the distorted economic definition of growth, through paying attention to the roles of ethical production & consumption in human meaning, & stock measures of material wealth rather than flow & throughput. So don't expect any changes from economics. It prefers to leave things out into the area of 'externalities'. In fact, that has been part of the political economy of intentional neolib strategy for slashing public services: cut the services, force or cajole people into voluntary work (from internships through work-for-dole through reciprocality guilt trips)...voila, your average bod gradually replaces some public services whilst the powerful interest focus on what they know best.
As a couple of comments note, the record of both capitalism & socialism hasn't been too flash. Both Smith & Marx were materialist philosophers writing in earlier times, but neither would have been so fixed in thoughts to not be able to question their own writings if they had foreseen historical developments & circumstances of today. But, as Jeff has written elsewhere, we are a little short on practical utopian thoughts these days. And there are the usual 'we'll be back in the caves' comments from those who fear the prospect that, if the cake is finite, we then start to seriously question about who gets what share of it.
Nice article Jeff.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548154210000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18279521', u'id': u'124957392', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'pavanne', u'text': u'The trouble with refusing to put a price on the environment is that, unless you can set up a command economy promptly and remain in power by brute force, you effectively set its price at zero.

Excellent stuff! We must focus on economics like a laser until it is fixed.
Obviously our system of material existence(economics) is destroying the planet. This must be because value has been decoupled from the things which confer it. Otherwise it would not destroy the basis for it's own prosperity, and of our very life/spirit-support. It was a clever trick. 
Folding nature into the capitalist delusion is an equally clever trap, and you are totally right to point at it and blow a loud whistle. But they are caught in their own delusion, and since they are caught in nature regardless, also their own trap.
BQSTART
The dictators and bureaucrats might be ruining spring, as they force every living organism to bear the consequences for their profits.
BQENDWhat they don't realise is that their profits are not stored wealth any more, they are monetized wealth. Representative of a wealth-creation system dependent, at root, on the living world, to produce real value.
Representative.
Secondary industries cannot support tertiary industries without primary industries, which is something capitalism cannot seem to acknowledge, any more than it can understand that every time it eliminates a worker, it loses a customer.
Aiiii.
1946 must have been a big year on the literary scene. In his 1946 introduction to Brave New World, Aldous Huxley describes a vision for humanity he has just read and digested - obviously unknown to him in 1931 - Progress and Poverty by Henry George. He writes: 
BQSTART
"If I were to rewrite the book, I would offer the Savage...the possibility of sanity...where community economics would be decentralist and Henry-Georgian".
BQEND
Georgism, or Economic Democracy is a fourth way, a middle path between socialism and capitalism, a true reconciliation of individualism and collectivism. Allegedly suppressed for a century, are we Brave enough to look at it again?

~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548211760000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124982999', u'id': u'124986831', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'StarOZamolxis', u'text': u'I find it funny how preoccupied the westerners "seem" to be, regarding Nature.

Yesterday morning I sat under a public rotunda next to the river where I live. It's a truly delightful spot. I looked and listened to the trees. I saw a big squadron of ducks fly in perfect formation and land on the river. A group of Magpies stopped by. A few walked on the floor around my legs. Some sat on the tables behind me. And one very friendly Magpie came right up close and sat on the table beside me.They chirped and sang and chatted loudly to each other. Up and down with their sing-song sounds which to my ear, sounded like the sweetest chorus. Their chorus was so good and so clear that I wished I'd had a device with me to record them.
The reason I thought of recording them was because I wondered how much longer they'd be around for me or anyone to see and hear them up close, personal and first-hand. I wondered how long it would be before the only place I'd see them would be in some select enclosure or zoo or via some documentary or digital vision. And I wondered how long it would be before the only way I could hear their sounds would be on a CD or some App or similar. I wondered how much longer the water would still be running in the river and how much longer the ducks would still be alive and able to fly there in perfect formation.
I prefer to use the yardstick of the Civil Law Courts i.e The BALANCE of PROBABILITIES.So I sat there and thought - on the balance of probabilities?  Still here in 5 years? Probably - but not confident enough to punt the house and the dog on it......10 years? Maybe - but probably nowhere near their current numbers and not anywhere near their current conditions.15 years?  Doubtful. Unlikely. Don't like their chances at all. Wouldn't even punt my breakfast coffee on it.20 years? Very highly probably...dead in the water. Literally. River stale or run dry. Just a memory. No more ducks. No more Magpies. What trees there are - near lifeless.
Beyond that? By the time one gets to "beyond that" it's all already HISTORY....', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548211144000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"i wondered how much longer they 'd be around for me or anyone to see and hear them up close hand", u'effect': u'the reason i thought of recording them was'}], u'author_id': u'12048513', u'id': u'124986761', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'We thought our way out of it in 1879. Henry George won the argument with Progress and Poverty by pointing out that the Earth is the only possible source of all wealth. Even digital wealth requires people, land and energy. 
The 20th century and the current malaise indicates merely that we are still in the process of winning the fight.~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548209901000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124983597', u'id': u'124986615', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Confuseus', u'text': u'Which therefore means that declining birth rates, probably through use of contraception, are a good thing and that immigration to make up for that decline is not helpful.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548151214000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101239654', u'in_reply_to': u'124952054', u'id': u'124954995', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pluto100', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

No we did not. Of course it has been snow free ever since? Nope you clearly have short term memory losshttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_of_2009%E2%80%9310_in_Great_Britain_and_Irelandhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_of_2010%E2%80%9311_in_Great_Britain_and_IrelandTry and analyse real data not a selective "memory"', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548166548000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'124952179', u'id': u'124967311', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'We have won the argument. Now we must win the fight. To do that we need to know precisely how and why the economic system got primed to destroy the basis of it's own prosperity. It's not enough to say greed. We need names, times and dates. And we have them. And we have an alternative economic system based on valuing the Earth by acknowledging it as the source of all wealth.
All we need is a tool capable of disseminating these facts at close to the speed of light, and people to work it. When the opportunity arises, we shall simply be ready with the correct explanation, and the best possible alternative solution.
~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548209410000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'124984178', u'id': u'124986543', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Layng1', u'text': u'I live in a rural area. Insects are dramatically reduced, bees are gone, bird life is reduced and industrial high intensity farming has taken over. This just a microcosm but it is obvious that this new agriculture is unsustainable in the longer term.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548151117000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18088802', u'id': u'124954924', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Dentarthurdent73', u'text': u'"So how do you explain the monotonically declining energy intensity of GDP? It's universal. "all available real-world evidence" is meaningless hyperbole."
Resource and energy intensity of GDP can decline all they want (and to be honest, it's a pretty shallow curve) - they are not going to zero, so if you keep increasing GDP overall, then resource use will also continue to grow. On this finite planet, whatever you do, at some point you hit a wall where you can not grow any further without eating into your capital (to use terminology you can relate to). We have hit that wall quite some time ago, and we currently do not have the technology to access resources from off-planet.
Tell me, how do you look at statistics on deforestation, loss of wildlife and biodiversity, declining fish stocks, massive plastic pollution, and still tell yourself that because there's some graphs of 'monotonically declining energy intensity of GDP', the system's obviously just grand.
"And the other real biggie. What do you think that the massive increase in agricultural yields represent if it's not more efficient use of land."
It represents exactly what I mentioned above - eating into our capital. 
What do you think of the estimated 30% of the planet's arable land having been lost to erosion and pollution? "The continual ploughing of fields, combined with heavy use of fertilizers, has degraded soils across the world, the research found, with erosion occurring at a pace of up to 100 times greater than the rate of soil formation."
Is that your idea of efficient? In reality, it's not efficient if it's not sustainable. 
I'm positive you understand this when managing your own life. I feel sure for example that you don't blow your entire pay packet on a huge night out and sit back thinking 'wow, I'm so rich', because you know you'll be without a home to live in and food to eat if you do that. Exactly the same applies to the planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1548150913000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"there 's some graphs of intensity", u'effect': u"that the system 's obviously just grand"}, {u'cause': u"you know you 'll be without a home to live in and food to eat if you do that", u'effect': u"wow i 'm so rich"}], u'author_id': u'14555235', u'in_reply_to': u'124952337', u'id': u'124954761', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'Read these. description: Environmentalists miss what corporates grasp: ‘put a price on carbon’ accepts commodification of the environment
og_fields.og:description: Environmentalists miss what corporates grasp: ‘put a price on carbon’ accepts commodification of the environment
og_fields.og:title: George Orwell said the world’s bureaucrats couldn’t take spring from us, but they are | Jeff Sparrow
text:
“Spring is here … and they can’t stop you enjoying it.”
That’s George Orwell in his essay Some Thoughts on the Common Toad.
“So long as you are not actually ill, hungry, frightened or immured in a prison or a holiday camp,” he continues, “Spring is still spring. The atom bombs are piling up in the factories, the police are prowling through the cities, the lies are streaming from the loudspeakers, but the earth is still going round the sun, and neither the dictators nor the bureaucrats, deeply as they disapprove of the process, are able to prevent it.”
But, of course, now they have.
Today spring’s no longer spring – at least not in the old way.
With climate change wrecking the seasonal rhythms, scientists find plants emerging from the soil earlier than ever before. Almost everywhere, the ancient patterns have gone awry: last November, for instance, summer temperatures killed a third – yes, a third! – of Australia’s remaining spectacled flying foxes.
The atom bombs, the police, the dictators and the bureaucrats remain with us and, God knows, so do the lies streaming from the loudspeakers. But, as the sociologist John Bellamy Foster noted back in 2002, Orwell’s beloved toads are now vanishingly rare, with some 200 different species of amphibians driven to extinction in the last few decades.
Some Thoughts on the Common Toad appeared in the socialist newspaper Tribune in 1946 just as the planet entered what environmentalists call “The Great Acceleration”: the period in which the human boot, weighing heavily since the industrial revolution, began to stamp on the face of nature.
Throughout the post-war boom, the tremendous expansion of the global economy drew more and more of the world into the circuit of capital. Ocean acidification, biodiversity loss, greenhouse gas emissions: all of these, and other indicators, shot violently upward from the late 1940s on.
The periodisation highlights a fundamental problem in the fight against climate change today.
We know now that scientists understood all the key principles of global warming decades ago. Furthermore, as Nathaniel Rich notes, back in the 1980s a real response seemed eminently feasible as “many prominent Republicans joined Democrats in judging the climate problem to be a rare political winner: non-partisan and of the highest possible stakes”.
But the early consensus for climate action coincided with what Naomi Klein dubs “the absolute zenith of the neoliberal crusade”. As a result, the leaders who committed to fighting warming also ruled out any response to emissions incompatible with their free market dogma.
Thus, in the negotiations that led to the Kyoto Protocol, the US, with the backing of companies like Enron, insisted that international efforts for climate change mitigation rely on business-friendly, market-based mechanisms such as cap and trade schemes. Even though Washington eventually refused to ratify Kyoto, the methodology championed by it (and institutions like the World Bank) became, by the early 2000s, an unassailable political orthodoxy.
Again, the notion that the market offered the best (or indeed the only) mechanism for fighting climate change was always pure ideology. For instance governments can shut down coal-fuelled power stations whenever they like – they don’t need price signals to pass legislation. In the real world, as researcher Jesse Jenkins explained to the New York Times “policies other than carbon pricing have driven the majority of emissions reductions to date”.
The ideologically-determined attempts to generate environmental outcomes through market action thus resembled huge Rube Goldberg machines, dependent on ultra-convoluted systems for results that can also be produced by non-market means.
But those fossil fuel corporations who supported (and sometimes led) the early campaigns for emissions trading systems saw the redundant complexity of market environmentalism as a feature, not a bug. Companies like BP and Shell understood – better than many environmentalists – that, in practice, a trading system could amount to a massive subsidy for big polluters since they could profit hugely by “selling” emissions they didn’t actually require.
Furthermore, because a trade in carbon allowed the purchase of credits associated with carbon offsets (usually in the developing world), tremendous opportunities opened up for creative (and sometimes blatantly dishonest) accounting. An EU study from 2017 found that a full 85% of offset projects actually failed to reduce emissions at all.
Many progressives reluctantly embraced free market environmentalism, judging any action to be better than none – particularly as overt climate change denialism grew.
But that missed something else that the corporates grasped: namely, that the “put a price on carbon” slogan accepted, by definition, the commodification of the environment.
That was, after all, the goal of pricing: transforming nature, in all its complexity and diversity, into an asset legible within a corporate ledger.
Fixing a market value on carbon was never supposed to halt the economic activity underpinning the Great Acceleration. On the contrary, it was intended to speed it up. Even if trading schemes do cut greenhouse gases (which, by and large, they don’t), they’re designed, as pro-business measures, not to limit industrial expansion but to foster it. They’re meant explicitly to encourage more economic growth – and that’s something that’s no longer compatible with the preservation of nature.
As Foster points out, a continuous 3% average annual rate of growth means that world industry doubles every twenty-five years, grows by a factor of sixteen every century, and 4,000 times every three centuries. Given the current state of the planet, how would that not bring utter ruination? The World Wildlife Fund says that populations of mammals, birds, fish, reptiles and amphibians have declined by 60% since 1970. What will be left if we continue economic metastasisation for another half century?
In political terms, the embrace by progressives of mitigation schemes so closely associated with big business has proved utterly disastrous. Over the last decades, an “environmentalism” that rewarded rapacious corporations seemed to many ordinary people less a strategy for preserving the planet they depended upon and more a rhetorical bludgeon wielded by an out-of-touch political class.
Take the experience in France, where President Emmanuel Macron, pledging to Make the Planet Great Again, introduced another neoliberal nostrum – a carbon tax.
A recent study revealed that carbon taxes don’t make a meaningful difference to the climate because governments invariably set them at too low a rate. Why? Well, carbon taxes are innately regressive – they pass the cost of reform onto the consumers who can least afford it – and thus are rarely popular.
In France Macron implemented his levy on fuel as part of a broader austerity package – and spurred the Yellow Vest revolt, a rebellion led by workers living outside the metropolitan centres, and with no choice but to use cars.
In other words, in the name of environmentalism, Macron managed to alienate France’s poorest – the very people who will suffer most in a warming future and so should have been a key constituency for change.
That’s why Thoughts on the Common Toad repays re-reading.
In his essay, Orwell takes for granted an affinity between everyday nature and working class people, who can, he suggests, find an alternative to oppression and exploitation in the environment around them.
“Even in the most sordid street the coming of spring will register itself by some sign or other, if it is only a brighter blue between the chimney pots or the vivid green of an elder sprouting on a blitzed site. Indeed it is remarkable how Nature goes on existing unofficially, as it were, in the very heart of London.”
In other words, Orwell celebrates an uncommodified environment, explicitly because it doesn’t obey the rules of the market.
“[T]he pleasures of spring are available to everybody, and cost nothing,” he explains, before exulting at the thought of birds, in the midst of bourgeois Britain, flagrantly avoiding rent.
The Great Deceleration we require today means deploying our scientific and technical knowledge to undo the damage we’ve wreaked. It means embracing economic planning, so that we use scarce resources for human need rather than corporate profit; it means confronting the military-industrial complex and abandoning the fossil economy; it means involving ordinary people in the decisions that shape their lives.
It means, in other words, constructing a non-market society, as scary as that idea will seem to some
In 1946 Orwell, a lifelong socialist, defended an appreciation of nature as something that made “a peaceful and decent future a little more probable”. The joy that he took in toads and kestrels and other creatures that evaded the market’s invisible hand hinted at an older kind of society – and potentially, a newer one.
The dictators and bureaucrats might be ruining spring, as they force every living organism to bear the consequences for their profits. But for most of human history we did not live under generalised commodity production, an economic order that’s remarkably recent. And if the past was different, the future can be, too.
As we struggle to preserve our only planet, that insight matters more than ever.
• Jeff Sparrow is a Guardian Australia columnist
