description: Climate change may devastate the globe’s major coffee-growing regions through extreme weather events – but Australia could be the solution
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Climate change may devastate the globe’s major coffee-growing regions through extreme weather events – but Australia could be the solution
og_fields.og:title: The end of coffee: could Australia save the world's beans?
text:
If a future of relentless fires, droughts, superstorms and rising sea levels makes you feel like you need a strong caffeinated beverage, there is some bad news: climate change is coming for the world’s coffee beans.
Greg Meenahan, the partnership director at the non-profit institute World Coffee Research, puts it this way: “Demand for coffee is expected to double by the year 2050 and, if nothing is done, more than half of the world’s suitable coffee land will be pushed into unsuitability due to climate change. Without research and development, the coffee sector will need up to 180m more bags of coffee in 2050 than we are likely to have.”
To address this, the organisation is undertaking the international multi-location variety trial, testing 35 coffee types across 23 countries to measure performance in different climates – including in regions not typically associated with coffee production, such as Australia.
In what could be Australia’s most significant contribution to coffee since the flat white, scientists at Southern Cross University will be testing 20 “climate-resistant” varieties.
Prof Graham King, a leading plant science researcher at SCU, says that in January up to 900 plants will be planted at the tropical fruit research station in Alstonville, northern New South Wales. According to King, climate change is expected to devastate the world’s major coffee-growing regions through extreme weather and by increasing attacks by crop pests and diseases.
“Many current mountainous tropical production areas of the world are likely to become untenable for coffee as climate change progresses,” he says. “Within Australia we currently have the benefit of no coffee rust or cherry borer, or other major pests and disease. This is quite unique compared with most production areas of the world.”
The impact is already being felt. As detailed in a 2016 report by Fairtrade Australia, in 2012 Central America was hit by a wave of coffee leaf rust (Hemileia vastatrix) after unusually high temperatures and high-altitude rains, causing US$500m in crop damages and putting nearly 350,000 labourers out of work.
Droughts and frequent storms have led to Costa Rican farmers giving up coffee for orange plantations. Outside Latin America, the coffee berry borer (Hypothenemus hampei) – which used to only appear at a maximum altitude of 1,500 metres above sea level – is being found above this limit, thanks to unseasonably hot conditions and higher rainfall on plantations from Tanzania to Indonesia. On Mount Kilimanjaro plantations, the beetle is now found 300 metres higher than last century.
The future of coffee … and the livelihood and wellbeing of coffee farmers, workers and their families is at stake
Not only is Australia free of these blights, says King, but climate change could open up more Australian regions for growing coffee cherries owing to reduced frost damage in winter.
King warns that the trial will need at least five years to reap results, but funding from the federal government-funded AgriFutures Australia runs out in May. He says it has offered “pretty poor engagement” on the issue.
AgriFutures’ business development manager, Duncan Farquhar, says the coffee sector has been provided with funding for developing new varieties since 2014. “Emerging industries, including the coffee industry” have been invited to compete for a new round of funding, he says.
The organisation’s figures indicate that local coffee production has a long way to go to meet domestic demand. In 2011–12, just under 50 Australian growers produced about 1,000 tonnes of dry green beans, while about 67,000 tonnes were imported. Its experts say Australian coffee is 10% to 15% lower in caffeine than much overseas coffee because it is grown in a low-stress environment. Caffeine is produced by coffee plants as a defence mechanism against threats from pests and diseases.
An agronomist and coffee industry adviser, David Peasley, says rising temperatures could hurt coffee growing in north Queensland but agrees that in subtropical coffee growing regions they could help. He cautions that climate change could leave Australian plantations more vulnerable to pests and diseases and that extreme weather events will present a challenge.
Indeed, without hardier varieties, Australian growers may find climate change brings more challenges than benefits. A grower, Zeta Grealy, says conditions have become increasingly difficult since she created her Zeta’s Coffee plantation on the border of NSW and Queensland in 1994.
“In the past we had fabulous conditions, a lovely microclimate for coffee,” she says. “It used to look rainforest-y around here, now it’s very sparse. It has been a gradual change – where once we’d be getting two metres of rainfall, [across 2018] we had less than one.
“Our crop actually didn’t happen this time, we had overripe cherries and completely green cherries, flowers on the tree – not what we want. So we decided to strip the trees and get them ready for next year.”
The crop was down to 19kg from a typical year of about a tonne. Grealy is hopeful that the trials lead to access to varieties that can cope with lower rainfall.
World Coffee Research is encouraging the industry to do its bit to safeguard the crop’s global future by contributing to its Checkoff program, in which roasters can donate up to 0.20 cents a kilogram of green coffee from participating suppliers to help fund initiatives such as the global trial.
Supporters include Single O’s director of coffee, Wendy De Jong, whose company will be the first roaster to import a full container of “future-friendly” coffees to Australia.
“[We] are calling on Australian roasters and importers to do their part to fund the critical research and development needed for coffee and farmers alike by signing up to the WCR Checkoff program,” she says.
Fairtrade Australia’s chief executive, Molly Harriss Olson, welcomes research into hardier varieties, noting that by 2080 wild coffee – a vital bedrock of genetic diversity for developing new varieties – could become extinct. She notes that expanding Australian plantations won’t prevent climate change’s impact on coffee growers in other countries.
“More frequent and severe drought is associated with a deep and disturbing sense of failure, loss, powerlessness, heightened anxiety, stress, depression and an increased suicide rate among farmers,” she says.
Harriss Olson urged coffee consumers to educate themselves about the challenges facing growers, seek out brands that are both carbon-neutral and help producers to adapt to a changing climate, and urge businesses and governments to pursue a carbon-neutral economy.
“It’s crucial that we all take action now,” she says. “Because the future of coffee, one of the world’s favourite commodities, and the livelihood and wellbeing of millions of coffee farmers, workers and their families is at stake.”
• This article was amended on 8 January 2019 to correct Prof Graham King’s job title.

[{u'author': u'kejovi', u'text': u'As a Labor voter I do appreciate your columns Oliver Yates, it is reassuring in one way that there is still some sane people left in the Liberal Party and they haven't been silenced or purged by the far right nutters who have been infiltrating the party since John Howard gave them the nod and the wink in the 90's.The problem for the Liberal Party is if there is a split, ala ALP/DLP in the fifties, it could find itself in the wilderness for decades and any cobbled together coalition of hard right Liberals, centre right Liberals, Nationals in government would be fraught with the drama we are witnessing today.And will the Nationals be a political force as their prediliction for coal over cows and corn make their 'base' look at and vote in independents who have rural and regional farmers and constituents on their minds now, instead of a seat on the board of mining company in the future.The future looks difficult and will only be made more difficult if the predicted electoral landslide happens and the LNP are left with around 50 seats.........', u'recommendation_count': u'80', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013578000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14861525', u'id': u'124420093', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheMadMonkeyPod', u'text': u'Kansas folk?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013559000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100650499', u'in_reply_to': u'124419921', u'id': u'124420091', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GeelongOldF', u'text': u'The real reason why women don’t get selected in pre selection is they can’t raise massive donation and are not bids on either the Conservative or Progressive front. She fits both. So preselection a breeze but can’t see voters impressed', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12204485', u'id': u'124420090', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Johnt3551', u'text': u'Dead', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12341626', u'in_reply_to': u'124419980', u'id': u'124420089', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dargie', u'text': u'Ha ha ...is this the Libs attempt to show they're up for putting more women into Parliament?Credlin would be like the appalling shrieking Michaelia Cash , except possibly worse.', u'recommendation_count': u'80', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013483000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2678356', u'id': u'124420085', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WhiyuMadbro', u'text': u'Her level of bias and far right demagoguery are situation normal on Sky.', u'recommendation_count': u'21', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013473000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14390176', u'in_reply_to': u'124419902', u'id': u'124420083', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheMadMonkeyPod', u'text': u'Not local, not happening.', u'recommendation_count': u'19', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100650499', u'in_reply_to': u'124420044', u'id': u'124420082', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LovelyDaffodils', u'text': u'These politicians and the political hopefuls are treating us all like bloody idiots. Wake up Australia, if they are to be in power and speak and act for us, then only vote the decent honest ones in; not creatures like Credlin.We deserve better than what we have.', u'recommendation_count': u'40', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013443000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18062194', u'id': u'124420081', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Lawrie Griffith', u'text': u'"Oliver Yates is a member of the Liberal party and former chief executive of the Clean Energy Finance Corporation"Well, thank you for writing this, and thank you Guardian for publishing it.To hear these from another prominent member of the Liberal Party is heartening.
It would seem from the passionate content of this article that the ratbag religious right are doing to the Liberal Party what B A Santamaria did to the Labor Party in the 1950s and 60s.I'm not sure though, that the Liberal Party, or even the Nationals, will come out the other side the way the Labor party did.
At the very least, I think you are going to have to have a formal split, and a name change.But please, wait at least six years, so we can get some progress permanently in place to repair the unspeakable damage done to this fine country by your colleagues over the last six years.', u'recommendation_count': u'83', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013394000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13793892', u'id': u'124420079', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'WhiyuMadbro', u'text': u'You know what really “remains Malcolm Turnbull’s kryptonite”?
Backstabbing, far right wing coal spruiking climate change deniers out of step with society.
You know what else they are kryptonite to?
The Liberal party's election chances, and most likely it's medium term political future.
Australia doesn't like extremism in any form.
They just don't represent the views and wishes of more than the handful of converted, the sky news after dark crowd who are already fully paid up Liberal Kool Aid drinkers.
The electorate want a purge of these backward thinkers. We saw it in Queensland and Western Australia. We've just seen it in Victoria, in levels that have the Coalition trembling with fear or shouting with impotent rage. We will see it again shortly in New South Wales, and then, finally, the one we have all been waiting for, federally.
Peta Credlin's preselection could just be the Liberal party’s final piece of kryptonite. That is, if agreeing to protect Craig Kelly and other far right mates from preselection challenges , or the actions of Dutton, Abbott, Abetz, Christensen, Morrison, Frydenberg, Cormann, Cash and the like hasn't already given the whole place the sickly green radioactive glow.', u'recommendation_count': u'37', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013392000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14390176', u'id': u'124420078', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Sunhead Darkspear', u'text': u'Wingnut Welfare at Murdochistan is a solid earner for those with the appropriate ethical and moral deficiencies.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013385000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14193547', u'in_reply_to': u'124419830', u'id': u'124420076', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheEgg3', u'text': u'The dog would take one look and highball it out of there as fast as it could !!', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013308000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18218644', u'in_reply_to': u'124420030', u'id': u'124420068', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'familygardener2', u'text': u'And what about the flat mooners,they never get mentioned.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547013240000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17730933', u'in_reply_to': u'124419921', u'id': u'124420059', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'CommunityMod', u'text': u'Discussion will close here shortly (on the hour) - Her hard-right views including denial of climate change will never win over moderate party members such as the author.

Her only career option is to continue to sermonise to the dwindling numbers of die-hard Sky News After Dark viewers.', u'recommendation_count': u'31', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547012818000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12225158', u'id': u'124420017', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gary Fallon', u'text': u'You missed some major points. Andrew Broad is a National. The National Party is currently considering which of their six nominees will be preselected. Mallee has only been held by the Nationals. Recovery of the 'brand' is not really possible any more.', u'recommendation_count': u'45', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547011002000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14193547', u'id': u'124419803', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'As we watch leaders fail to halt climbing emissions driving increased drought and wildfire and storms we might ask where are we are now, long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1°C, due to lags in the system.
We’ve been seeing numerous impacts catching many scientists by surprise with how soon they are occurring. In 2014 two independent teams of scientists reported that the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is likely irreversibly retreating. 3.3 meters of sea level rise equivalent of ice there is being destabilized by a warming ocean and energy is going into the net melting of ice all over the planet. 
The paleoclimate record indicates that increasing global temperature by just 1.5-2°C above preindustrial temperature commits the system to an eventual 6-9m of sea level rise, a large fraction of which could arrive within the next 100 years.
Corals may not survive this century of warming and acidifying oceans, and droughts and floods linked to global warming—and conflict linked to those droughts—have already caused four countries to face famine.
Because of the decades to millennial long lag between a climate forcing and our feeling the full effect, due to the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets, the effects we are feeling now are largely just the beginning of the result of emissions from the 20th century. And emissions have been increasing steadily for decades.
We are also seeing numerous amplifying feedbacks: loss of albedo (heat reflectivity) from ice melt, permafrost melt, methane release and massive wildfires; the Earth is starting to wrest any possible further human control of the climate away.
We're about out of time on this, if not already, and leaders are not only still acting as if this is not a planetary emergency, but some are acting as if there isn’t a problem at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'24', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547010980000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'lags in the system', u'effect': u'as we watch leaders fail to halt climbing emissions driving increased drought and wildfire and storms we might ask where are we are now long before feeling the full effects of a rise in temperature of just over 1 \xb0 c'}, {u'cause': u'the thermal inertia of the ocean and response time of the ice sheets', u'effect': u'our feeling the full effect'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'124419801', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID3674289', u'text': u'Exactly! Despite what the right wing of the party thinks, many local members are not happy with the ousting of Turnbull or with the party's lack of a climate policy. I'm sure this will show up in a seat like the Mallee, where people have had first hand experience of the effects of climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547010961000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16170251', u'id': u'124419797', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'mantovani cesspool', u'text': u'Watch out people of the Mallee.

og_fields.og:description: Credlin has put short term political interests, and the interests of the coal industry, before the future of our country
og_fields.og:title: Peta Credlin's preselection could be the spark that blows up the Liberal party | Oliver Yates
text:
What better example is there that the Liberal party must split than the proposed nomination of Peta Credlin for the seat of Mallee.
If, as Credlin says, “climate change remains Malcolm Turnbull’s kryptonite”, then her preselection could just be the Liberal party’s dynamite. The split already exists, but for now, it’s being held together with sticky tape and string. And Credlin’s preselection could well be the spark that lights the fuse, and blows the whole thing up.
The Liberal party is suffering an existential crisis. And no other issue defines this crisis like the looming threat to our safety and security caused by inaction on climate change. Credlin understands this and has used her position as a climate change-denying, hard-right mouthpiece of the Murdoch empire to advance her own political interests, and the interests of the coal industry.
• Sign up to receive the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning
She’s consistently claimed climate change is a political hoax, and used her position in the media to undermine a sitting prime minister and any energy policy supported by the Coalition party room that does not involve more coal and the end of renewables.
She doesn’t represent real liberal views, and if she appeals to what’s left of the “base”, then many people who used to vote Liberal will keep moving for the exits.
Inspired by Donald Trump, Credlin has argued Australia should tear up the Paris agreement, tear up any sensible national energy guarantee. Credlin has demanded taxpayers’ money go to the Adani coalmine and be used to build new coal-fired power stations. It’s madness.
Australians don’t want this. We would prefer a Great Barrier Reef, renewable energy and a future we can survive and thrive in.
These views are so ignorant – their political manifestation through Tony Abbott, Craig Kelly and their ilk – that it presents a grave economic and security threat to Australia’s future. And it could be the final death knell to the Liberal party.
Credlin’s demonstrated lack of understanding of the serious climate emergency we face, or even the basic economics of power production costs are breathtaking. She promotes the view that climate change is some leftwing conspiracy and that the science is rubbish.
These views need to be called for what they are: dangerous.
In her media roles, Credlin has even attacked the scientific foundation for energy and climate policy. From the desk at Sky, she announced her displeasure that former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull asked chief scientist Alan Finkel for real consideration of the climate change transition and energy policy. Instead she demanded a manufactured report devoid of reality.
It is essential now that real liberals stand against this reckless game of Russian roulette
“What started out as a report designed to expose the South Australian Labor government’s catastrophic handling of energy policy leading up to last year’s blackouts” – promoting the lie that the blackouts were caused by renewables – “is now a report that threatens the tense equilibrium of the Coalition party room”, warned Credlin.
Heaven help us if facts were allowed to get in the way of the stability of the party room or facts should reach the people!
We should be deeply concerned that the Liberal party is once again seeking to preselect people who are prepared to sprout deranged conspiracy theories.
“Green ideology has trumped sensible economics. Affordable power, from abundant coal and gas, is Australia’s principal competitive advantage and in recent years, we’ve given it away in the name of saving the planet.”
Good luck finding a bank, or anyone under 35, to agree with you.
The job of any politician should be to put the long-term wellbeing of the public before cheap and dangerous political point-scoring. People are sick to death of it. This kind of pandering to the hard-right’s views did not serve Matthew Guy well in Victoria, and it will not serve the Liberals well at national level either.
Australians know it’s getting hotter every summer and see the increases in extreme weather. Report after report, overflowing with scientific evidence, traditionally a solid foundation for investment and public policy making, has been abandoned by the federal Liberal party. We understand how this will threaten our families, economy and security, and we must act to provide people with a real liberal alternative.
Credlin, Abbott and the rest of the hard-right’s “commitment to coal” is entirely political. The calculation they’ve made is that their short-term political interests, and the interests of the coal industry, are more important than the future of our country, our people and holistically the environment we all share.
It is essential now that real liberals stand against this reckless game of Russian roulette the hard right are playing with our future. If not, they too will adorn the walls as climate change deniers, who, despite all the evidence, refused to act.
• Oliver Yates is a member of the Liberal party and former chief executive of the Clean Energy Finance Corporation

description: Bolsonaro’s capitalist ideology threatens minorities – and the rainforest that protects the planet, says the journalist Eliane Brum
og_fields.og:description: Bolsonaro’s capitalist ideology threatens minorities – and the rainforest that protects the planet, says the journalist Eliane Brum
og_fields.og:title: He’s been president a week – and already Bolsonaro is damaging Brazil | Eliane Brum
text:
The world needs to understand what Brazil has become, before it’s too late. Jair Messias Bolsonaro’s Brazil is not just another country that elected a far-right president at a time when the world’s most powerful nation is led by Donald Trump. It’s not just South America’s version of the current trend of countries sliding into authoritarianism, like we’ve seen in Hungary, Poland, Turkey and the Philippines. It’s not simply a peripheral nation with a pathetic leader. Brazil has become the apocalyptic vanguard that signals how radical this moment is – one with the power to worsen the climate crisis at top speed and blight the entire planet.
Bolsonaro was elected in October, on his pledge to go back ‘50 years'. Brazil lived under a military dictatorship then
The election of Bolsonaro is a response to what we might call civilisation’s new discontent. Maybe people can’t identify the source of their anxiety, which has driven up the consumption of tranquillisers and sedatives. The average citizen might apply more familiar labels to the corrosion of their quality of life, air, and water; to a relentless fear of the “other”; to the feeling they’re walking in quicksand. But what’s underpinning this new discontent pervading all areas of human experience is our climate crisis.
Bolsonaro was elected in October, on his pledge to go back “50 years”. Fifty years ago, Brazil lived under a military dictatorship. For Bolsonaro and his followers, who are outright defenders of torture and the elimination of adversaries, it was a glorious era. Despite the terrifying menace of nuclear war, the world was still a place where science promised nothing but progress and solutions – it delivered no bad news, like global warming, that led to limitations on an individual’s daily life or on government actions. It was a time when white, heterosexual men held power and knew precisely who they were. They may have faced some resistance from minorities, but they still enjoyed absolute hegemony.
We cannot comprehend what is now happening in Brazil – and around the world – unless we understand that our culture wars are tightly bound up with humanity’s need to say goodbye to 20th-century illusions of power and face a planet made more hostile by human hand. Things will soon reach catastrophic levels if nations and their residents do not unite in a global effort to do something extremely hard and unpopular: impose limits on ourselves to counteract global warming.
The election of Bolsonaro ties all this together like no other event. The Bolsonaro administration promises a “new era” – a return to a time free of doubts and insecurity, with certainty about what a man is and what a woman is and a clear sense who’s in charge of the public sphere and the family. Their ultra-conservatism is at times corny, at times biblical – but never innocent.
Soon after Bolsonaro’s inauguration last week, the minister of women, family, and human rights, Damares Alves – an evangelical pastor – stated in a video that now “girls wear pink and boys, blue”. Beside her, a supporter held an Israeli flag. Some neo-Pentecostals likewise waved Israeli flags at the inauguration. These religious groups, who are growing numerically and wielding greater power in Brazil, voted overwhelmingly for Bolsonaro.
A significant portion of them believe Jews will play a role in fulfilling scriptural prophesies about the return of the Messiah. It must be remembered that Bolsonaro was baptised in the River Jordan, in Israel, a couple of years before the presidential campaign. Now in power, he has announced that Brazil will move its embassy to Jerusalem, which, say these evangelicals, will be the “stage for Armageddon”. In a recent visit to Brazil, Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, declared: “We have no better friends in the world than the evangelical community.”
Ernesto Araújo, the dogmatic foreign minister, said Bolsonaro’s rise will be marked by “God through the nation”. He has also written that climate change is an “ideology” dreamed up so imperialist nations could determine Brazil’s future. “The people who say there are no men and women are the same ones who preach that countries don’t have the right to protect their borders,” Araújo stated in his inaugural speech.
This Brazil, stitched from a patchwork of dogmas, might be a fascinating topic of study if it didn’t put the whole planet at risk. Ideological discourse serves to instil the notion of destiny and to ensure cohesion within a population frightened about everything it might lose, from salaries and jobs to symbolic positions in the realms of race, gender, and sexual orientation. When Bolsonaro says he’s going to “free Brazil from political correctness”, he’s pledging to break both the “chains” that force people to respect minorities and those that curtail devastation of the Amazon forest.
In his first days in power, the president shifted responsibility for demarcation of indigenous and quilombola territory – which makes up a large part of the protected Amazon – to the agriculture ministry. This government sector is controlled by agribusiness, responsible for much of deforestation and eager to get their hands on the remaining forest. Bolsonaro promised to turn the public land occupied by indigenous peoples into private land where mining and agribusiness concerns can reap profits. The goal is to make more forest land available for capitalist speculation: cattle, soybeans, mining, and major construction projects.
This is why government ideologues fabricated the idea that “communism” – a system never implemented in Brazil and now largely irrelevant worldwide – is a looming threat to Brazilians. The supposed “international Marxist plot” serves to justify turning the forest into a commodity. In this fantasy, indigenous peoples, who are the chief barrier to destruction of the Amazon, are portrayed as a “threat to national sovereignty”.
The deforestation rate for 2018 was the highest in a decade. The mere possibility that Bolsonaro might win had a liberating effect on deforesters and further inflamed conflicts in a country where more environmental defenders are killed than in any other.
Without the world’s biggest tropical forest, there is no way to control global warming. If Bolsonaro’s messianic capitalism is not stopped, life on this planet will be much worse for everyone. For a contingent of neo-Pentecostal evangelicals, this may be welcomed as an apocalypse preceding the final salvation of “true believers”. For most of humanity, it will bring nothing but horror and suffering – perpetuated by the stupidity of a species with delusions of grandeur.
Translated by Diane Grosklaus Whitty
•Eliane Brum is a Brazilian journalist, writer and documentary maker

Ha Ha!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547626429000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4420827', u'in_reply_to': u'124679958', u'id': u'124704719', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"“It’s basically chaotic,” says Tony of the new climatic normal."
Although there won't be a "new normal" for millennia at the earliest, chaotic is a good term for a climate which is no longer relatively stable, like the last 10-12,000 years which roughly coincided with the development of agriculture, cities and civilization.
For a very long time now we've dialed in a lot of change. The paper below, published recently, raises an interesting question regarding adaptation to long-term climate change.
From the abstract:
BQSTART
Adaptation is the process of adjusting to climate change in order to moderate harm or exploit beneficial opportunities associated with it. Most adaptation strategies are designed to adjust to a new climate state. However, despite our best efforts to curtail greenhouse gas emissions, climate is likely to continue changing far into the future.
BQEND
The paper uses the example of sea level rise, currently around 4.4mm per year, to show one example of long-term, continuous change in climate.
BQSTART
Over the next 1000 years, sea-level is projected to rise at an average rate of 3.44 cm yr−1, if all available fossil fuel resources are combusted and the CO2 released to the atmosphere.
BQEND
Where would we rebuild our coastal cities, naval facilities and sea ports? There’d be no stable shoreline in any time scale of interest to humans.

I know it's drier on the east, but I didn't realise it had been that dry.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547569129000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100795284', u'in_reply_to': u'124654853', u'id': u'124668885', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SheerContent', u'text': u'Of course lots to do to get faur and organic, recycle etc', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547566550000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1948003', u'in_reply_to': u'124628762', u'id': u'124666345', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SheerContent', u'text': u'Well we all should be on the ball already on this.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547566505000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1948003', u'in_reply_to': u'124618925', u'id': u'124666317', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SheerContent', u'text': u'Gosh yes. So much to consider there. Last year some fellow allotment holders introduced me to some incredibly tangy and tasty herbs, some almost as hot as chilli. All grow well in the allotment. Just one small example of growing a hardy herb, rather than buying packaged spices, and so much more could be done .
Perhaps one small recommendation in every recipe to save food miles or whatever.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547566461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1948003', u'in_reply_to': u'124615323', u'id': u'124666268', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Tiberman', u'text': u'I live in the west of Scotland so as well as clay soil I am provided with very high rainfalls in an average year. I have over the years, raised the level of shrub beds, learned to live with mossy grass and I have seen a willow tree (not dwarf)thrive in the soil. I have a slabbed area (about a tenth of the rear garden with a slight gradient casting the water towards the rear edge of the property onto a gravel border where concrete posts and concrete gravel boards hold the timber border fence panels clear of the water that sometimes puddles there. I know concrete is not permeable but the slabs do give us a working area to place furniture and floral pots on for the odd days that sun shines. I do not think I have acted foolishly nor in antagonistic manner to nature by advocating a view that hard landscaping is a choice which in certain circumstances can be a good option to be able to enjoy an outdoor space.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547566277000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2949804', u'in_reply_to': u'124635285', u'id': u'124666096', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SheerContent', u'text': u'Great idea, particularly for contributors. I cut them back quite hard in the autumn, and I'll try following your suggestions.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547563922000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'124637018', u'id': u'124663922', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'lij lamja', u'text': u'It is very stressing to have ones bulbs flower out of the correct sequence.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547563528000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'101252791', u'in_reply_to': u'124611095', u'id': u'124663610', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'“If you go a little bit past the thermal optimum for tropical insects, their fitness just plummets,” he said.As the data came in, the predictions were confirmed in startling fashion. “The number of hot spells, temperatures above 29C, have increased tremendously,” he said. “It went from zero in the 1970s up to something like 44% of the days.” Factors important elsewhere in the world, such as destruction of habitat and pesticide use, could not explain the plummeting insect populations in Luquillo, which has long been a protected area.Data on other animals that feed on bugs backed up the findings. “The frogs and birds had also declined simultaneously by about 50% to 65%,” Lister said. https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/jan/15/insect-collapse-we-are-destroying-our-life-support-systems', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547559623000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'id': u'124660057', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Air conditioned tractor? Below is the site I got the data from, but I suspect you may know it already! https://apps.sepa.org.uk/rainfall/#charttop', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547554381000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12013283', u'in_reply_to': u'124623857', u'id': u'124654853', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'you do know the weather averages are based on a running mean from 1980?i.e. the average re adjusts each year.And the main issue I have found is the extremes that get smoothed out in averages- i.e. a week of intense cold followed by instant summer as we found out last year when spring was non existent.', u'recommendation_count': u'12', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547553669000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'124636809', u'id': u'124654270', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'The biggest road side pollutant is the salt put on the roads in icy weather- so with UK wet and mild winters even that will be reduced- Ironic.

If my box sprouts again, I will give it a go.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547544424000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10027069', u'in_reply_to': u'124623886', u'id': u'124645652', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Noutopia', u'text': u'Some great plants for gardens, Oregano/marjoram, cranesbill, Echinops, shrubby Honeysuckle, Lavender, Bees love these Plants, particularly Oregano, Oregano is drought resistant and seems to get no pests, with Herb plants you get great scents in the Garden too.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547543679000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10760557', u'id': u'124645010', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Duxk', u'text': u'Yup the squirrels do for any bulbs we plant unfortunately', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547542091000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'839690', u'in_reply_to': u'124612562', u'id': u'124644196', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Maggie B', u'text': u'So true.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547539064000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16300334', u'in_reply_to': u'124622841', u'id': u'124643077', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Maggie B', u'text': u'I'm in the E. midlands and Calendulas have been in bloom all winter in a south facing border- snowdrops last week. I have two house based rabbits and their "emissions" are producing great compost from my heap.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547538743000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12391528', u'in_reply_to': u'124641907', u'id': u'124642999', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BenWoodcockUK', u'text': u'Anyone else worried how dry this winter has been? Coupled with a hot summer we could be seeing water shortages.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547535753000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10189339', u'id': u'124642387', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Some kid asked the glaciologist Richard Alley the following question and I'll put the gist of his response.
Kid: "So what species of animal has been the most affected because of climate change?"
Alley: "I'm not sure I know the answer to that. You can pick a lot of the really easy glib ones, so polar bears are gonna get hit because they rely so much on sea ice, pikas are gonna get hit because they’re really cold adapted. 
Probably now the biggest worries may be things we don’t even know about. So you think about what we're doing, we have a lot of us and we have a lot of places that there's a thousand miles of cornfield and somewhere in that there's a little bog and in that bog there's somebody who’s hanging on and they may not be very important and they may not be very common but that's what they do. 
And now the climate changed and they need to get a thousand miles somewhere else and how do they get there? And so probably the initial real issues are how it combines with the other things that we're doing.
The climate change we’ve done so far is still pretty small compared to natural variability but we're pushing the system in multiple ways."
Climate cycles: What are we doing? We have blown the cycle out of the water. So the cycle was doing 180 to 280 parts per million atmospheric CO2 by volume over about ten thousand years and we have done more change than that in a hundred years.', u'recommendation_count': u'15', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547535427000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they \u2019re really cold adapted', u'effect': u'na get hit'}, {u'cause': u'they rely so much on sea ice', u'effect': u'you can pick a lot of the really easy glib ones gon pikas are gon na get hit because they \u2019re really cold adapted'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'124642330', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Silgen', u'text': u'"So-called gravity".', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547534490000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3956624', u'in_reply_to': u'124641186', u'id': u'124642196', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Solluz', u'text': u'Funny thing, last Sunday on TV was u'author_id': u'17273964', u'in_reply_to': u'124641580', u'id': u'124642137', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'How about "germ theory"?', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547533181000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'124641186', u'id': u'124642030', u'schema_org_type': Just reported now. https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/jan/15/insect-collapse-we-are-destroying-our-life-support-systems
BQSTART
Scientist Brad Lister returned to Puerto Rican rainforest after 35 years to find 98% of ground insects had vanished
BQEND
It's been a while since I had to buy a product to remove insects from my car. 
This recent article seems relevant https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/dec/20/risks-of-domino-effect-of-tipping-points-greater-than-thought-study-says', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547533122000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'124642017', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'admonfr', u'text': u'If its bad for gardners, spare a thought for farmers and the English climate was never easy!', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547532702000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13320334', u'id': u'124641957', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'jason campbell', u'text': u'Like Dianab says, consider your crops, potatoes are great for breaking up soil. I didn’t really take anything from the soil for over a decade, I grew in raised beds/pots using bought in soil (which I needed to replace the contaminated soil bulk anyway) and really the small garden was used to keep my rabbits and chickens happy in the main. I also have a clay soil, grey leading to red. I live on what was a floodplain, the land was recovered over the last 200 years. Worms do the main work in ‘no dig’ and I saw a massive increase in worms.
Rather than grass lawn I went with herbs and I was happy to put up with a work in progress for a decade. I have a small garden, maybe 5M square which made the work manageable.
The worms have mixed the clay in with the improved soil and general composting keeps on top of things by adding soil volume each year.
One benefit has been our council has adopted strict recycling targets which means you HAVE to compost because the bins are just far too small to just recycle. A rabbit turns a large amount of green waste into ready to use compost and he takes up much less space than a recycling/compost bin and that is important in my small garden and it cuts down on flies and associated problems with composting which are also problematic in smaller gardens.
My rabbit (and chickens when I kept them) are free range, raised beds protect the crops I really care about. Chickens destroy everything but I’ve found rabbits tend to calm down over time and don’t destroy everything- I grow kale just for the rabbit, the rabbit loves dandelions so they are absent from the garden, and we agree to share things like sorrel and similar salad crops.
And of course a rabbit is a cheap pet. He also hates cats so keeps our garden free from cats which encourages the birds. It is funny to watch the birds group around the rabbit in the garden for protection while they fill up on insects. 
I’m not self sufficient in any way, I don’t have the space or inclination, in fact ‘no dig’ suits my rather lazy nature.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547532299000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'red'}, {u'cause': u'the bins are just far too small to just recycle', u'effect': u'which means you have to compost'}], u'author_id': u'12868193', u'in_reply_to': u'124635701', u'id': u'124641907', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dianab', u'text': u'Yes, it's probably going to be a slug fest this year - might give my neighbour's fav method a go- get yourself 20 odd slugs from a couple of different sites (to raise chances of some being infected with nematodes, I believe)-put them in covered bucket to drown- leave the water for a few weeks (it stinks)- use it to water your beds liberally and then round the edges of beds after that', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547530847000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3093009', u'in_reply_to': u'124632142', u'id': u'124641766', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dianab', u'text': u'Tryplanting stuff that helps break the soil up - potatoes are good. Green manures are also worth thinking about - think clover is good for clay soils', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547530512000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3093009', u'in_reply_to': u'124635701', u'id': u'124641733', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'In 2016 James Hansen published a paper which suggested that shut down of deep ocean ventilation is more sensitive to meltwater off of the ice sheets than the models have suggested.
Were the AMOC to shut down, perhaps later this century as he suggested it might, the increased horizontal temperature gradient between high and low latitude regions would drive superstorms unlike any we have today. He noted that "all hell would break loose" in regions around the N Atlantic.
Good luck with those vines.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547528890000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'124641510', u'id': u'124641580', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Solluz', u'text': u'Haha, admiring the coral reefs in the Isle of Wight? or the tasty cabernet sauvignon from Devon?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547528247000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17273964', u'in_reply_to': u'124640825', u'id': u'124641510', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Or the "so called heliocentric model".', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547525241000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'124636164', u'id': u'124641186', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Across Britain, gardeners are facing the challenges of an unstable climate: extreme weather, unpredictability and prospering pests – and trying a range of solutions to cope
og_fields.og:description: Across Britain, gardeners are facing the challenges of an unstable climate: extreme weather, unpredictability and prospering pests – and trying a range of solutions to cope
og_fields.og:title: Growing pains: how the climate crisis is changing British gardens
text:
On a dank day in January, a small slice of Walsall is blooming. Marie and Tony Newton’s back garden is filled with summery colour: miniature mauve cyclamens, frilly red camellias, graceful hellebores, seasonal snowdrops and the bright green sheaths of bulbs promising more flowers to come. A few winters back, their first daffodil bloomed on Boxing Day.
“It’s basically chaotic,” says Tony of the new climatic normal. “It’s non-stop flowers from now on. Winters are milder on average and there’s every opportunity to have a riot of lovely flowers from December right through till spring.”
Deadly floods in Bangladesh, devastating wildfires in California, melting glaciers in Greenland, coral bleaching in the oceans – this is climate change in action. Highlighting far more benign changes in Britain, long blessed with a moderate climate, may appear trivial or downright insensitive. Our gentle extremes – the beast from the east, or summer 2018 being England’s hottest ever – are far from drastic. But they still pose challenges, and there is more change coming.
Britain’s 27 million gardeners could be the canaries in our coalmine. How are gardeners experiencing climate change in Britain and how is it transforming our gardens? And can adapting our gardening styles mitigate the negative impacts of climate change?
Marie and Tony couldn’t see their garden when they first viewed the house in 1982 because it was covered by a snowdrift. In the years since, as their south-facing quarter-acre evolved from a children’s play-space to a “four-seasons garden” with an all-year-round rainbow of flowers, shrubs and trees, they have witnessed the Midlands climate become steadily milder. Autumn frosts are much later, if they strike at all, and September is a summer month now. Their begonias continue until October. “That would never have happened in the past; we’d barely get through September without air frosts,” says Tony. “Although it’s warming up, you’ve got to plan for the extremes. We’re still going to get very severe winters and it will wipe out many gardeners’ new species.”
They know about this only too well. Their garden features a jungle area of bamboo, palm trees, a banana tree and the stumps of several Tasmanian tree ferns. These ferns survived the winter of 2009, the coldest for 30 years, but a run of -15C nights and sub-zero days the following December killed them off. “It’s a mortgage to replace them,” grimaces Marie. Climate change is encouraging many gardeners to buy exotic plants but “we still need truly hardy varieties,” says Tony. Their banana is wrapped in black cloth over winter. He ensures that whenever they add a shrub to the 3,000 in their garden it can survive at -15C.
Marie and Tony’s garden fared better during last summer’s drought. Their clay soils retain moisture, which helps, but they didn’t lose a single plant to the weather, despite being on holiday for two weeks. This may be because they are obsessive mulchers. Mulch is material added to the surface of the soil to increase organic matter and repress weeds. The Newtons have added 108 cubic metres of tree bark to their soil over the years; each year they also compost all their garden leaves and cuttings, reapplying this to their soil. This organic matter has steadily improved soil quality and, crucially, helps it retain moisture.
When Liam Shoesmith, deputy parks manager of Truro city council, saw how dry 2018 summer’s long-term forecast looked, he suggested the city’s gardeners should plant succulents and cacti for their Britain in Bloom competition entry. “It was a bit of a joke really,” he says. But the community group that organises Truro’s displays took his advice. In what the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) described as the “toughest year for community gardening in 54 years”, Truro’s blend of exotic, drought-tolerant plants, including palms and Mediterranean herbs, serviced by a solar-powered rainwater-harvesting system, thrived. And Truro won the Britain in Bloom competition for the first time.
Shoesmith is currently dispatching his team to mow parkland grass: milder winters mean Truro’s grass grows all year round. He began gardening as a boy in the 1980s. “It’s definitely milder and wetter,” he says. “The difficult thing we have with the climate is the more changeable weather. Last winter was probably one of the wettest on record here and then we went into one of the driest summers. The capricious nature of the weather is very hard to anticipate and work with.”
We don’t think of mild winters as extreme weather events, but December 2015 was the most anomalous month ever recorded, 5.1C above average, and the warmest in the Met Office’s central England temperature dataset, which stretches back to 1659. Shoesmith notices how pollinating insects, such as solitary bees, often emerge during these mild midwinters. If there are no flowers, and no nectar, they will perish. “Climate change is a big issue and as gardeners we can all do our bit to help by planting the garden so it’s flowering throughout the year,” he says. “We all want that anyway.”
Wildlife-friendly gardening focuses on native flowers, but Shoesmith argues we have long had non-native plants – particularly in milder Cornwall – and many exotic species are just as attractive to pollinators. In general, Britain’s 400,000 garden plant species provide genetic diversity, enabling more selection and breeding to adapt to future extremes. But Shoesmith also has a motto – “don’t go silly buying too much frilly” – because certain varieties of exotic flowers with lots of petals lose their nectar-holding sexual organs and so become useless for pollinators. Daisies, aconites, crocus, hellebores are good for winter-waking bees.
Allotment holders are also adapting to the increasingly capricious climate. Mandy Barber has turned to growing perennial produce on her plot in Ashburton, Devon. “Annual vegetables needed a lot more watering and it was touch and go whether they would make it last summer, but perennial vegetables have a lot more resilience to temperature changes,” she says. Barber is experimenting with crops including Taunton Deane kale; poireau perpétuel, a perennial leek; and Hablitzia tamnoides, or Caucasian spinach, which is grown in Scandinavia and can survive -25C. “The Hablitzia tamnoides plants go on for decades, they are like a rampant triffid, but you get a crop between February and June every year and the leaves are a bit like baby spinach,” says Barber. She also propagates and sells these perennials.
Every gardener I speak to agrees that milder winters are enabling more pests to survive and encouraging new pest species. Allan Trigg has been growing vegetables for more than 40 years and has an allotment in Chelmsford, Essex. “This is my little patch of England,” he smiles. Fewer frosts means his fellow allotment holders plant out runner beans, sweetcorn and potatoes earlier. With an extended growing season, Trigg can grow more, and second crops, although last year he grew less because he was spending so much time watering his vegetables. The dry weather produced lower yields of crops such as potatoes. After 2017, his potatoes lasted him and his wife through to February; this winter, they were eaten by November. And allium leaf miner and leek moth are a growing problem. “I used to grow loads of leeks but now I don’t bother,” he says. He pulls one up to show the damage below ground. “We never used to have this trouble years ago.”
In Walsall the Newtons are accepting of their growing losses to pests such as the lily beetle and the lace bug. “It went absolutely berserk after the hot summer,” says Tony. “I thought it was going to kill all the plants in the garden.” Barber is beset by voles (which survive the milder winters), while in Cornwall, Shoesmith has noticed the spread of fuchsia gall mite along the hedges. “It had the opportunity to come to Britain for decades, but only arrived this century because of the milder winters,” he says. “We don’t have the same amount of frosts now and so we get many more fungal problems.”
These observations precisely match the more scientific language of Gardening in a Changing Climate, a 2017 RHS report that outlines the challenges – milder winters, more unpredictable extremes and more pests – posed by climate change. But the RHS also asks how gardeners might help save the planet. The way we garden is still sometimes part of the problem – using precious water in pursuit of a perfect lawn during a drought springs to mind – but it can be part of the solution. Gardeners can reduce carbon dioxide emissions, mitigate pollution and flooding, and help increase their neighbourhood’s resilience.
“Water use in gardens is going to be a major issue in the future,” says Alistair Griffith, director of science at the RHS. London is forecast to require 100m litres a day more than it can supply in 2020, with this deficit rising to 400m litres a day by 2040. The use of energy-intensive mains water on gardens is still socially acceptable and Britain lags behind more water-stressed countries where grey-water recycling is commonplace. But hosepipe bans could become perpetual for some regions in coming decades.
Apart from using only rainwater – even a small balcony can catch and store rainwater with a mini-reservoir – Griffith recommends gardeners provide “as much greenery as possible”. He suggests planting hedges instead of fencing and planting trees. Trees not only dispel pollution but can alleviate flash flooding and provide shade for a home during heatwaves. Perhaps the most overlooked way gardening can benefit the climate is via the soil: adding organic matter (mulch from home-composting, not peat) can create a soil that stores more carbon and retains more water, also making gardens more resilient in flood and droughts.
Griffith’s final practical suggestion for climate-friendly gardening is to make everything permeable. Unfortunately, paving gardens for parking continues (in 2015, the RHS found that the number of paved, plant-free front gardens had tripled in 10 years from 1.5m to 4.6m). Even car park gardens can be permeable and planted with trees and shrubs around the edge. But, according to Griffith, people resist, citing a lack of time and a nervousness about failing at gardening. “Gardening is always trial and error,” he says. “Give it a go.”
Gardening won’t stop climate change, but it could make our local communities more resilient when faced with extreme floods, heat – and mild weather. In troubled times, it is also a fundamentally optimistic gesture.

article_tags: [Environment, Climate change, Green party, Politics, Economic policy, Economics, Business]
description: Letter: All discussion of Brexit or any other issue should be in the context of the need for government to enter emergency mode, writes Caro New, campaigns co-ordinator of the Green party
og_fields.og:description: Letter: All discussion of Brexit or any other issue should be in the context of the need for government to enter emergency mode, writes Caro New, campaigns co-ordinator of the Green party
og_fields.og:title: The primacy of climate change | Letter
text:
The Guardian is the only newspaper to recognise the seriousness of the threat we face from accelerating climate breakdown. Yet you, like Labour, still treat it as an “add-on” – as a separate subject, not something that, in Naomi Klein’s words, changes everything. Thus Jonathan Haidt and Pamela Paresky (Opinion, 10 January) write about the mental effects of childhood stress, never mentioning how terrifying it is for children to live in an environment of existential threat coupled with denial. Thus Owen Jones (Opinion, 10 January) discusses Labour’s Brexit choices and the need to reverse austerity, with no recognition that redistribution must now be within an economy focused on reducing emissions to net zero by 2030, not on “good” growth. All discussion of Brexit or any other policy issue should now be in the context of the need for central and local government to enter emergency mode.Caro NewGreen party of England and Wales campaigns coordinator (jobshare)

article_tags: [Climate change, Climate change, Oceans, Environment, Science]
description: Rising temperatures can be charted back to the late 1950s, and the last five years were the five hottest on record
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Rising temperatures can be charted back to the late 1950s, and the last five years were the five hottest on record
og_fields.og:title: Our oceans broke heat records in 2018 and the consequences are catastrophic
text:
Last year was the hottest ever measured, continuing an upward trend that is a direct result of manmade greenhouse gas emissions.
The key to the measurements is the oceans. Oceans absorb more than 90% of the heat that results from greenhouse gases, so if you want to measure global warming you really have to measure ocean warming.
There are other ways to measure climate change, but none are as convincing as the oceans. Air temperatures are most commonly reported in the media as evidence of global warming, but the problem with these is they are very erratic. While there is certainly a long-term trend of higher air temperatures, any given year may be warmer or colder than the last.
So oceans are key, and they are telling us a clear story. The last five years were the five hottest on record. The numbers are huge: in 2018 the extra ocean heat compared to a 1981-2010 baseline amounted to 196,700,000,000,000,000,000,000 joules. The current rate of ocean warming is equivalent to five Hiroshima-size atomic bombs exploding every second.
The measurements have been published in the journal Advances in Atmospheric Sciences in an article by Lijing Cheng, the lead author, and his colleagues from the Institute for Atmospheric Physics in China. His collaborators, of which I am one, included researchers from around the world. The article charts ocean heat back to the late 1950s, showing a steady increase.
Ocean warming is incontrovertible proof of global warming, and there are real consequences to a warming ocean. Firstly, warmer water expands, and this expansion causes sea levels to rise. Approximately a third of the rise in ocean waters is a result of the heat absorbed by the oceans. Scientists expect about one metre of sea level rise by the end of the century, which would be enough to displace 150 million people worldwide. 
The warming waters also make storms more powerful. In the US recently, we have seen hurricanes pass over extremely warm ocean waters, which has supercharged them and increased the damage they cause. Other kinds of storms are also being made stronger. Heavier downpours of rainfall are increasing flooding around the world. Simply put, our emissions of greenhouse gases have caused loss of life and property. We are all responsible, but the people who have denied the science and the solutions own a special responsibility that history will judge harshly.
It isn’t just humans that are suffering and will suffer more in the future. The heating of oceans is causing tremendous problems for sea life, particularly coral reefs. If we continue to warm the planet, we can expect to lose much of these reefs. We can also anticipate reductions in fish and sea life populations. 
We scientists sound like a broken record. Every year we present the science and plead for action. Not nearly enough is being done. We can still tackle climate change, but we must act immediately. We have the means to make a difference, we lack only the will.

When it warms some carbon dioxide out-gasses, it goes flat. The rises and falls in atmospheric carbon dioxide FOLLOW the rises and falls in ocean temperature."
No they don't. From 19,000 to 9,000 years ago the rise in global ocean temperatures followed the rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide.
At 33 degrees C I don't have much experience with Coke, but the tonic in my G&T follows the same principle. However even if I return the tonic water to the fridge but leave its lid off, it still goes flat. Pressure change over time plays a greater role in determining whether your fizzy drink will go flat. Temperature largely affects the rate at which this happens. When you remove your fizzy drink from the fridge, and unscrew the cap, it fizzes immediately, not due to the temperature change of the bottles contents - there has not been sufficient time for that, even at 33 degrees C - but due to the sudden pressure decrease.
Similarly in the ocean, while the ability of sea water to dissolve CO2 decrease with temperature, increasing atmospheric CO2 concentration and partial pressure is causing more CO2 to dissolve in the oceans reducing their pH. You need around 30 years of data to measure climate temperature. 20 years of data is not enough.
Satellites measure the temperature of the upper troposphere high above where humans live. Satellite data requires considerable adjustment (tampering) before it provides you with a measure of the temperature of the upper troposphere.
"Photographic evidence shows no significant rise in mean ocean surface levels in places known to be geologically stable - the land is neither sinking nor rising."
Mean ocean surface levels are measured using radar based satellites not by photographic means. Such satellite based measures are not affected by tectonism or geological instability. Global sea level rose between 20 cm between 1884 and 2014, an average rate of about 1.8 mm per year. By the later half of the 20th century that rate had increased to 3 mm per year.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547780237000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124751993', u'id': u'124809109', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"3. Temperature data is being falsified and always in the direction of increase. Closed data sources are being guessed at. Coverage is being diminished particularly in sites in the former Soviet Union and most of the planet has no data being measured at all. Existent measures of temperature data which used to be in normal environments are now in carparks or airports subject to local urban temperature increase. Published IPCC graphs past and present illustrate this to be true but the emails were icing on the cake." On land global temperature data is based on measurements made by meteorological organisations such as the Australian Bureau of Meteorology. In determining which sites more accurately reflect regional as distinct from local and urban climate temperature meteorologists take into account such factors as the urban heat island affect, changes in shading and wind tunneling from buildings as well as changes in vegetation in both urban, suburban and agricultural areas. They don't falsify data but remove sites or adjust data from sites to remove these cooling and biases in the measure of the regional climate temperature. Sites have removed or adjustments made which result in the cooling of the data, not always in a increase in the climate temperature shown by the data. Removal of a site or adjustment of the data from a site to remove the bias produced by an urban heat island will result in decrease in the temperatures shown by the data.
These data sources are not guessed at, nor are they closed but can be accessed on line. Adjustments are made and sites abandoned, in the determination of regional climate temperature, for objective reasons reflecting the factors discussed in the preceding paragraph. Ships and buoys measure ocean temperatures while sparsely populated countries such as Australia have a good coverage of meteorological stations. Any shortfall in central Asia would reflect the policies of the current Russian and US administrations. Removal of urban heat island bias from data in the 90s and earlier produced cooling of that data whereas recent increases in climate temperature data reflect global climate trends. You can't hide from reality by disingenuously accusing the messenger of falsification or misinterpreting casually written stolen private emails.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547778072000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'the cooling of the data'}, {u'cause': u'removal of a site or adjustment of the data from a site to remove the bias produced by an urban heat island', u'effect': u'decrease in the temperatures shown by the data'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124751993', u'id': u'124808794', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"2. Enormous amounts of work have been done in numerous disciplines in my lifetime. Collectively it has provided us with very good ideas of what has happened through history going back millions of years. The carbon cycle is not one of the parameters having any significant causal role in determining the climate."
Your last sentence is wrong. The carbon cycle was the major factor in causing the global warming which led to the end of the last glacial period or "ice age" over the 10,000 years of deglaciation between 19,000 and 9,000 years ago. The carbon cycle was also the cause of the early mid-Pliocene warming around 5 million years ago and the Palaeocene Eocene thermal maximum 55.5 million years ago.
"The current state of knowledge is that a significant number of periodic variables in the solar system and the sun itself drive the planet's climate."
The sun's energy output as a star has been increasing very slowly through the 4.543 billion years of the Earth's existence. This rate of increase is far to slow to have any noticeable impact on the Earth's climate in times spans of a couple of million to a couple of centuries over which which we have observed recent and Pleistocene climate change.
Periodic changes in the Earth's axial tilt, eccentricity of rotation and the point in the planets orbit where it is closest to the sun cause cycles in Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation (NHHLSI) over periods of 10,000 to 100,000 years. A peak in NHHLSI 19,000 years ago produced some melting of the North American and north Eurasian glacial continental ice sheets which at that time extended as far south as the regions of Yosemite, Chicago, New York, London, Milan and Belgrade.
This produced a large meltwater pulse in the North Atlantic shutting the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) which cools the Southern Ocean, which led to oxidation of oceanic oozes in the Southern Ocean increasing atmospheric CO2 resulting in global greenhouse warming over the next 10,000 years causing the Northern Hemisphere continental glacial ice sheets to retreat to their current levels.
Atmospheric CO2 reached 280 ppm 8,000 years ago on the shoulder of that NHHLSI peak. NHHLSI has declined slowly since then and will continue to do so for the next 50,000 years, at which time, if atmospheric CO2 had remained at the usual interglacial level of around 280 ppm, the glacial period or "ice age" would have started. If atmospheric CO2 is still at, near or above current levels of 410 ppm that next glacial period will not occur. Our most productive agricultural soils are in the Northern Hemisphere associated with glacial sediments produced by the glacial / deglacial cycle.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547775301000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the global warming which led to the end of the last glacial period or age'}, {u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'the end of the last glacial period or age'}, {u'cause': u"periodic changes in the earth 's axial tilt eccentricity of rotation and the point in the planets orbit where it is closest to the sun", u'effect': None}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'global greenhouse warming'}, {u'cause': u'which', u'effect': u'oxidation of oceanic oozes in the southern ocean'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'124751993', u'id': u'124808338', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gregory Shearman', u'text': u'A typical reaction from climate change deniers is to take an average, rather than looking at those who are losing their islands due to climate change.... 80 percent aren't shrinking, so therefore, climate change isn't happening... har har har... very good, I bet you think you're so clever.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547773443000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': u'who are losing their islands'}], u'author_id': u'14899696', u'in_reply_to': u'124806312', u'id': u'124807983', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gregory Shearman', u'text': u'Move inland? A scientific model is an hypothesis which you test against experimental evidence. If the results of the experiment agree or fit with the projections of your model, the model has been verified. With models of the current global warming this is what has happened.
Climate models of the current global warming projected what global climate temperature would result from various increases in atmospheric CO2. Their projections of global climate temperatures are what has happened with current atmospheric CO2 levels.
"Incidentally, all models have failed to predict the climate parameters over the last several decades and ALL have erred in being too high outside the error bars declared."

These “orbital perturbations” caused huge changes in climate due to amplifying feedbacks like ice melt and release of CO2 from warming oceans and methane from permafrost.
From PNAS in 2014: “Using satellite measurements, this analysis directly quantifies how much the Arctic as viewed from space has darkened in response to the recent sea ice retreat. We find that this decline has caused 6.4 ± 0.9 W/m2 of radiative heating since 1979, considerably larger than expectations from models and recent less direct estimates. Averaged globally, this albedo change is equivalent to 25% of the direct forcing from CO2 during the past 30 y.” https://www.pnas.org/content/111/9/3322
As the other half of the surface area of Arctic sea ice largely goes away by mid-century, that amplifying feedback will increase substantially. And the loss of seasonal snow cover in the North adds a similar amplifying feedback. 
I’m not sure the brakes available to us now are sufficient to stop this ball from rolling where we don’t want it to, so we need to figure out how to remove a lot of CO2 from the atmosphere soon.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547766172000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'earth orbital perturbations', u'effect': u'that exceeds the forcing'}, {u'cause': u'these \u201c orbital perturbations', u'effect': u'huge changes in climate'}, {u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'6.4 \xb1 0.9 w m2 of radiative heating'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'124806178', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Over the last 200 years as the oceans have warmed due to increasing CO2 they have increased in volume and risen. Northy is a goofy footers' paradise, I had my first tube ride there and my first big wave day on the bommie. I still have one of Simon Anderson's "Hot Buttered" surf-boards. I also learned to sailboard on Narrabeen lake and sailboard offshore from Sth Collaroy surf club so I know about the wind and sea conditions there. The major storm surges and swells usually come from the south, so Collaroy was usually protected by the Long Reef headland. The storm that caused the major erosion problems was a very rare double-black nor-easter, and Sth Colloroy beachfront was fully exposed. I do hope they save the beaches from erosion, for the sake of those who enjoy the surf and their natural beauty, not to save a lot of tacky surf-side mansions.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1547706240000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'16020012', u'id': u'124759045', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The next ice age or glacial period was not expected to happen for another 50,000 years.
